Name: To amend the Food Security Act of 1985 to increase funding for the conservation stewardship program, and for other purposes.
Summary:
This bill would reauthorize funding levels for the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP) at $1.8 billion annually.

It would also authorize $5.02 billion of unobligated balances from funds appropriated or made available under section 21001 of the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) to be used for CSP.
Support: N/A
Analysis:
The Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP), administered through USDA-NRCS,  supports a suite of conservation practices, including those directly related to building soil health. 

The bill would raise funding levels for CSP to $1.8 billion annually (for 5 years), up from $1 billion authorized for FY23. 

The bill would reallocate $5 Billion of “unobligated balances” from the IRA (inflation reduction act) to fund the majority of the increased CSP budget. Note: Senate Ag Committee Dems have said they would not approve reallocation of IRA funds.
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Michael Guest (R-MS-3), Rep. Mike Ezell (R-MS-4), Rep. Julia Letlow (R-LA-5), Rep. Eric Crawford (R-AR-1)
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Conservation, Research, and Biotechnology

Name: COVER Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill would establish the "Good Steward Cover Crop Program" to provide producers a $5 per acre premium subsidy when they enroll in a covered insurance program and plant cover crops for conservation purposes. This program would be voluntary and not require farmers to plant cover crops in order to be eligible for crop insurance. The program would be paid for through the Commodity Credit Corporation (CCC) (not RMA). 

Authorizes additional funding for technical assistance: Reserves $5 million for technical assistance, outreach, and program support to help producers access the Good Steward Cover Crop Program. Specifies that cooperative agreements can be entered into with organizations capable of assisting with outreach and coordinating with soil and water conservation districts to encourage the adoption of qualifying cover crop practices.

Requires RMA, FSA, and NRCS to coordinate and conduct a report not 1 year after enactment of the bill on number and amount of premium subsidies provided, acres of cover crops planted, and recommendations to increase the number of producers that quality for the subsidies. A study must also be conducted and reported on to examine whether planting qualifying cover crops leads to decreased crop insurance payments and stabilized yields compared to acres not using cover crops.

The bill also authorizes the Federal Crop Insurance Corporation to create a "Soil Health Pilot Program" to provide premium subsidies and assess risk-mitigating potential of other soil health practices. Specifies that premiums must be actuarially sound. The pilot program is to be conducted in a selected number of counties to evaluate the feasibility, effectiveness, and demand for the risk management tools implemented.
Support:
The bill is supported by the National Farmers Union, American Seed Trade Association, Evangelical Environmental Network, Natural Resources Defense Council, American Farmland Trust, National Wildlife Federation, Environmental Defense Fund, Izaak Walton League of America, E2, Michael Fields Agricultural Institute, World Wildlife Fund, Farm Action Fund, American Grassfed Association, Organic Trade Association, American Sustainable Business Network, Illinois Soybean Association, Illinois Farm Bureau, Illinois Farmers Union, Iowa Farmers Union, Wisconsin Farmers Union, Indiana Farmers Union, Ohio Farmers Union, Pennsylvania Farmers Union, Practical Farmers of Iowa, Danone, Unilever, Keurig, Dr Pepper, PepsiCo, MegaFood, Patagonia Provisions, Kent State University, and more. See full endorsement list [[here https://www.brown.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/cover_act_endorsement_list.pdf]]

Brown [[Press Release https://www.brown.senate.gov/newsroom/press/release/sherrod-brown-colleagues-introduce-bipartisan-bill-promote-soil-health-support-ohio-farmers-using-cover-crops]]
Analysis:
This bill creates a $5/acre crop insurance subsidy when farmers voluntarily plant cover crops for conservation purposes in a field that is already planted to another insurable crop.

The bill mandates up to $84 million annually to fund the subsidies, technical assistance, and outreach. 

The bill requires that USDA report on how yield and insurance payments for acres enrolled in the cover crop subsidy program compare to acres not enrolled to assess if cover crops reduce the risk of crop failure and insurance payments.

This proposal makes the Pandemic Cover Crop Program (PCCP) permanent and available nationwide. Over 12.2 million acres were enrolled in the program pilot in 2021, representing all 48 lower states.

The term ‘qualifying cover crop’ is defined as cereal or other grass, legume, brassica, nonlegume broadleaf, or any combination thereof that is planted for conservation purposes in accordance with the guidance of NRCS or any other expert as determined by the Secretary.

New in this version of the bill: • Clarifies that participation in a state program offering premium subsidies for conservation practices does not disqualify producers from receiving assistance under this section. • Requires NRCS, RMA and FSA to carry out and report on a study examining whether cover crops result in decreased crop insurance payments and stabilized yields. • Adds mandatory funding levels, starting at $60 million in 2024 and increasing to $84 million in 2028. • Explicitly mentions conservation crop rotations as eligible under the pilot program to receive similar discounts.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Tina Smith (D-MN), Sen. Ron Wyden (D-OR)

Name: Forest Conservation Easement Program Act of 2023
Summary:
Overall, the bill aims to establish a program that facilitates the conservation and restoration of forest land and related resources through the acquisition of conservation easements, with a focus on maintaining working forest land, protecting biodiversity, and meeting other conservation goals.

The bill contains many provisions, but the following purposes directly relate to forest soil health: 
 - to protect and enhance forest ecosystem and landscape functions and values
 - to maintain and enhance biodiversity
 - to enhance carbon sequestration

The bill creates working forest conservation programs (Forest Land Easments and Forest Reserve Easements) to be administered through the Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) and allocates funding for financial and technical assistance for each program. 

The bill authorizes $100,000,000 in mandatory funds annually from FY2024-FY2028.

The Conservation Fund [[Legislative Summary https://www.conservationfund.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/FCEP-Legislative-Summary-Final_May-2023-v2.pdf]] contains additional information.
Support:
This bill is endorsed by Wildlife Mississippi, National Alliance of Forest Owners, Boone and Crockett Club, Resource Management Service, LLC, Mississippi Forestry Association, The Conservation Fund, Land Trust Alliance, Congressional Sportsmen's Foundation. 

Rep. Kuster [[Press Release https://kuster.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=5360]]

Boone and Crockett Club [[Press Release https://www.boone-crockett.org/forest-conservation-easement-program-legislation-introduced-senate]]
Analysis:
This bill creates conservation programs for working forest lands that would allow forest owners and managers to improve forest soil health. 

According to the bill sponsors, "this program would build to mirror the framework from the established Agricultural Conservation Easement Program (ACEP), which is familiar to farmers and landowners. Eligible entities would purchase development rights from willing private and tribal landowners to prevent conversions to non-forest uses while maintaining working forests. This would help landowners restore, enhance, and protect habitat for at-risk species."

The working land conservation programs created in this bill replace the Healthy Forests Reserve Program (created in 2003).

Name: America Grows Act
Summary:
This bill permanently funds several agencies that perform agriculture research. The bill provides specified funding for the following agencies within the Department of Agriculture:

the Agricultural Research Service,
the Economic Research Service,
the National Agricultural Statistics Service, and
the National Institute of Food and Agriculture.
The bill exempts the funding from sequestration, which is a process of automatic, usually across-the-board spending reductions under which budgetary resources are permanently cancelled to enforce specific budget policy goals.

It also exempts the budgetary effects of the funding from the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010 (PAYGO) and the Senate PAYGO rule.

Analysis: Coming soon.

Name: Increased TSP Access Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill would:

Direct USDA to establish a process to approve non-Federal certifying entities within 180 days of enactment. The process would allow agricultural retailers, conservation organizations, cooperatives, professional societies, and service providers to become certifying entities.
Direct USDA to establish a streamlined certification process for TSPs who hold appropriate specialty certifications (including certified crop advisors) within 180 days of enactment. 
Ensure that TSPs—who are often paid using conservation program dollars—are paid the fair market rate for their services.
Support: Baird [[Press Release https://baird.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=311]]

Aims to address shortage of Technical Service Providers (TSPs).

The streamlined certification process is aimed at ensuring applicants with other certifications aren’t burdened with duplicative training, but are still trained in the competencies needed to serve as a TSP.

Name: Eliminating Needless Administrative Barriers Lessening Efficiency (ENABLE) for Conservation Act of 2023
Summary:
The ENABLE Conservation Act of 2023 proposes amendments to the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP).

The bill permanently establishes the State Acres For Wildlife Enhancement (SAFE) initiative under CRP, and expands the types of land that can be enrolled under the SAFE initiative.

It also allows for the SAFE initiative to be waived from the county acreage cap if it meets USDA goals.
Support:
The bill received supportive quotes from the National Wildlife Federation, Foster Creek Conservation District, Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife, Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife, and the Association of Fish & Wildlife Agencies.

See Schrier [[Press Release https://schrier.house.gov/media/press-releases/rep-schrier-introduces-bipartisan-bill-support-farmers-who-participate]]
Analysis:
From the press release: "Currently, there is a cap on how much land can be included in the Conservation Reserve Program, making it difficult for all farmers who want to participate to be able to. 

This bill reverts to a previous policy enacted under the 2014 Farm Bill to allow for SAFE and other important conservation programs to be waived from the county cap if it meets USDA and the county’s shared goals." 

The proposed amendments aim to streamline administrative processes and potentially increase the types of land eligible for enrollment in CRP.

CRP is often oversubscribed and is thought to be one of the most respected long term conservation programs (created in the 1985 Farm Bill).

These amendments seem to be aimed at increasing the flexibility and efficiency of the program, likely in an effort to better promote land and soil health conservation, and enhance wildlife habitats.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Jim Costa (D-CA-21)
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Dan Newhouse (R-WA-4)

Name: A bill to amend the Agricultural Credit Act of 1978 to authorize the Secretary of Agriculture to provide for floodplain easement restoration and management, and for other purposes.
Summary:
This bill proposes changes to the way floodplain easements are managed and restored in the United States. It is designed to provide the Secretary of Agriculture with the ability to offer both financial and technical assistance for restoring adapted vegetative cover and the hydrologic functions and values of wetlands on floodplain easements.

Key provisions include:

Easement Restoration: The Secretary of Agriculture may provide financial and technical support to restore vegetative cover and the hydrologic functions of wetlands on floodplain easements. 

Easement Management: The Secretary of Agriculture will have sole discretion to enter into compatible-use agreements with landowners, as well as with government agencies or non-governmental organizations.
Support: N/A
Analysis: The easement restoration agreements could help to improve environmental outcomes, as vegetative cover can reduce soil erosion, improve water quality, and provide habitat for wildlife; while the easement management agreements will address the maintenance and management of vegetative cover and the restoration of wetlands on floodplain easements.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Michael Bennet (D-CO)

Name: Recycling and Composting Accountability Act
Summary:
This bill would require the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to prepare and submit reports to Congress on the capability of the United States to implement a national residential composting strategy, and on federal agency recycling practices. The bill would also require EPA to collect, and make publicly available, data on recycling and composting rates across the country. 

This is the reintroduction of S. 3743
Support: See article [[here https://swark.today/boozman-backed-bills-to-strengthen-recycling-and-composting-pass-committee-advance-to-full-senate/]]
Analysis: Sec. 4 - Report on Composting Infrastructure Capabilities - is the most relevant section of this bill for agriculture. A consistent source of compost nationwide for use as fertilizer would be invaluable to the success of regenerative farming. Compost infrastructure and strategies are underdeveloped in the US (which is recognized in the bill's "Sense of Congress" section), leading to low quality and often unusable compost. The national strategy explored through the report in this section of the bill, including an evaluation of existing infrastructure and needs to expand composting programs, would potentially help to overcome these challenges.

Name: Conservation and Innovative Climate Partnership Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill would establish a competitive grant program under which the Secretary of Agriculture provides grants to land-grant colleges and universities to support agricultural producers in voluntarily adopting "conservation and innovative climate practices".

The grant program would:
Enable partnerships between land-grant institutions and local farmers to increase uptake of "conservation and innovative climate practices".
Require land-grant institutions to partner with a non-profit, state, or federal entity.
Allow the partnership to conduct a variety of activities to support farming communities like workshops, distribution of digital materials, and tests to measure the effectiveness of conservation and climate smart practices.
Provide $13 million in funding for 4-year grants, with a maximum grant of $400,000.

See [[one-page bill summary https://newhouse.house.gov/sites/evo-subsites/newhouse.house.gov/files/evo-media-document/2023_conservation_and_innovative_climate_partnership_act_one_pager.pdf]]

This bill is the reintroduction of H.R. 2613
Support: The Citizens for Responsible Energy Solutions (CRES) provided a supportive quote (see Newhouse [[Press Release https://newhouse.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/newhouse-introduces-bipartisan-bicameral-legislation-support-farmers]])
Analysis:
This bill defines 'innovative climate practice' as a practice that results in reduced emissions, carbon sequestration, soil health improvement, or reduced exposure to climate-related risk.

Eligible activities under the grant funding include providing technical assistance to agricultural producers in implementing a conservation practice or an innovative climate practice, conducting workshops and public awareness campaigns that provide direction to producers around how to access technical assistance, and for soil testing.

This version of the bill includes a new section 2 on Congress' findings, which include that farmers and producers are engaging in a variety of innovative climate and conservation practices, that producers are doing so for reasons including improved soil health, improved water quality and quantity, and wildlife management, and that the benefits include reduced GHG emissions, carbon sequestration, soil health improvement, and reduced exposure to climate-related risk.

Name: Open Access Evapotranspiration Data Act
Summary:
This bill proposes to establish the Open Access Evapotranspiration (OpenET) Data Program under the authority of the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the United States Geological Survey.

The main goal of the proposed OpenET Data Program is to provide satellite-based evapotranspiration data, to improve the quantification of evaporation and water consumption. This data is to be made available to users across large landscapes over certain periods of time, with priority for Landsat scale (30–100m) when available.
Support: Lee [[Press Release https://susielee.house.gov/media/press-releases/congresswoman-lee-senator-cortez-masto-introduce-bipartisan-legislation-fill]]
Analysis:
Evapotranspiration (ET) is the process by which water is transferred from the land to the atmosphere through evaporation from soil and other surfaces, and transpiration from plants. This process is a key component of the water cycle and is essential for understanding water availability and usage.

The bill recognizes the importance of evapotranspiration in managing water resources, as it is a measure of water consumption and loss from a system, which is important for managing water supply and demand. It also notes that current access to this data is often limited and cost-prohibitive, which impedes efficient decision-making in water management.

The proposed Act thus aims to provide an open-access, comprehensive source of evapotranspiration data to aid in water resource management and planning, and to support conservation and sustainability efforts.

Cosponsors (R): Rep. Chris Stewart (R-UT-2), Rep. Burgess Owens (R-UT-4), Rep. Celeste Maloy (R-UT-2)

Name: Recovering America’s Wildlife Act of 2023
Summary:
The purpose of this Act is to extend financial and technical assistance to States, territories, the District of Columbia, and Indian Tribes, including under the Pittman-Robertson Wildlife Restoration Act (16 U.S.C. 669 et seq.), for the purpose of avoiding the need to list species, or recovering species currently listed as a threatened species or an endangered species, under the Endangered Species Act of 1973 or under State law.

The bill establishes in the fund a subaccount to be known as the ‘Wildlife Conservation and Restoration Subaccount’, and provides funding for (1) the conservation or restoration of wildlife and plant species of greatest conservation need; (2) the wildlife conservation strategies of states, territories, or the District of Columbia; and (3) wildlife conservation education and recreation projects.

The Department of the Interior (DOI) must use a portion of the funding for a grant program for "innovative recovery efforts for species of greatest conservation need, species listed as endangered or threatened species, or the habitats of such species."

In addition, the bill requires certain revenues generated from fees and penalties for violations of environmental requirements to be used as a source for the funding.

This is the reintroduction of [[H.R. 2372 https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/senate-bill/2372/text]] - Recovering America's Wildlife Act of 2022, Senator Heinrich (D-NM) introduced alongside former Senator Roy Blunt (R-MO) in 2021. The Senate bill was voted out of the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works (EPW) in 2022. Before that, [[H.R. 3742 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/3742/text]] - Recovering America's Wildlife Act of 2019 (A version of this legislation was included as a bipartisan amendment to [[H.R. 2 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/2/text]], the Moving Forward Act).
Support:
RAWA is supported by over 60 Tribes and 1,500 organizations representing state fish and wildlife agencies, sportsmen and women, conservation groups, and industry associations and businesses. 

Heinrich [[Press Release https://www.heinrich.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/heinrich-tillis-introduce-bipartisan-recovering-americas-wildlife-act]]
Analysis:
The Recovering America’s Wildlife Act (RAWA): 

Funds conservation efforts for more than 12,000 species of wildlife and plants in need of assistance by providing $1.4 billion in dedicated annual funding for proactive, on-the-ground efforts across the country.

Provides Tribal nations $97.5 million annually to fund proactive wildlife conservation efforts on roughly 140 million acres of land.

Ensures wildlife recovery efforts will be guided by the Congressionally-mandated State Wildlife Action Plans, which identify specific strategies to restore the populations of species of greatest conservation need.

Accelerates the recovery of approximately 1,600 U.S. species already listed as threatened or endangered under the Endangered Species Act.

Includes improvements to ensure funds are appropriately targeted to the areas of greatest need and facilitate additional investments in protecting at-risk plant species.

This version of the bill contains a new section (Sec 3): "Sense of Congress Relating to Offsets" - that the costs of carrying out this Act, and the amendments made by this Act, shall be offset. 

This version also removes the clause from the former bill that allows penalties, fines etc. from natural resource or environmental-related violations to be used as revenue for the activities specified in the bill.

Name: NRCS Wetland Compliance and Appeals Reform Act
Summary:
This bill seeks to modify several NRCS compliance rules. Specifically, the bill would: 

Prohibit the NRCS from entering into permanent easement agreements, only allowing termed easements.

Make certain compliance penalties for newly determined wetlands only prospective.

Place the burden of proof on the NRCS to prove a violation, "rather than on the farmer/landowner to prove innocence."

Prohibit the NRCS from changing rationales for wetland determinations.

Require the NRCS to go through notice and comment rulemaking for conservation compliance, essentially banning the use of interim rulemaking.

Require the USDA to develop an appeals process for redetermination requests that are not accepted by state NRCS offices.

Require the USDA to establish state oversight committees, for each state, that will oversee the appeals of wetland determinations within each state.

Prevent the NRCS from using one-time observations to satisfy the hydraulic criteria for determinations.

Remove all references to “woody vegetation” from 7 CFR 12.2 and 12.32.

Create a customer satisfaction survey carried out by an independent survey provider.

Update the NRCS’ appeals process by "retraining the National Appeals Division judges and agency directors in how to provide a fair and balanced hearing", providing supports for farmers/landowners, and other measures.

(2) the impact of the changes described in paragraph (1) on farmers, ranchers, and downstream consumers, including—(A) financial impacts; (B) market entry impacts; (C) access to resources and inputs, including processing facilities; and (D) dietary impacts.

Analysis coming soon.

According to the press release:

"Cattle producers often make pennies on the dollar due to a lack of transparency and competition in the cattle processing industry, where four companies control the vast majority of the market.  During the pandemic, when processing slowed, the impact of this consolidation was exposed in the form of higher consumer prices and low supply.  Due to a bottleneck in processing and a lack of competition, farmers got less for their products, while consumers paid more at the grocery store.

Right now, there is a patchwork of data and research on consolidation in the livestock industry, but more information is needed to make policy decisions on how to best support small and independent ranchers and farmers. 

The Livestock Consolidation Research Act of 2023 moves beyond existing research to discover the impact of this consolidation on farmers and ranchers, as well as downstream impact on consumers."

Name: Agriculture Resilience Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill aims to reduce the impact of climate change on the agricultural sector, and to reduce agriculture emissions by 50 percent by 2030 and achieve net zero emissions by 2040.

The bill would quadruple funding and investment for agricultural research, with an emphasis on science-driven areas like climate change and adaptation, soil health, and farmland preservation and viability. 

The bill authorizes USDA to provide performance-based crop insurance discounts for farmers utilizing risk-reduction farming practices, and provides funds, information, and data for farmers and ranchers. 

Sec. 101(b)(2) establishes soil health benchmarks as goals for USDA and directs USDA to create an action plan that will reach these goals, including expanded adoption of soil health practices (crop rotations, cover cropping, among other practices) in order to restore soil health and sequester carbon, and to increase cover crop acreage in the United States. 

Title II directs USDA to pursue research to develop science-based methods to advance these goals, and education programs based on that information that would help farmers and ranchers who want to incorporate practices that support soil health. This research intends to accelerate the ability of agriculture and the food system to achieve net zero carbon emissions and ultimately become carbon negative.

Pursuant to these goals, Title V advocates for the establishment of pastured-based livestock management on 100 percent of grazing land by 2040.

Reintroduction of [[H.R. 2803 https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/2803]] - Agriculture Resilience Act of 2021

This comprehensive bill is framed as one that transition to regenerative agricultural practices comes with increased costs and risks, and thus intends to provide farmers with access to regional assistance in order to implement those changes (making regenerative agriculture both more accessible and more profitable for farmers to adopt). The bill includes seven titles: (setting a) I) National Goal; II) Research; III) Soil Health; IV Farmland Preservation and Farm Vitality; V Pasture-Based Livestock; Title VI On-Farm Renewable Energy; Title VII Food Loss and Waste

Name: Agriculture Resilience Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill aims to reduce the impact of climate change on the agricultural sector, and to reduce agriculture emissions by 50 percent by 2030 and achieve net zero emissions by 2040.

The bill would quadruple funding and investment for agricultural research, with an emphasis on science-driven areas like climate change and adaptation, soil health, and farmland preservation and viability. 

The bill authorizes USDA to provide performance-based crop insurance discounts for farmers utilizing risk-reduction farming practices, and provides funds, information, and data for farmers and ranchers. 

Sec. 101(b)(2) establishes soil health benchmarks as goals for USDA and directs USDA to create an action plan that will reach these goals, including expanded adoption of soil health practices (crop rotations, cover cropping, among other practices) in order to restore soil health and sequester carbon, and to increase cover crop acreage in the United States. 

Title II directs USDA to pursue research to develop science-based methods to advance these goals, and education programs based on that information that would help farmers and ranchers who want to incorporate practices that support soil health. This research intends to accelerate the ability of agriculture and the food system to achieve net zero carbon emissions and ultimately become carbon negative.

Pursuant to these goals, Title V advocates for the establishment of pastured-based livestock management on 100 percent of grazing land by 2040.

Reintroduction of [[S. 1337 https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/senate-bill/1337/text]] - Agriculture Resilience Act of 2021

Analysis:
This comprehensive bill recognizes that transition to regenerative agricultural practices comes with increased costs and risks, and thus intends to provide farmers with access to regional assistance in order to implement those changes (making regenerative agriculture both more accessible and more profitable for farmers to adopt). The bill includes seven titles: (setting a) I) National Goal; II) Research; III) Soil Health; IV Farmland Preservation and Farm Vitality; V Pasture-Based Livestock; Title VI On-Farm Renewable Energy; Title VII Food Loss and Waste

Name: Promoting Precision Agriculture Act
Summary:
The bill would "establish a partnership between the government and the private sector to develop voluntary interconnectivity standards and prioritize the cybersecurity needs for precision agriculture technologies."

Directs USDA, in consultation with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), to support the development of voluntary, consensus-based, industry-led interconnectivity standards, guidelines, and best practices for precision agriculture to encourage the adoption of precision agriculture technology.
 
Supports the evolving demands of precision agriculture by requiring USDA, the Federal Communications Commission, and NIST to consider the impacts next-generation technologies will have on precision agriculture.

Prioritizes the cybersecurity needs of precision agriculture. "As advanced precision agriculture technologies become more readily available, the agriculture industry has increasingly become vulnerable to cybersecurity threats."
Support:
The bill has been supported by NC State University.

Davis [[Press Release https://dondavis.house.gov/media/press-releases/us-representatives-davis-mann-introduce-bipartisan-legislation-increase]]
Analysis:
While not directly focused on soil health, the bill could indirectly promote soil health and resilience by:
--Improving data collection and analysis capabilities, allowing farmers to make more informed decisions about soil management.
--Enhancing the efficiency of input use, potentially reducing environmental impacts.
--Facilitating the adoption of precision conservation practices through improved technology integration.

To further advance soil health, the bill could incorporate provisions for:
--Research on how precision agriculture technologies can specifically support soil health practices.
--Education and technical assistance programs focused on using precision tools for soil health management.
--Incentives for adopting precision technologies that demonstrably improve soil health outcomes.

Name: New Markets for State-Inspected Meat and Poultry Act of 2023
Summary:
The bill would amend the Federal Meat Inspection Act and the Poultry Products Inspection Act to allow the interstate (i.e. across state lines) sale of meat and poultry products that have been inspected by state inspection programs (i.e. State Meat and Poultry Inspection - or MPI - programs).

See bill [[one pager https://www.rounds.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/New%20Markets%20for%20State-Inspected%20Meat%20and%20Poultry%20Act%20One%20Pager.pdf]]
Support: Rounds [[Press Release https://www.rounds.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/rounds-king-lead-bipartisan-legislation-allowing-local-meat-and-poultry-products-to-be-sold-across-state-lines-]]
Analysis:
Currently, meat and poultry products must be inspected by the USDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) to be sold across state lines. However, some states have established their own inspection programs that meet or exceed the standards of the FSIS (known as MPIs). The state-inspected products are currently limited to intrastate (i.e. inside the state) commerce, unless a state opts into a separate Cooperative Interstate Shipment (CIS) Program. This bill would allow meat and poultry products that have been inspected by the state programs to be sold in interstate commerce.

The bill aims to reduce regulatory burdens for small and medium-sized meat and poultry processors, as well as increase market access for producers in states with approved inspection programs. The bill also includes provisions related to labeling and record-keeping requirements to ensure that consumers have access to accurate information about the products they are purchasing. Overall, the goal is to create new markets while maintaining high inspection standards. 

In the United States, there are currently three types of meat and poultry inspection programs for products sold for human consumption: 
1) Food Safety Inspection Service (FSIS) federal inspection: Federally inspected meat is allowed to be sold across state lines and exported
2) Cooperative Interstate Shipment (CIS) Program: CIS-inspected products are treated as federally inspected 
3) FSIS-approved Meat and Poultry Inspection (MPI) programs: 29 States have a USDA-FSIS-approved MPI program, which provides inspection of meat and/or poultry

This bill does not eliminate or phase out the CIS program. If passed, the CIS facilities currently operating across the ten states that utilize this program can continue as they are. Additionally, this bill does not explicitly allow for products inspected by state MPI programs to be exported. 

Rounds and King also introduced this legislation in the 115th, 116th and 117th sessions of Congress.

Cosponsors (R): Rep. Carol Miller (R-WV-1)

Name: Biochar Research Network Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill would establish a national biochar research network at USDA.

The research network would include up to 20 centers "to test the impact of biochar across various soil types, application methods and climates to learn more about its capacity to benefit farmers and the environment."

The specific goals of the network would be to "understand the uses of biochar in crop production and climate mitigation; assessing its potential for soil carbon sequestration; and delivering cost-effective and practical information to farmers on sustainable biochar production and application."

Authorizes appropriations of $50 million annually.
Support:
The press release contains a support statement from David Laird, Professor Emeritus of Soil Science at Iowa State University.

Miller-Meeks [[Press Release https://millermeeks.house.gov/media/press-releases/miller-meeks-pingree-schrier-introduce-biochar-research-network-act]]

In May 2022, Miller-Meeks and colleagues wrote a [[letter https://millermeeks.house.gov/sites/evo-subsites/millermeeks.house.gov/files/evo-media-document/5.26.2022%20MMM%20IA%20Delegation%20Letter%20to%20EPA%20and%20USDA.pdf]] to USDA and EPA expressing their support for biochar.
Analysis:
Biochar is created through the thermal or chemical conversion of biomass. For example, when a forest fire burns up trees and plants it leaves behind biochar. It spans across all kinds of black carbon, and can be made from many different types of organic material – including agricultural waste.

The proposal includes assessments of the most promising uses of biochar, including to "increase profitability, scalability, and portability", "to improve ecosystem and soil health", and "strengthen resilience to extreme weather events". 

Requires the centers to "share research results to inform farmers, horticulturalists, ranchers, foresters, urban biochar users, extension agents and specialists, and technical assistance providers on the most advantageous ways to use biochar to increase profitability, raise productivity, lower costs, improve soil and plant health, and enhance resilience to extreme weather events while contributing to carbon sequestration and greenhouse gas reductions."

Name: Advancing Cutting Edge (ACE) Agriculture Act
Summary:
This bill would reauthorize the Agriculture Advanced Research and Development Authority (AgARDA). Established in the 2018 Farm Bill, AgARDA is a federal agency that focuses on advancing agricultural research and development to address challenges facing the agricultural industry. Name: Plant Biostimulant Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill would:

Amend the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) to define what is a plant biostimulant and exclude it from being regulated under the Act.

Require the U.S. Environmental Agency (EPA) to revise existing Code of Federal regulations to include this new plant biostimulant definition.

Require U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) to study and publish a report on how plant biostimulant products can contribute to soil health.
Support: The bill has been endorsed by the Humic Products Trade Association (HPTA), Marrone Bio Innovations, BPIA, Novozymes Inc., Biotechnology Innovation Organization, and the American Seed Trade Association (ASTA).
Analysis:
The Plant Biostimulant Act of 2023 seeks to establish a consistent definition for plant biostimulants and exclude them from FIFRA (the  Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act) regulation. It also directs the Secretary of Agriculture to conduct a study on the best practices using plant biostimulants to improve soil health, reduce nutrient runoff, and contribute to agricultural sustainability.

While the bill offers a clear definition for plant biostimulants (a substance, micro-organism, or mixture thereof, that, when applied to seeds, plants, the rhizosphere, soil, or other growth media, act to support a plant’s natural processes independently of the biostimulant’s nutrient content, including by improving nutrient availability, uptake or use efficiency, tolerance to abiotic stress, and consequent growth, development, quality, or yield)  it also excludes them from FIFRA regulation, which may inadvertently create a regulatory gap for these substances. 

The bill calls for a soil health study, which can provide valuable information on the most effective plant biostimulant practices to achieve various goals, such as reducing nutrient runoff or increasing carbon sequestration. However, the bill does not set forth any specific criteria or guidelines for implementing the findings of the study or ensuring that plant biostimulant practices are incorporated into agricultural practices in a meaningful way.

The Plant Biostimulant Act of 2023 also does not provide any funding for research or implementation of plant biostimulant practices.

Name: Agricultural Management Assistance Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill would reauthorize and make adjustments to the Agriculture Risk Management Education (ARME) and the Agricultural Management Assistance (AMA) programs, which aim to help farmers manage financial risk through diversification, marketing or conservation practices.

The bill would boost funding for the AMA to $30 million, increase funding limits for farmers to $200,000 over five years, and expand the eligible uses for these funds to include soil health improvements, composting, implementing organic farming, developing value-added processing, and food safety certification in addition to existing authorized uses such as water management structure and soil erosion control.

Allocates $10 million annually to the PRME program, with at least half going towards training of crop insurance providers and producers who are underserved by the FCIP. 

In addition to these amounts, the bill makes an additional one-time $20 million available.

This bill draws on and makes adjustments to [[H.R. 8706 https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/8706/text]] - the Agricultural Management Assistance Modernization Act of 2022 - from the 117th Congress.
Support: Murphy [[Press Release https://www.murphy.senate.gov/newsroom/in-the-news/murphy-introduces-bill-to-aid-farmers-in-financial-risk-management]]
Analysis:
This bill expands the purpose of the Partnership for Risk Management Education (PRME) from educating only agricultural producers to also edcuating approved crop insurance providers (with a focus on whole farm diversified risk management insurance plans), as well as providing language translation services for the program.

The Agricultural Management Assistance (AMA) program currently provides financial assistance to producers for a number of risk management activities, including mitigating financial risk through production or marketing diversification or resource conservation practices, including soil erosion control, integrated pest management, organic farming, or developing/implementing a plan to create marketing opportunities including through value-added processing. This bill adds to the conservation practices named in this paragraph, the following: soil health improvements, development of sustainable water sources and irrigation, perennial crop establishment, including establishment of agroforestry systems, integration of livestock, aerobic composting of crop and livestock waste, or "other conservation practices determined by the Secretary to reduce the risk to a farm of financial loss due to the regional impacts of climate change". The bill also adds to the eligible production or marketing diversification activities aimed at mitigating financial risk, the following: "developing or implementing a plan to establish market infrastructure for the producer to support enterprise diversification, including drying and storage facilities for small grains from resource-conserving crop rotations", organic farming, and food safety certification.

Recognizes soil health as a risk management strategy, and specifically calls out and funds some important components of soil health systems, including livestock integration, perennial crops, and agroforestry. 

Addresses the need for markets and infrastructure to support getting soil health-focused products to market. Access to local infrastructure and markets a major need and the lack of these components present a risk as it relates to transitioning to soil health systems.

There is a large unmet need for language translation in the delivery of federal education and technical assistance programs. 

Triples the annual funding for PRME.

Context: This bill makes updates to the Agriculture Risk Management Education Partnerships Program (ARME), which is a competitive grant program of NIFA. The 2018 Farm Bill reauthorized ARME, merged it with RMA's Crop Insurance Education in Targeted States Program, and provided $10 million in mandatory funding for the new merged program (previously, $5 was allocated to the ERME). These funds are distributed through the 4 regional ERME centers across the country (as well as the 1 digital center). The AMA is only available to 16 states that have historically low rates of participation in the Federal Crop Insurance Program.

Name: Relief for Farmers Hit with PFAS Act
Summary:
This bill would authorize the Secretary of Agriculture to provide grants to States, territories, and Indian Tribes to address contamination by perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) on farms.

Funds could be used for a variety of purposes, including: providing financial assistance to affected farmers; building capacity for PFAS testing for soil or water sources; monitoring blood for individuals to make informed decisions about their health; upgrading or purchasing equipment to ensure a farm remains profitable during or after known PFAS contamination; developing alternative production systems or remediation strategies; developing educational programs for farmers experiencing PFAS contamination; and researching soil and water remediation systems, and the viability of those systems for farms.

The bill provides $500 million for the period of fiscal years 2024 through 2028.

Summary: This bill would reauthorize the Healthy Food Financing Initiative and provide annual CCC funding on an increased basis, up to $50 million by 2028.

Name: Promoting Precision Agriculture Act
Summary:
The bill would "establish a partnership between the government and the private sector to develop voluntary interconnectivity standards and prioritize the cybersecurity needs for precision agriculture technologies."

Directs USDA, in consultation with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), to support the development of voluntary, consensus-based, industry-led interconnectivity standards, guidelines, and best practices for precision agriculture to encourage the adoption of precision agriculture technology.
 
Supports the evolving demands of precision agriculture by requiring USDA, the Federal Communications Commission, and NIST to consider the impacts next-generation technologies will have on precision agriculture.

Prioritizes the cybersecurity needs of precision agriculture. "As advanced precision agriculture technologies become more readily available, the agriculture industry has increasingly become vulnerable to cybersecurity threats."
Support: Thune [[Press Release https://www.thune.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?ID=F7822970-6581-4F90-91D1-42D0B0C05CBD]]
Farm Bill Status: House companion (H.R. 1697) included in the House Farm Bill.
Analysis:
While not directly focused on soil health, the bill could indirectly promote soil health and resilience by:
--Improving data collection and analysis capabilities, allowing farmers to make more informed decisions about soil management.
--Enhancing the efficiency of input use, potentially reducing environmental impacts.
--Facilitating the adoption of precision conservation practices through improved technology integration.

To further advance soil health, the bill could incorporate provisions for:
--Research on how precision agriculture technologies can specifically support soil health practices.
--Education and technical assistance programs focused on using precision tools for soil health management.
--Incentives for adopting precision technologies that demonstrably improve soil health outcomes.

Summary:

The program would offer loans up to $500,000 between 3 and 12 years in length at interest rates of less than 2% and create a list of acceptable precision agriculture technologies approved by the FSA and covered by USDA. This funding would also allow farmers to retrofit existing equipment with new technologies.

Appropriates "such sums as are necessary".

Reintroduction of [[H.R. 9047 https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/9047/text]] - Precision Agriculture Loan Program Act of 2022 (with no change).
Support:
The bill is supported by the Association of Equipment Manufacturers

Feenstra [[Press Release https://feenstra.house.gov/media/press-releases/feenstra-panetta-introduce-legislation-help-farmers-purchase-cutting-edge]]
Analysis:
Precision agriculture is defined in the act as "managing, tracking, or reducing crop or livestock production inputs, including seed, feed, fertilizer, chemicals, water, and time, at a heightened level of spatial and temporal granularity to improve efficiencies, reduce waste, and maintain environmental quality."

The bill provides a list of approved equipment types.

This is a low-interest rate loan program that will lower the cost of new "precision agriculture" equipment acquisition. Given that this approach is aimed at improving efficiency and reducing input use.

Name: Plant Biostimulant Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill would:

Amend the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) to define what is a plant biostimulant and exclude it from being regulated under the Act.

Require the U.S. Environmental Agency (EPA) to revise existing Code of Federal regulations to include this new plant biostimulant definition.

Require U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) to study and publish a report on how plant biostimulant products can contribute to soil health.   

This is the reintroduction of [[H.R. 7752 https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/7752/text]]
Support:
The bill has been endorsed by the Humic Products Trade Association (HPTA), Marrone Bio Innovations, BPIA, Novozymes Inc., Biotechnology Innovation Organization, and the American Seed Trade Association (ASTA). 

Panetta [[Press Release https://panetta.house.gov/media/press-releases/rep-panetta-introduces-bipartisan-bill-bolster-plant-biostimulant-research-and]]
Analysis:
The Plant Biostimulant Act of 2023 seeks to establish a consistent definition for plant biostimulants and exclude them from FIFRA (the  Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act) regulation. It also directs the Secretary of Agriculture to conduct a study on the best practices using plant biostimulants to improve soil health, reduce nutrient runoff, and contribute to agricultural sustainability.

While the bill offers a clear definition for plant biostimulants (a substance, micro-organism, or mixture thereof, that, when applied to seeds, plants, the rhizosphere, soil, or other growth media, act to support a plant’s natural processes independently of the biostimulant’s nutrient content, including by improving nutrient availability, uptake or use efficiency, tolerance to abiotic stress, and consequent growth, development, quality, or yield), it also excludes them from FIFRA regulation, it may inadvertently create a regulatory gap for these substances. 

The bill calls for a soil health study, which can provide valuable information on the most effective plant biostimulant practices to achieve various goals, such as reducing nutrient runoff or increasing carbon sequestration. However, the bill does not set forth any specific criteria or guidelines for implementing the findings of the study or ensuring that plant biostimulant practices are incorporated into agricultural practices in a meaningful way.

The Plant Biostimulant Act of 2023 also does not provide any funding for research or implementation of plant biostimulant practices.

Name: Producing Responsible Energy and Conservation Incentives and Solutions for the Environment (PRECISE) Act of 2023
Summary:
The PRECISE Act will provide funding through existing USDA loan programs to help producers purchase precision agriculture equipment. The bill:

Includes precision agriculture technologies within USDA’s Conservation Loan and Guaranteed Loan program, with up to a 90% guarantee.

Increases cost share and practice payments for precision agriculture technologies under the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) and the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP)

Funds 100% of precision agriculture projects through joint participation of conservation cost share programs and the Conservation Loan Program

Requires the Secretary of Agriculture to emphasize the use of third-party providers for technical assistance for soil health planning

New in this version of the act is a new SEC. 4 - providing definition of "precision agriculture technology" with a list of technologies.

Reintroduction of [[H.R. 2518 https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/2518/text]]
Support:
This bill is supported by Food and Agriculture Climate Alliance, American Farm Bureau Federation, American Soybean Association, Association of Equipment Manufacturers, Iowa Farm Bureau and John Deere.

Hinson [[Press Release https://hinson.house.gov/media/press-releases/hinson-introduces-bipartisan-precise-act-expand-access-precision-ag-technology]]
Analysis:
The PRECISE Act seeks to encourage the adoption of precision agriculture practices by incorporating them as recognized conservation practices under EQIP and CSP. It proposes a 90% cost-share for purchasing precision agriculture equipment, systems, and technology under EQIP, payments under CSP, and loan guarantees. Additionally, the bill aims to incentivize private sector financing of precision agriculture equipment through existing programs and emphasizes technical assistance for soil health planning.

However, with no clearly defined standards or outcomes tied to payments, the substantial cost-share (without any additional funding) will likely further strain EQIP and CSP's budgets, reducing funding for other established and effective conservation practices. The bill also lacks any prioritization of higher impact practices or projects, which could result in less effective use of resources.

Incentives are not tied to specific conservation outcomes. 

Additionally, the PRECISE Act does not include any provisions for evaluating the conservation impacts of incorporating any of the precision agriculture practices it would subsidize in EQIP and CSP.

Name: EQIP Improvement Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill would:

Reduce the overall five-year EQIP payment cap per grant award from $450,000 to $150,000.

Reduce the federal cost-share from 75% to 40% for structural practices including roads, fish ponds, stock ponds, dams, animal waste pits, pipelines, and land clearing (see bill text for full list of practices).

Eliminate the requirement that 50% of EQIP funding flow to livestock operators.
Support:
The bill has received support from the American Grassfed Associatin, Association of American Indian Farmers, Farm Action, Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy, National Black Farmers Association, American Conservation Coalition, American Sustainable Business Network, Earthjustice, Environmental Working Group, Food and Water Watch, National Taxpayers Union, Natural Resources Defense Cuncil, R Street Institute, Taxpayers for Common Sense, and others (see full list [[here https://www.booker.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/eqip_improvement_act_endorsement_list.pdf]])

Booker [[Press Release https://www.booker.senate.gov/news/press/booker-lee-reintroduce-bipartisan-bill-to-improve-eqip-conservation-program]]
Analysis:
The bill aims to "ensure more farmers and ranchers can participate in the program, particularly small farmers, funding the most effective conservation practices, and giving states more flexibility in implementing the program."

The reduction of the payment cap is aimed at freeing up EQIP funds to serve more farmers and address the backlog of applications (two out of every three farmers are currently turned away from EQIP, creating an unfunded annual backlog for EQIP of more than $2 billion).

The reduction of federal cost-share for infrastructure projects is aimed at freeing up funds for conservation practices that provide more direct benefits. Between 2018 and 2021, over $812 million of EQIP funds were spent on these infrastructure practices. 

The removal of the 50% set-aside for livestock operators is aimed at instead allowing "each state to determine the best distribution of funding for itself" and meet conservation needs locally. Over $1.8 billion went to livestock operations between 2017 and 2020, including concentrated animal feeding operations.

Name: Cattle Price Discovery and Transparency Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill would:

Require the Secretary of Agriculture to establish 5-7 regions encompassing the entire continental U.S. (that reasonably reflect similar fed cattle purchases) and then establish minimum levels of fed cattle purchases made through approved pricing mechanisms. Approved pricing mechanisms are fed cattle purchases made through negotiated cash, negotiated grid, at a stockyard and through trading systems that multiple buyers and sellers regularly can make and accept bids.

Require USDA to set minimum levels of purchases through approved pricing mechanisms that covered packers – those controlling five percent of more of fed cattle slaughter – must make.

Include provisions to create a publicly available "cattle contract library" of marketing contracts, mandating boxed beef reporting to ensure transparency, expediting the reporting of cattle carcass weights, and requiring a packer to report the number of cattle scheduled to be delivered for slaughter each day for the next 14 days. The contract library would be permanently authorized and specify key details about the contents that must be included in the library – like the duration and other provisions in the contract that may impact price such as schedules, premiums, discounts, and transportation arrangements.

Mandate that each regional mandatory minimum be not less than the average of that region’s negotiated trade for the two year period of 2020-2021. Additionally, sets a maximum threshold for any region at 50 percent. Require USDA to conduct an initial review of mandatory minimums after two years. Allow USDA to work with the cattle and beef industry to periodically review and modify regional minimums after a public notice and comment period.

See [[one-page summary https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/8251ceae-b1b8-4f61-a617-a337f56dda08/3.28.22---acattle-market-transparency-one-pager-updated-6-.pdf]] and [[section-by-section summary https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/20e5a458-c8f9-4af1-90a2-c901aba51fd7/2.1.23---cattle-market-transparency-summary---section-by-section-updated-1-9-.pdf]]

Analysis:
This bill could support small and regenerative livestock producers through improved transparency in cattle markets.

From [[one-pager https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/8251ceae-b1b8-4f61-a617-a337f56dda08/3.28.22---acattle-market-transparency-one-pager-updated-6-.pdf]]: 

"A significant challenge facing the cattle industry is the declining number of participants in the negotiated cash market. In order to have robust price discovery that provides accurate information about market dynamics along the supply chain, you need a competitive cash
market with multiple price discovery points. Negotiated trade, also called the “cash” or “spot” market increasingly has been replaced by formula pricing, forward contracts, and longer-term marketing agreements—collectively referred to as “alternative marketing
arrangements” (AMAs).

Negotiated transactions involve a bid and ask process. The negotiated market facilitates price discovery, which is the process of establishing the “going rate” of cattle based on market conditions at any given time. Formula pricing, where a reference price from a published report is used as the base price for the transaction, is becoming more common. The bulk of formula pricing uses negotiated cash prices as the base in the formula— meaning information from the negotiated cash market is being heavily leveraged by nonparticipants, even as negotiated purchases decline in volume. 

If a packer relies on the negotiated market to set the price for a large portion of the cattle they purchase, they should actively participate in establishing the negotiated price."

Sens. Fischer, Wyden, Grassley, and Tester introduced the [[Cattle Price Discovery and Transparency Act https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/news?ID=ED39FFA4-8F1D-4211-80F9-1B4F3EBD11CA]] in March 2022. In June, the Senate Agriculture Committee [[approved https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/news?ID=2F7F6480-E5A3-4BE4-93EA-83B0D230EBA1]] the legislation, which passed by voice vote. This was an updated version of the bill that Sen. Fischer previously [[introduced https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2021/11/ischer-leads-cattle-market-price-discovery-and-transparency-bill]] in 2021.

Name: Opportunities for Fairness in Farming Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill establishes restrictions and requirements for checkoff programs, which are programs overseen by the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to promote and provide research and information for a particular agricultural commodity without reference to specific producers or brands.

The bill prohibits boards established to carry out a checkoff program or a USDA order issued under a checkoff program from entering into a contract or agreement to carry out program activities with a party that engages in activities to influence any government policy or action that relates to agriculture.

A board or its employees or agents acting in their official capacity may not engage in any: act that may involve a conflict of interest; anticompetitive activity; unfair or deceptive act or practice; or act that may be disparaging to, or in any way negatively portray, another agricultural commodity or product.

Upon approval of USDA, a board may enter directly into contracts and agreements to carry out generic promotion, research, or other activities authorized by law if the agreement or contract requires records accounting for the funds received to be submitted to the board.

The board must meet specified requirements regarding the publication of budgets and disbursements of funds.

The USDA Inspector General and the Government Accountability Office must conduct specified audits regarding checkoff programs.
Support: Mace [[Press Release https://mace.house.gov/media/press-releases/rep-mace-and-rep-titus-introduce-new-bill-reform-checkoff-programs]]
Analysis: According to the press release: "Checkoffs are mandatory Department of Agriculture fees assessed on a per-unit basis that fund boards designed to promote the commodity as a whole. However, checkoff funds are frequently coopted against the interests of some or even a majority of contributors. Countless farmers, ranchers, and other producers have seen their checkoff dollars squandered or used against their interests. This bill would prohibit certain wasteful, anti-competitive, and deceptive behavior from checkoff boards."

Name: Protect the West Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill establishes an "Outdoor Restoration and Watershed Fund" at USDA to increase support for local efforts to: restore forests and watersheds, reduce wildfire risk, clean up public lands, enhance wildlife habitat, remove invasive species, and expand outdoor access. The bill establishes a Restoration Fund Advisory Council to advise funding priorities, coordinate with existing regional efforts, and provide oversight for the Fund. 

The purpose of the Fund is to provide funding to a grant program and a partnership program, including: 

$20 billion for the "Restoration and Resilience Grant Program", which funds state and local governments, Tribes, special districts, and nonprofits to support restoration, drought resilience, and fire mitigation projects. 

$40 billion for the "Restoration and Resilience Partnership Program", which partners with states and Tribes to carry out restoration, fire mitigation, and resilience projects across public, private, and Tribal lands. 

The bill proposes to create or sustain two million jobs, including in agriculture.

This bill is a reintroduced/renamed and amended version of [[H.R. 2682 https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/2682]] - the Outdoor Restoration Partnership Act of 2021 (117th Congress)
Support:
The bill is supported by: The National Wildlife Federation, the Southern Ute Indian Tribe, National Association of State Foresters, The Freshwater Trust, American Forests, National Wild Turkey Federation, National Audubon Society, Family Farm Alliance, Theodore Roosevelt Conservation Partnership, Western Landowners Alliance, Western Resource Advocates, Trout Unlimited, and Conservation Legacy.

Crow [[Press Release https://crow.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-crow-senator-michael-bennet-introduce-protect-the-west-act-to-combat-intensifying-wildfires-and-drought-across-the-american-west]]
Analysis:
This bill seeks to address soil health at the landscape scale. The bill focuses on restoration and resilience, but could incorporate more explicit focus on soil health (e.g. by giving priority to projects that build soil health as a central component of achieving the stated goals (improving forest, watershed, and rangeland health and mitigating wildfire), in addition to the stated job creation goals).

New in this version of the Act (compared with S. 1248): 

Adds conservation programs, including RCPP, to the covered authorities the Secretary may use when carrying out a restoration and resilience project under the Fund

Renames the "Outdoor Restoration Fund" to the "Outdoor and Watershed Restoration Fund", signaling this bill's focus on tackling the water issues of the west 

Adds provisions to the establishment of the Fund on "(f) Interagency Flexibility And Leverage.", "(g) Pay-For-Performance Contract Authority." and "(h) Acceptance And Use Of Contributions"

Gives additional mandates to the Restoration Fund Advisory Council, established under SEC. 4, for "(2) priority-setting for landscapes"; and "(3) evaluation and monitoring for restoration and resilience project success." 

Adds pay-for-performance contracts to the grant program under SEC. 5 

Directs the Secretary and Council to "complement or support existing State or regional efforts, initiatives, and partnerships to restore ecological integrity on Federal land and non-Federal land" under the grant program. 

Adds several provisions to support and reduce barriers to participation for underserved communities, including grant-writing training and mentoring, waiving of matching requirements under covered authorities, 

Adds a requirement for eligibility to participate in the Partnership Program under SEC. 6 that the area must have "fire-risk assessment resources or mapping tools maintained by the applicable State"

Adds several priorities to the restoration and resilience projects under the SEC. 6, including improving water quality and quantity outcomes in waterways that low through and out of priority areas, proactive wildfire risk mitigation actions in the wildland-urban interface, etc. 

Adds a new SEC. 7 - OVERSIGHT, requiring a Report to Congress 60 days after enactment of the Act. 

Other small changes.
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Conservation, Research, and Biotechnology & Subcommittee on Forestry; Natural Resources - Subcommittee on Federal Lands

Name: Justice for Black Farmers Act of 2023
Summary:
The Justice for Black Farmers Act will reform the U.S. Department of Agriculture, including by creating an independent civil rights oversight board, provide debt relief and create a land grant program and a Farm Conservation Corps to encourage a new generation of Black farmers. 

Sec. 201(3) defines training, as supported through the Act, as providing ""basic skills to operate a farm or ranch profitably with a primary focus on regenerating the soil, ecosystem, and local community"".

The Act substantially increases funding for USDA technical assistance and for programs such as the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP), which compensates farmers and ranchers for practices that build soil health such as crop rotation, cover cropping, reduced and no till, and rotational grazing; and gives priority for these programs, as well as increased access to capital, to all socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers.

Name: Meat and Poultry Special Investigator Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill establishes within the Department of Agriculture (USDA) the Office of the Special Investigator for Competition Matters, which would be comprised of a team of investigators, with subpoena power, responsible for targeting and preventing anti-competitive practices amongst entities in the meat and poultry industries.

Specifically, the office must use all available tools (e.g., subpoenas) to investigate and prosecute violations of the Packers and Stockyards Act of 1921 by packers and live poultry dealers. Further, the bill grants the office the authority to bring any civil or administrative action authorized by that act against a packer or live poultry dealer.

Additionally, the office must:
- serve as a liaison to the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission with respect to competition and trade practices in the food and agricultural sector,
- consult with the Department of Homeland Security on national security and critical infrastructure security in the food and agricultural sector,
- maintain a staff of attorneys and other professionals with appropriate expertise, and
- coordinate with the USDA Office of the General Counsel and the Packers and Stockyards Division of the Agricultural Marketing Service.

Name: Strengthening Local Processing Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill aims to support small and very small meat and poultry processing establishments by:

Increasing the federal share of costs for state inspection from 50 to 65 percent and for Cooperative Interstate Shipment (CIS) facilities from 60 to 80 percent.

Creating a competitive grant program for small and very small establishments, state inspected facilities, custom exempt facilities, or new small-scale slaughter facilities to help increase processing capacity and grow resiliency (funded at $20 million per year).

Creating two new grant programs for meat processing workforce training – one for colleges, universities, nonprofits, worker training centers, and others to establish or expand meat processing training program (funded at $15 million), and one for small and very small establishments or nongovernmental organizations to offset the cost of training new meat processors (funded at $10 million).

Establishing a searchable database of peer-reviewed validation studies for use in developing Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (HACCP) plans for smaller and very small establishments.

Reintroduction of [[H.R. 1258 https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/1258/text]]
Support: Pingree [[Press Release https://pingree.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=4484]]
Analysis:
The bill aims to support small and very small meat processors, and to increase competition in the meat processing industry. From Pingree's press release: "Under federal law, farmers or ranchers must send their animals to one of a limited number of U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) or state-inspected slaughterhouses in order to sell individual cuts of locally raised meats. These slaughterhouses are sometimes hundreds of miles away and there are far too few of them across the nation. As a result, many smaller meat and poultry processing plants are booked out for months, and small farms are unable meet new demand due to a lack of processing capacity."

This could benefit regenerative livestock producers and those looking to sell their products locally and regionally. 

Smaller establishments are those with between 10 and 500 employees, and very small establishments are those with fewer than 10 employees or annual sales of less than $2.5 million.

Increasing the federal cost share for state facility inspections and for Cooperative Interstate Shipment (CIS) facilities aims to encourage more states to operate state inspection programs and participate in CIS. There are currently 27 states that operate a state inspection program and eight states that participate in CIS. 

New in this version of the Act: SEC. 2 (HACCP resources) adds a point on Data Confidentiality, clarifying that "the Secretary shall not publish confidential business information, including a Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points plan of an establishment.”; SEC. 5 (the "Processing Resilience Grant Program") gives priority for these grants to "businesses owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals" (while it was "minority-owned businesses" in the last version of the bill; and makes the purpose of grants under the Processing Resilience Grant Program "to increase resiliency and diversification of the meat processing system" (rather than only for activities aimed at responding and recovering from the effects of COVID-19, as in the last version of the bill); and increases the funding for the Processing Resilience Grant Program from $15 to $20 million.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Ann Kuster (D-NH-2), Rep. Mike Levin (D-CA-49), Rep. Jill Tokuda (D-HI-2)

Establishing a searchable database of peer-reviewed validation studies for use in developing Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (HACCP) plans for smaller and very small establishments.

Support:
The bill is supported by the South Dakota Farm Bureau, the U.S. Cattlemen’s Association, the South Dakota Cattlemen’s Association, the South Dakota Stockgrowers Association, and the National Bison Association. See statements of support [[here https://www.thune.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/7dd603fb-e2f0-44ad-9425-4ef4463edc26/DBA2991008EE7B1DD9B43653149303B7.strengthening-local-processing-act.pdf]]

Thune [[Press Release https://www.thune.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?ID=DF299318-D2AD-4850-BABA-C36BB5CD20E4]]
Analysis:
The bill aims to support small and very small meat processors, and to increase competition in the meat processing industry. From Pingree's press release: "Under federal law, farmers or ranchers must send their animals to one of a limited number of U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) or state-inspected slaughterhouses in order to sell individual cuts of locally raised meats. These slaughterhouses are sometimes hundreds of miles away and there are far too few of them across the nation. As a result, many smaller meat and poultry processing plants are booked out for months, and small farms are unable meet new demand due to a lack of processing capacity."

This could benefit regenerative livestock producers and those looking to sell their products locally and regionally. 

Smaller establishments are those with between 10 and 500 employees, and very small establishments are those with fewer than 10 employees or annual sales of less than $2.5 million.

Increasing the federal cost share for state facility inspections and for Cooperative Interstate Shipment (CIS) facilities aims to encourage more states to operate state inspection programs and participate in CIS. There are currently 27 states that operate a state inspection program and eight states that participate in CIS. 

New in this version of the Act: SEC. 2 (HACCP resources) adds a point on Data Confidentiality, clarifying that "the Secretary shall not publish confidential business information, including a Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points plan of an establishment.”; SEC. 5 (the "Processing Resilience Grant Program") gives priority for these grants to "businesses owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals" (while it was "minority-owned businesses" in the last version of the bill; and makes the purpose of grants under the Processing Resilience Grant Program "to increase resiliency and diversification of the meat processing system" (rather than only for activities aimed at responding and recovering from the effects of COVID-19, as in the last version of the bill); and increases the funding for the Processing Resilience Grant Program from $15 to $20 million.
