Name: Cattle Price Discovery and Transparency Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill would:

Require the Secretary of Agriculture to establish 5-7 regions encompassing the entire continental U.S. (that reasonably reflect similar fed cattle purchases) and then establish minimum levels of fed cattle purchases made through approved pricing mechanisms. Approved pricing mechanisms are fed cattle purchases made through negotiated cash, negotiated grid, at a stockyard and through trading systems that multiple buyers and sellers regularly can make and accept bids.

Require USDA to set minimum levels of purchases through approved pricing mechanisms that covered packers – those controlling five percent of more of fed cattle slaughter – must make.

Include provisions to create a publicly available "cattle contract library" of marketing contracts, mandating boxed beef reporting to ensure transparency, expediting the reporting of cattle carcass weights, and requiring a packer to report the number of cattle scheduled to be delivered for slaughter each day for the next 14 days. The contract library would be permanently authorized and specify key details about the contents that must be included in the library – like the duration and other provisions in the contract that may impact price such as schedules, premiums, discounts, and transportation arrangements.

Mandate that each regional mandatory minimum be not less than the average of that region’s negotiated trade for the two year period of 2020-2021. Additionally, sets a maximum threshold for any region at 50 percent. Require USDA to conduct an initial review of mandatory minimums after two years. Allow USDA to work with the cattle and beef industry to periodically review and modify regional minimums after a public notice and comment period.

See [[one-page summary https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/8251ceae-b1b8-4f61-a617-a337f56dda08/3.28.22---acattle-market-transparency-one-pager-updated-6-.pdf]] and [[section-by-section summary https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/20e5a458-c8f9-4af1-90a2-c901aba51fd7/2.1.23---cattle-market-transparency-summary---section-by-section-updated-1-9-.pdf]]
Support:
The bill received supportive quotes from the Nebraska Farmers Union, Nebraska Cattlemen, Nebraska Farm Bureau Federation, U.S. Cattlemen’s Association, and National Farmers Union.

Fischer [[Press Release https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/news?ID=749A99FB-04C8-4400-A296-E91A19EAB874]]
Analysis:
This bill could support small and regenerative livestock producers through improved transparency in cattle markets.

From [[one-pager https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/8251ceae-b1b8-4f61-a617-a337f56dda08/3.28.22---acattle-market-transparency-one-pager-updated-6-.pdf]]: 

"A significant challenge facing the cattle industry is the declining number of participants in the negotiated cash market. In order to have robust price discovery that provides accurate information about market dynamics along the supply chain, you need a competitive cash
market with multiple price discovery points. Negotiated trade, also called the “cash” or “spot” market increasingly has been replaced by formula pricing, forward contracts, and longer-term marketing agreements—collectively referred to as “alternative marketing
arrangements” (AMAs).

Negotiated transactions involve a bid and ask process. The negotiated market facilitates price discovery, which is the process of establishing the “going rate” of cattle based on market conditions at any given time. Formula pricing, where a reference price from a published report is used as the base price for the transaction, is becoming more common. The bulk of formula pricing uses negotiated cash prices as the base in the formula— meaning information from the negotiated cash market is being heavily leveraged by nonparticipants, even as negotiated purchases decline in volume. 

If a packer relies on the negotiated market to set the price for a large portion of the cattle they purchase, they should actively participate in establishing the negotiated price."

Sens. Fischer, Wyden, Grassley, and Tester introduced the [[Cattle Price Discovery and Transparency Act https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/news?ID=ED39FFA4-8F1D-4211-80F9-1B4F3EBD11CA]] in March 2022. In June, the Senate Agriculture Committee [[approved https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/news?ID=2F7F6480-E5A3-4BE4-93EA-83B0D230EBA1]] the legislation, which passed by voice vote. This was an updated version of the bill that Sen. Fischer previously [[introduced https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2021/11/ischer-leads-cattle-market-price-discovery-and-transparency-bill]] in 2021.

Name: Emergency Conservation Program Improvement Act of 2023
Summary: The legislation would reform the Emergency Conservation Program (ECP) and Emergency Forest Restoration Program (EFRP) to provide producers impacted by disasters with the option to receive an up-front cost-share, based on existing USDA estimates. The bill would also adjust eligibility for relief to include any wildfire caused or spread due to natural causes, as well as wildfires caused by the federal government. In other words, the bill increases the amount of funding available for the ECP, expands the types of activities that can be funded by the ECP, and streamlines farmer access to the program.
Support: N/A
Analysis:
This bill aims to improve Emergency Conservation Program (ECP)'s effectiveness in providing assistance to farmers and ranchers who have been affected by natural disasters.

Background: The ECP is a federal program that provides financial assistance to farmers and ranchers who have been affected by natural disasters. The program provides funding for a variety of activities, including: repairing damaged fences and irrigation systems, planting cover crops, removing dead or dying trees, providing emergency grazing for livestock. USDA found that the ECP has helped to provide over $2 billion in assistance to farmers and ranchers since 2008, and that the ECP has helped to save over 100,000 jobs in the agricultural sector.

The bill's supporters argue that the bill would help to reduce the economic impact of natural disasters on the agricultural sector, while opponents argue that it would be too expensive and that the money could be better spent on other programs.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Ben Ray Luján (D-NM)

Name: Protect America's Children from Toxic Pesticides Act
Summary:
This bill amends the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) to fully protect the safety of children and the environment, to remove dangerous pesticides from use, and for other purposes.

Name: Conservation for Agricultural Leased Land (CALL) Act
Summary:
This bill directs the National Agricultural Statistics Service of the Department of Agriculture to carry out a study and make recommendations regarding conservation practices on leased agricultural land.

The study must (1) address issues such as participation in conservation programs and barriers to adopting conservation practices; and (2) be carried out with particular consideration of farmers and ranchers who are people of color, including Black and indigenous farmers and ranchers, and beginning farmers and ranchers.

Reintroduction of [[H.R. 2756 https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/2756/text]] from the 117th Congress.
Support:
The bill is supported by American Farmland Trust, Environmental Defense Fund, and the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition. 

Brownley [[Press Release https://juliabrownley.house.gov/brownley-introduces-legislation-to-improve-conservation-practices-in-agriculture/]]
Analysis:
Today about 40% of U.S. working lands (53% of croplands and 28% of rangelands) are operated by tenant farmers/ranchers, who currently have little or no direct economic incentive to improve the health of our soils as the benefits of regenerative agriculture are longer term and felt little over the average, one-year term of a land lease. This bill seeks to better understand the range of factors limiting landowners and tenants from adopting conservation practices on the land that they own or manage, and from participating in Federal, State, and local conservation programs.

The Select Committee on the Climate Crisis’s Congressional Action Plan recommended this action to improve federal conservation programs.

Name: Climate Agricultural Conservation Practices Act
Summary: This bill requires the Natural Resources Conservation Service within the Department of Agriculture to consider climate benefits, such as reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, in reviews or revisions of its conservation practice standards. (These standards provide guidance and set out minimum quality criteria for implementing federally funded conservation practices.)
Support:

Brownley [[Press Release https://juliabrownley.house.gov/brownley-introduces-legislation-to-improve-conservation-practices-in-agriculture/]]
Analysis:
"While it is acknowledged that many of the currently approved conservation practices, such as cover cropping or no-till farming, also have climate benefits (such as reducing GHG emissions, sequestering carbon, or mitigating or adapting to the impacts of extreme weather), NRCS does not directly consider climate benefits when developing their list of approved standards. By making the linkage between such conservation practices and climate benefits, this bill could help to ensure that the full range of benefits of adopting conservation practices is addressed in NRCS programs, resulting in more comprehensive and responsive support for farmers' and ranchers' specific conservation goals and management plans.

This improvement to NRCS conservation programs was also a recommendation made by the Select Committee on the Climate Crisis’s Congressional Action Plan."

Name: Zero Food Waste Act
Summary:
This bill directs the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish a grant program to study and reduce food waste.

The program includes planning grants, measurement grants, and reduction grants. Activities under the grant program could include studies on food waste generation and food waste management planning, data and reports, preventing food waste, redirecting surplus food for consumption, upcycling and recycling. 

Grants for anaerobic digestion projects must use animal waste for no more than 20% of the feedstock, and only use source-separate organics for the remainder; and submit a plan for end-product recycling to provide for the use of the material resultnig from the project as a soil amendment. 

Eligible entities are States, local governments, territorial governments, nonprofits and Tribal governments.

The program prioritizes diverse locations and uses, with a focus on communities of color, low-income communities, and Tribal communities that have been disproportionately affected by adverse human health or environmental effects.

The Act authorizes $650 million for each of fiscal years 2023 through 2032 to carry out this grant program.
Support:
The bill received supportive quotes from ReFED, the World Wildlife Fund, and Unilever. 

Brownley [[Press Release https://juliabrownley.house.gov/brownley-kuster-pingree-booker-introduce-legislation-to-incentivize-sustainable-practices-and-reduce-food-waste/]]
Analysis:
The potential impact of the 'anerobic digestion' section on soil health is significant if properly implemented. The proposed bill mandates a comprehensive plan for recycling the end-products of anaerobic digestion projects, with the aim of utilizing the resulting material as a soil amendment. This amendment, commonly referred to as digestate and akin to compost, has the potential to provide a substantial quantity of cost-effective compost. Such a development would greatly assist producers in enhancing soil quality and fertility.

The bill could open other opportunities for the production of higher-quality compost from waste diversion.

According to the press release: "In the U.S., nearly half of all food produced is lost or wasted, which means an estimated $408 billion is spent on growing, processing, transporting, storing, and disposing of food that is never consumed. Landfills are now the third-largest source of methane in the U.S., and food is the single largest input by weight in our landfills and incinerators."

Grants for anaerobic digestion projects must use animal waste for no more than 20% of the feedstock, and only use source-separate organics for the remainder; and submit a plan for end-product recycling to provide for the use of the material resultnig from the project as a soil amendment. 

Eligible entities are States, local governments, territorial governments, nonprofits and Tribal governments.

The program prioritizes diverse locations and uses, with a focus on communities of color, low-income communities, and Tribal communities that have been disproportionately affected by adverse human health or environmental effects.

The Act authorizes $650 million for each of fiscal years 2023 through 2032 to carry out this grant program.
Support:
The bill received supportive quotes from ReFED, the World Wildlife Fund, and Unilever. 

Booker [[Press Release https://www.booker.senate.gov/news/press/booker-smith-brownley-kuster-pingree-introduce-bicameral-legislation-to-incentivize-sustainable-practices-and-reduce-food-waste]]
Analysis:
The potential impact of the 'anerobic digestion' section on soil health is significant if properly implemented. The proposed bill mandates a comprehensive plan for recycling the end-products of anaerobic digestion projects, with the aim of utilizing the resulting material as a soil amendment. This amendment, commonly referred to as digestate and akin to compost, has the potential to provide a substantial quantity of cost-effective compost. Such a development would greatly assist producers in enhancing soil quality and fertility.

The bill could open other opportunities for the production of higher-quality compost from waste diversion.

According to the press release: "In the U.S., nearly half of all food produced is lost or wasted, which means an estimated $408 billion is spent on growing, processing, transporting, storing, and disposing of food that is never consumed. Landfills are now the third-largest source of methane in the U.S., and food is the single largest input by weight in our landfills and incinerators."

Name: Cultivating Organic Matter through the Promotion Of Sustainable Techniques (COMPOST) Act
Summary:
This bill directs USDA to designate composting as a conservation practice and a conservation activity, add composting as an eligible practice under the Conservation Stewardship Program and Environmental Quality Incentives Program, and develop a composting practice standard. The bill would also establish a program to award grants and loan guarantees for projects that expand access to food waste composting.

The bill authorizes $200 million per year to be appropriated to carry out the grant and loan guarantee program

Reintroduction of [[H.R.4443 https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/4443/text]] - COMPOST Act of 2021
Support:
This bill is supported by the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition (NSAC), US Composting Council, Institute for Local Self-Reliance, US Green Building Council, Harvard Food Law and Policy Center, Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC), and others.

Brownley [[Press Release https://juliabrownley.house.gov/brownley-kuster-pingree-booker-introduce-legislation-to-incentivize-sustainable-practices-and-reduce-food-waste/]]
Analysis:
By designating composting as a conservation practice, this bill would enable farmers who produce and utilize compost to receive financial support and technical assistance through the Farm Bill's conservation programs, such as the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP) and the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP). This, in turn, would increase the use of compost and improve soil health outcomes on farms, resulting in increased production and quality. 

This bill would increase the demand for compost, which would not only be a source of potential revenue for urban producers of compost from city food waste, but would also encourage municipal waste diversion from urban centers, create new jobs, reduce emissions from landfills, and bridge the urban-rural divide.

Although it seems clear that the NRCS could/should just make a determination to add composting as a conservation practice without congressional intervention, this bill is likely responding to the fact that they have not yet and is attempting to require them to do so.

There is an existing NRCS practice that covers the building of compost facilities, but does not address the actual application of compost for soil health, nutrient management, resilience, water quality, etc. Some of the language from the bill may be useful to take directly to NRCS to advocate for broader compost use policies. 

The bill would create new USDA grant and loan guarantee programs and authorize $2 billion over 10 years for composting infrastructure projects, including both large-scale composting facilities as well as farm, home, or community-based projects.

Name: Earth Act to Stop Climate Pollution by 2030

Name: Agriculture Innovation Act of 2023
Summary:
The Agriculture Innovation Act would direct the Secretary of Agriculture to identify, collect, link, and analyze data relating to the impacts of covered conservation and other production practices on enhancing crop yields, soil health, and ecosystem services, reducing risk, and improving farm, ranch, and other working land profitability.

It would also allow the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a secure, confidential cloud-based conservation and farm productivity data center to store operational, transactional, and administrative program databases and records that support business, statistical, and other analysis.

The bill directs USDA to use research, analysis, and evaluation products derived from enhanced data to provide technical assistance to farmers and improve farm program implementation. 

Identical to [[S.4189 https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/senate-bill/98/text]] - Agriculture Innovation Act of 2022. Also builds on the Agriculture Data Act of 2018 ([[S.2487 https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/senate-bill/2487/text]]), parts of which passed in the 2018 Farm Bill (authorizing USDA to identify existing datasets on conservation practices, and producing a summary report to the House Ag Committee).
Support:
The legislation has been endorsed by the National Corn Growers Association, Theodore Roosevelt Conservation Partnership, Natural Resources Defense Council, AGree Coalition, Ducks Unlimited, BPC Action, National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition, Pheasants Forever, American Farmland Trust, Environmental Defense Fund, American Sportfishing Association, Backcountry Hunters & Anglers, Izaak Walton League of America, the National Wildlife Federation, American Fly Fishing Trade Association, American Woodcock Association, Angler Action Foundation, Archery Trade Association, Danone North America, Mishra and Roznik, Arizona State University Morrison School of Agribusiness, National Deer Association, Quail Forever, Ruffed Grouse Society, Supporters of Agriculture Research, Unilever United States, and the Wildlife Management Institute.

[[Klobuchar Press Release https://www.klobuchar.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2023/1/klobuchar-thune-introduce-bipartisan-legislation-to-connect-farmers-with-most-effective-conservation-practices]]
Analysis:
The bill direct USDA to conduct research on the impacts of conservation practices on crop yields, soil health, ecosystem services, and profitability (using the analyzed data), and it also directs USDA to use the results of this research to improve the implementation of USDA programs (Sec 2).

The act would make a large amount of data publicly available; see Sec. 2 added Sec. 1248 (c) (10) "Promptly make available on the public-facing component of the secure data center established under paragraph (6) the research, analysis, evaluation products, and other information generated in carrying out this section"). 

The bill addresses data confidentiality and security (Sec. 2, (d) (2) REQUIREMENT TO MODERNIZE DATA SECURITY, STORAGE, AND ACCESS.), which is a concern for many farmers.

This bill could make a significant impact on research and development, especially for new quantification tools associated with agriculture, and specifically soil health.

While farmers would only benefit directly from the incentives offered to share their data, they would hopefully also benefit indirectly through the development of tools that would be facilitated by the increased availability of data (e.g. tools to quantify risk, or efficiency of practices etc...). However, the public availability of such a significant amount of data could potentially devalue the data of an individual farmer because the annonimized, aggregated data would be widely avaialble. 

Features of the bill: 
→ Expands the scope of the legislation beyond “conservation practices” to include all production practices.
→ Expands the “purpose” of the bill to include support for the development of ecosystem markets. 
→ Authorizes the Secretary to provide incentives to producers to share data.
→ Authorizes the Secretary to use existing funds and authorities to carry out the legislation.
→ Adds the Department of Agriculture’s Chief Data Officer as a coordinating position for carrying out the activities outlined in the legislation.
→ Explicitly links the collection and identification of relevant USDA data sets to the evidence building plan required by the Evidence Act.
→ Replaces the term “data warehouse” with “data center” to better convey the intent.
→ Requires the Secretary to periodically consult with experts and stakeholders to consider necessary modifications to security and confidentiality protections.
Cosponsors (R): Sen. John Thune (R-SD)

Name: Beginning Agriculturalist Lifetime Employment (BALE) Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill revises the limits for the USDA conservation loan guarantee program. 

The bill replaces the existing 80% limit on the portion of a loan that USDA may guarantee with limits that range from 80%-90%, depending on the principal amount of the loan.

Increases lending caps on conservation, ownership and operator loans from $1.75 million (as authorized in the 2018 Farm Bill) to $3 million.

For socially disadvantaged or beginning farmers or ranchers, the bill replaces the existing 90% limit with limits that range from 85%-95%, depending on the principal amount of the loan.

The bill also (1) prohibits USDA from guaranteeing a loan under the program that exceeds $4 million, and (2) requires USDA to adjust the limits annually for inflation.

Applicable to all FSA conservation, ownership, and operating guaranteed loans.

Name: Butcher Block Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill authorizes USDA to make (or guarantee) loans and award grants for establishing, expanding, and otherwise supporting livestock and poultry processing and related activities.

In awarding grants and making or guaranteeing loans, USDA shall prioritize applicants that have experience in livestock and poultry processing and can quickly scale-up to increase overall processing capacity in the region involved.

The bill authorizes $20 million annually to carry out the program.

The bill is aimed at increasing competition in the cattle market by improving access to meat processing grants for small processors.

According to a 2021 Rabobank report, an additional daily packing capacity of 5,000 to 6,000 head of fed cattle could restore the historical balance of fed cattle supplies and packing capacity.

In a video discussing the bill, cosponsor Rep Spanberger addresses the fact that cattle producers' share of retail value for beef has decreased from more than 51% in 2015 to less than 37% in 2021, while meat prices are up 13% over the last year.

Following the introduction of the legislation, in July 2021, USDA announced its intent to provide $500 million in grants to expand meat and poultry processing capacity. Following this announcement, a press release from Rep Johnson's office stated: "As USDA continues to finalize details of the program, Johnson will continue to push USDA to design a program that is scalable and can quickly add processing capacity while incentivizing producer investment." These grants mirror the Act.

The text of the 117th Congress version of the Butcher Block Act was included in H.R.7606 - Lower Food and Fuel Costs Act - which passed in the House on June 16, 2022.

Name: Qualified Agricultural Carbon Sequestration Act of 2022
Summary:
This bills establishes a tax credit to incentivize the abatement and sequestration of carbon dioxide (CO2) through agricultural methods. The bill includes three types of credits - CO2 equivalent abatement credit, CO2 equivalent sequestration credit, and early adopter credit.

Establishes a program at USDA to certify farms as qualifying for the tax credits (outlining a set of criteria/principles by which to measure carbon dioxide equivalent abatement and sequestration), and approve independent GHG crediting programs to conduct monitoring/verification.
Analysis:
A tax credit could be an effective mechanism for incentivizing farmers to adopt certain agricultural management practices.

The proposal calculates the abatement credit based on changes in CO2 equivalent emissions in a year compared to a baseline year, while the sequestration credit is calculated based on a percentage of the "applicable dollar amount" per metric ton of carbon sequestered, and the early adopter credit based on soil organic carbon stored in the farm's soil compared to the county average.

Focuses singularly on CO2 instead of rewarding a broader scope of ecosystem services provided by beneficial agricultural management practices (such as water quality, biodiversity, other soil health metrics, etc).

Name: Biochar Research Network Act of 2022
Summary:
This bill directs USDA to establish a national biochar research network of not more than 20 research sites to test a range of biochar types "across soil types, soil conditions, application methods, and climatic and agronomic regions", including to assess soil carbon sequestration potential, understand how to use biochar for ecosystem health, resilience, and conservation, and deliver information to producers on biochar production and application.

Eligible entities are State agricultural or forestry experiment stations, research facilities of the Agricultural Research Service, the Forest Service, or any other agency of the Department of Agriculture that the Secretary determines is appropriate, or research facilities of the Department of Energy, the Department of Commerce, or the Department of the Interior.

$50,000,000 is appropriated annually from 2023 through 2028.
Analysis:
Biochar, a charcoal-like substance made by burning excess organic material from agricultural and forestry wastes (biomass) through pyrolysis, with reserch indicating that it can be applied to soils to improve soil health, improve soil fertility, and sequester carbon. 

The bill explicitly focuses on researching interactions between biochar and soil health. 

Useful framing in the section (Sec 2 - Sec 403(A)(b)(2)(f)) that requires research to be shared with producers and technical assistance providers on "the most advantageous ways to use biochar to increase profitability, raise productivity, lower costs, improve soil and plant health, and enhance resilience to extreme weather events while contributing to carbon sequestration and greenhouse gas reductions". 

The research generated as a result could help bring the cost of biochar down in order to make it more economically viable for use by agricultural producers and forest landowners. 

A focus shuld be placed on researching the sourcing of biomass from already dead/dying material or that culled from post fire areas to help in the sustainability of biochar production.

Name: Natural Infrastructure Act of 2022
Summary:
This bill directs the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a joint natural infrastructure science program that would work closely with educational institutions to produce research about natural infrastructure. It also directs the Secretary of Interior to assess the costs and effectiveness of at least 30 natural infrastructure projects per year. 

Authorizes $4 million per year through 2026.
Analysis:
The term “natural infrastructure” is defined as "constructed landscape features and systems that employ nature-based solutions that promote, use, restore, or emulate natural ecological processes." This creates an opportunity to generate research and data on building soil health as a key component of restoring natural ecological processes.

The program's "stakeholder advisory group" includes: a rep of local government, a developer, a rep of a construction association or company, a civil or environmental engineer, a researcher, a Tribal member, and an environmental scientist. The bill sponsors may consider adding a soil scientist or agroecologist to the membership requirements, to ensure needs and potential resilience benefits with respect to soil's properties as natural infrastructure are addressed.
Agencies: Department of the Interior; US Dept of Agriculture (in particular the Forest Service)

Name: Civilian Conservation Center Enhancement Act of 2022
Summary:
This bill directs the Secretaries of Agriculture and Interior, in coordination with the Secretary of Labor, to offer specialized training programs at Civilian Conservation Centers on (1) forestry and rangeland management, (2) wildland firefighting; or (3) any other topic relating to the mission of the Forest Service or the Department of the Interior or the public interest.

It also authorizes the Secretaries to carry out pilots "to provide career and technical education curricula and course offerings to advance the missions of the Department of the Interior and the Department of Agriculture at Civilian Conservation Centers". 

The bill also includes some other provisions to encourage hiring and employment of wildland firefighters, and calls for a report to Congress on maximizing the capacity of Civilian Conservation Centers.
Analysis: The curricula and courses offered through the Wildland Firefighting Workforce Development Pilot include not only forest management and restoration activities, but also watershed and habitat enhancement, range management, and other areas, making this an opportunity to introduce a focus on soil health as a means of building resilience to and managing wildfires, particularly by increasing water infiltration rates, recharging water tables, and reducing fuel load (through carefully managed grazing and browsing).

Analysis: Could create an opportunity for regenerative land management initiatives, especially for grazing, on public lands.

Name: Agricultural Management Assistance Modernization Act of 2022
Summary:
Updates the NIFA Agriculture Risk Management Education Partnerships Program (ARME), which provides competitive grants for risk management education for producers, by adding nonprofit organizations to the list of eligible entities for grants; allowing these grants to be used to educate approved crop insurance providers (in addition to producers), "especially with respect to the availability of whole farm insurance plans"; adding language translation services to technical assistance; and adding food safety to the list of topics covered. 

Adds to the list of eligible activities for financial assistance for risk management through RMA's Risk Management Education Partnership Program, the following: soil health improvements; perennial crop establishment, including establishment of agroforestry systems; integration of livestock; aerobic composting of crop and livestock waste; or other conservation practices determined by the Secretary to reduce farms’ risk of financial loss due to the regional impacts of climate change; marketing including of value-added processing; establishing market infrastructure to support enterprise diversification, e.g. drying and storage facilities.

Provides $30 million annually from CCC funds (up from the current $10 million), and makes an additional one-time $20 million available.
Analysis:
Recognizes soil health as a risk management strategy, and specifically calls out and funds some important components of soil health systems, including livestock integration, perennial crops, and agroforestry. 

Addresses the need for markets and infrastructure to support getting soil health-focused products to market. Access to local infrastructure and markets a major need and the lack of these components present a risk as it relates to transitioning to soil health systems.

Making nonprofits eligible for the funding is useful as there are many nonprofits that act as the primary technical assistance points of contact for producers. This can especially serve historically underserved producers well. There is a large unmet need for language translation in the delivery of federal education and technical assistance programs. 

Triples the annual funding for ARME.

Context: This bill makes updates to the Agriculture Risk Management Education Partnerships Program (ARME), which is a competitive grant program of NIFA. The 2018 Farm Bill reauthorized ARME, merged it with RMA's Crop Insurance Education in Targeted States Program, and provided $10 million in mandatory funding for the new merged program (previously, $5 was allocated to the ERME). These funds are distributed through the 4 regional ERME centers across the country (as well as the 1 digital center).
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Ed Case (D-HI-1)
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on General Farm Commodities and Risk Management

Name: Small Family Farmer and Rancher Relief Act
Summary:
This bill has two main components that aim to support the viability of small cattle ranchers: 

1. Strengthening the safety net for small cattle ranchers, as follows: Increase the premium subsidy within the Livestock Risk Protection insurance program (LRP) for ranchers who market 100 or less head of cattle per year; Create the Beef Cattle Spread Coverage Program, an indemnity program administered by the Farm Service Agency (FSA) that provides relief to small producers when the farmer’s share of the retail dollar drops below 51.7 percent; and Provide resources to RMA and FSA to educate producers and insurance agents on the utility of the livestock insurance programs and the safety net program.

2. Increase competition and market access for small cattle ranchers, as follows: Create a Small Rancher Market Access competitive grant program. Administered by the Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS), this program will help small producers, cooperatives of small producers, or other eligible organizations aggregate, add value, and market meat and meat products to local and regional markets with a focus on direct-to-consumer and direct-to-institution sales; and Provide AMS with resources to educate farmers on how to best apply for and leverage these new programs.
Support: [[Press Release https://davidscott.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=399771]]
Analysis:
Lack of access to local markets for small and regenerative producers prevents the opportunity to increase net farm or ranch profitability and keep more food dollars inside local economies. Increasing access could also allow more farmers to integrate regeneratively managed livestock into their cropping systems. This bill could help increase profitability and inject more competition into the supply chain, supporting the viability of regenerative ranchers.

The Beef Spread Coverage Program should provide small producers with protection against significant swings in the difference between cattle prices, wholesale beef prices, and retail prices. This could support the economic viability of regenerative producers.

Eligible entities for the "Small Rancher Market Access" program would include groups of small cattle producers (average of 100 head or fewer) cooperatives with a majority of members under a certain size, non-profits or Land Grant Universities with experience working with small sized cattle producers, Tribal governments, food hubs, or CSAs. The program eligibility would prioritize underserved and limited resource producers.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Alma Adams (D-NC-12)

Name: Biochar Research Network Act of 2022
Summary:
This bill directs USDA to establish a national biochar research network of not more than 20 research sites to test a range of biochar types "across soil types, soil conditions, application methods, and climatic and agronomic regions", including to assess soil carbon sequestration potential, understand how to use biochar for ecosystem health, resilience, and conservation, and deliver information to producers on biochar production and application.

Eligible entities are State agricultural or forestry experiment stations, research facilities of the Agricultural Research Service, the Forest Service, or any other agency of the Department of Agriculture that the Secretary determines is appropriate, or research facilities of the Department of Energy, the Department of Commerce, or the Department of the Interior.

$50,000,000 is appropriated annually from 2023 through 2028.
Analysis:
Biochar, a charcoal-like substance made by burning excess organic material from agricultural and forestry wastes (biomass) through pyrolysis, with reserch indicating that it can be applied to soils to improve soil health, improve soil fertility, and sequester carbon. 

The bill explicitly focuses on researching interactions between biochar and soil health. 

Useful framing in the section (Sec 2 - Sec 403(A)(b)(2)(f)) that requires research to be shared with producers and technical assistance providers on "the most advantageous ways to use biochar to increase profitability, raise productivity, lower costs, improve soil and plant health, and enhance resilience to extreme weather events while contributing to carbon sequestration and greenhouse gas reductions". 

The research generated as a result could help bring the cost of biochar down in order to make it more economically viable for use by agricultural producers and forest landowners. 

A focus shuld be placed on researching the sourcing of biomass from already dead/dying material or that culled from post fire areas to help in the sustainability of biochar production.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Chellie Pingree (D-ME-1), Rep. Jimmy Panetta (D-CA-20), Rep. Ann Kuster (D-NH-2), Rep. Kim Schrier (D-WA-8)
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Randy Feenstra (R-IA-4)
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Biotechnology, Horticulture, and Research

Name: Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2023
Summary: The Senate version of the FY23 ag appropriations bill allocates $27.1 billion in total funding (a $2.3 billion increase over last year, but $350 million short of what the White House requested). In total discretionary and mandatory spending, the bill has a price tag of $195 billion. Name: North American Grasslands Conservation Act
Summary:
This bill would: Establish a North American Grassland Conservation Strategy for the protection, restoration, and management of grassland ecosystems across North America; Establish a Grassland Conservation Grant Program for voluntary, incentive-based conservation of grasslands, including projects to restore degraded grasslands, increase carbon sequestration, improve grassland and rangeland health, mitigate the threats of wildfire and drought, improve biodiversity and support habitat connectivity, and restore watersheds; Create National and Regional Grassland Conservation Councils to recommend and approve grassland conservation projects to be funded under the grant program; and Establish research initiatives on native seed crop systems and regenerative grazing practices.

See [[section-by-section summary https://www.wyden.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/The%20North%20American%20Grasslands%20Conservation%20Act%20Section%20by%20Section%20Final.pdf]].
Support:
The legislation is endorsed by: National Wildlife Federation, Pheasants Forever/Quail Forever, North American Grouse Partnership, National Deer Association, First Nations Development Institute, World Wildlife Fund, Buffalo Nations Grasslands Alliance, National Bobwhite & Grassland Initiative, Theodore Roosevelt Conservation Partnership, Backcountry Hunters & Anglers, Native American Fish and Wildlife Association, Bird Conservancy of the Rockies, Izaak Walton League of America, American Bird Conservancy, Land Trust Alliance, Southeastern Grasslands Initiative, Colorado Wildlife Federation, Missouri Prairie Foundation, North Dakota Wildlife Federation, Tennessee Wildlife Federation, Idaho Wildlife Federation, Minnesota Conservation Federation, Minnesota Prairie Chicken Society, Minnesota Sharp-tailed Grouse Society, Montana Wildlife Federation, and South Dakota Wildlife Federation. See [[Act for Grasslands https://actforgrasslands.org/]] coalition.

[[Press Release https://www.wyden.senate.gov/news/press-releases/wyden-introduces-legislation-to-restore-americas-grasslands]]
Analysis:
According to the bill, grasslands cover 358,000,000 acres of the United States, 85 percent of which are privately owned and serve as an important habitat for 29 breeding obligate grassland bird species. 

According to WWF, "Pressure to convert grasslands for agriculture or other uses contributed to the loss of some 2.6 million acres across the US and Canadian portions of the Great Plains from 2018-2019 alone."

Establishes a competitive grant program under the Department of Interior (DOI) that provides grants to eligible entities (a grazing land coalition, an ag or livestock producer group, an Indian Tribe, a land trust, a State or local gov't, a Federal land management agency, an NGO or community-based org, or a group of individual private landowners) to conduct grasslands conservation and restoration projects. Funds can be used for voluntary conservation easements, restoration and management activities (including advanced grazing management), and "ecosystem education, outreach, and conservation stewardship assistance". Includes a 10% set aside for Tribes and Tribal organizations. Requires at least 25% match. Up to 10% of funds can be used for assisting grasslands conservation projects in Canada and Mexico.

Voluntary, incentive-based programs tend to be well-received.

Under Sec. 10, "Regenerative grazing data collection", the bill directs research to be conducted on "a standard set of practices...that support conservation and grazing goals" as well as the potential of grazing to improve soil health, increase carbon sequestration, reduce wildfire risk, and improve watershed resilience and biodiversity. 

The bill provides $290 million for the grant program annually through 2026, as well as $10 million for the regenerative grazing research annually through 2024.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Michael Bennet (D-CO), Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-MN)

Name: Conservation Opportunity and Voluntary Environment Resilience Program (COVER) Act
Summary:
This bill would help producers maintain cover crop systems by establishing the Good Steward Cover Crop Program to provide producers a $5 per acre premium subsidy when they enroll in a covered insurance program and plant cover crops for conservation purposes. This program will be fully voluntary and not require farmers to plant cover crops in order to be eligible for crop insurance.

Authorizes additional funding for technical assistance: Reserves $5 million for technical assistance, outreach, and program support to help producers access the Good Steward Cover Crop Program. 

Creates a Soil Health Pilot Program: Authorizes USDA to evaluate how additional premium subsidies can be offered for other soil health practices that reduce risk and comply with the goals of the FCIP.
Support:
The bill is supported by the Illinois Farm Bureau, Practical Farmers of Iowa, Danone, Unilever, Natural Resources Defense Council, American Farmland Trust,National Wildlife Federation, Green Cover Seed, Practical Farmers of Iowa, Izaak Walton League of America, Iowa Farmers Union, GO Seed, E2, Edge Dairy Farmer Cooperative, Farm Action Fund.

[[Press Release https://casten.house.gov/media/press-releases/casten-introduces-cover-act-support-soil-health-practices]]
Analysis:
This proposal makes the Pandemic Cover Crop Program (PCCP) permanent and available nationwide. Over 12.2 million acres were enrolled in the program pilot in 2021, representing all 48 lower states.

This is a voluntary program that would be paid for through the Commodity Credit Corporation (CCC) (not RMA). It also reserves $5 million to be used by USDA for technical assistance. 

The "Good Steward Cover Crop Program" would provide a premium subsidy amount of $5 per acre planted with qualifying cover crops (defined in accordance with NRCS guidance), and "an additional premium subsidy under paragraph (1) shall not exceed the amount of the premium owed by the producer with respect to the acres described in subsection (a)."

The bill includes directive for FSA and NRCS to carry out outreach, including through cooperative agreements with soil and water conservation districts, and other organizations capable of conducting outreach. 

Requires RMA, FSA, and NRCS to coordinate and conduct a report not 1 year after enactment of the bill on number and amount of premium subsidies provided, acres of cover crops planted, and recommendations to increase the number of producers that quality for the subsidies.

Also creates a pilot under which a producer who uses "innovative soil health practices may receive additional premium subsidies on multiperil crop insurance, as determined by the Corporation" through reinsurance arrangements with private insurance companies. Specifies that premiums must be actuarially sound.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Cynthia Axne (D-IA-3)

Name: Inflation Reduction Act
Summary:
This budget reconciliation bill would authorize nearly $370 billion in spending on energy security and climate change programs, $300 billion in deficit reduction, 3 years of Affordable Care Act subsidies, prescription drug reform, and tax reform.  The climate portion of the package includes over $20 billion for agriculture conservation.  The bill was the result of ongoing negotiations on the proposed Build Back Better Act, which had been reduced and modified from its initial proposal.

Summary from the Senate Agriculture Committee

• This bill has Democrat support.

• Press: Forbes, CNN

• See funding breakdown and analysis by NSAC, Farm Progress, or farmdoc DAILY
Analysis:
Historic funding increase for soil health and conservation. Includes nearly $20 billion for farm bill conservation programs through FY2026. This includes the following:

$8.45 billion for the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP), directing funds to be used "for 1 or more agricultural conservation practices or enhancements that the Secretary determines directly improve soil carbon or reduce nitrogen losses or greenhouse gas emissions, or capture or sequester greenhouse gas emissions, associated with agricultural production" and prioritizing projects and activities that mitigate or address climate change through the management of ag production, including by reducing or avoiding GHG emissions. The bill also removes the existing 50% funding set aside for livestock, and doubles funding for the Conservation Innovation Grants (from $25 million to $50 million).

$3.25 billion for the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP), directing that the funds shall only be available for "(I) 1 or more agricultural conservation practices or enhancements that the Secretary determines directly improve soil carbon or reduce nitrogen losses or greenhouse gas emissions, or capture or sequester greenhouse gas emissions, associated with agricultural production; or (II) State-specific or region-specific groupings or bundles of agricultural conservation activities for climate change mitigation appropriate for cropland, pastureland, rangeland, nonindustrial private forest land, and producers transitioning to organic or perennial production systems" and directs the Secretary to prioritize projects and activities that mitigate or address climate change through the management of ag production, including by reducing or avoiding GHG emissions.

$1.4 billion for the Agricultural Conservation Easement Program (ACEP), and directs the Secretary to prioritize projects and activities that mitigate or address climate change through the management of ag production, including by reducing or avoiding GHG emissions.

$4.95 billion for the Regional Conservation Partnership Program (RCPP), and directs the Secretary to prioritize partnership agreements that support the implementation of conservation projects that assist agricultural producers and forest landowners in directly improving soil carbon or reducing nitrogen losses or GHG emissions, or capturing or sequestering GHG emissions, associated with agricultural production; to prioritize projects that mitigate or address climate change; and also allows the Secretary to prioritize projects that "leverage corporate supply chain sustainability commitments, or utilize models that pay for outcomes from targeting methane and nitrous oxide emissions associated with agricultural production systems." 

Also includes $1 billion for conservation technical assistance, and $300 million for a new NRCS carbon sequestration and GHG emissions quantification program.

These investments will support farmers and ranchers across the US in building soil health, resilience & profitability, and provide a robust baseline as we head towards the 2023 Farm Bill. 

Passed by the Senate on 8/7/2022, passed by the House on 8/12/2022, became law 8/16/2022.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Joe Manchin (D-WV)

Name: Agriculture Skills Preparation for Industry Recruitment Efforts (ASPIRE) Act
Summary:
This bill directs USDA to establish an agriculture training program within the USDA’s existing Beginning Farmer and Rancher Development Program to fund participation in apprenticeship and internship programs with local agriculture businesses. 

Goals: (i) promote the growth of the agriculture industry; (ii) foster competitiveness within such industry; and (iii) improve the training and retention of workers in the agriculture industry.
Support:
The bill has been supported by The Minnesota Farm Bureau Federation and the Minnesota Farmers Union.

Smith [[Press Release https://www.smith.senate.gov/u-s-senator-smith-and-rep-emmer-introduce-legislation-investing-in-ags-next-generation/]]
Analysis:
Strategies to support young and beginning farmers are vital, with as many as 400 million acres of American farmland expected to change hands in the coming years. We need to ensure that this land not only remains in production, but that it is accessible to small, young ad beginning producers who want to farm regeneratively.

Thus there is opportunity for soil health and regenerative topics to be added to the training curricula. 

There is no funding specified in the bill.

Name: Expressing support for regenerative agriculture and other conservation practices to support more sustainable and resilient agriculture, and compensating farmers for providing environmental services.
Summary: This resolution expresses "support for regenerative agriculture and other conservation practices to support more sustainable and resilient agriculture, and compensating farmers for providing environmental services."
Analysis:
This resolution provides a comprehensive overview of the linkages between regenerative agriculture, farmer prosperity, soil health, resilience, and addressing climate change.

Resolves that the House will support programs to pay farmers to achieve environmental outcomes on a whole farm basis, using context-based practices, including paymens for ecological services for climate change mitigation and adaptation. Specifies support for USDA offices and staff to provide appropriate support to farmers. Also resolves that USDA should publish a series of related reports.

The resolution was released following the Oversight Subcommittee on Environment's hearing entitled, “Regenerative Agriculture:  How Farmers and Ranchers are Essential to Solving Climate Change and Increasing Food Production” on July 19, 2022

Name: Carbon Sequestration Collaboration Act
Summary: This bill directs the Department of Energy, the Department of Agriculture, and the Department of the Interior to conduct coordinated research to "evaluate terrestrial carbon sequestration and carbon sequestration in geologic formations".
Support: [[Press Release https://republicans-science.house.gov/press-releases?id=068AB6C7-804B-4ED2-AA8A-DC968CA13BFA]]
Analysis:
Two of the four priorities of the research are directly related to soil carbon sequestration, the results of which could justify more support for soil health programs and initiatives: 
(1) Increasing the understanding and development of permanent terrestrial carbon sequestration, including through organic soil carbon sequestration, soil carbon mineralization, artificial reforestation, and carbon mineralization utilizing mine tailings.
(3) Collecting, identifying, and utilizing data needed to increase the understanding of terrestrial carbon sequestration, in particular carbon sequestered through agricultural practices and conservation agriculture, such as rangeland and grazing management, soil cover, and crop rotations.

Part of the purpose of the initiative is to "inform mproved risk-assessment methods, risk-management practices, and standards with respect to the sequestration of carbon on large and small scales"

Defines “terrestrial carbon sequestration” as carbon sequestration methods or technologies engineered by humans and targeted at rangelands, agricultural lands, or fallow lands to increase soil organic carbon levels or sequester carbon through plant and root biomass, including through soil additives, geochemical approaches, and other engineered solutions that can increase the storage of produced carbon in inorganic or mineral forms, such as biochar and carbon mineralization utilizing mine tailings.

Name: Harvesting Knowledge Act of 2022
Summary: To amend the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include indoor agricultural technology as an activity that supports well-rounded education, and eligible for student support and academic enrichment grants.
Support: Check back for press.
Analysis:
The goals as stated - “(vii) providing hands-on learning and exposure to hydroponic or aquaponic agricultural systems by integrating experiential, hands-on learning to enhance the students’ understanding of the STEM subjects as they relate to—(I) agriculture; (II) sustainability topics (including climate change, water resource management, efficient land use, biodiversity, conservation, and sustainable development); and (III) biology-related topics (including plant life cycles, functioning of ecosystems, and adaptation);” - would be best achieved by including soil-based agricultural systems (e.g. community/school gardens). 

This bill could include curriculum covering the basic understanding of soil biology and soil health as they relates to healthy ecosystems, carbon and water cycles. Adding the context of soil based agriculture systems is an opportunity improve this bill.

Name: Reducing Farm Input Costs and Barriers to Domestic Production Act
Summary:
This bill would include precision agriculture or nutrient management practices, including the acquisition of industry equipment and technology, within the FSA Conservation Loan and Guaranteed Loan Programs, and would give guaranteed loan priority to producers that engage in precision agriculture or nutrient management practices, including the purchase of equipment and technology. Allow 90 percent of the principle loan amount to be guaranteed for loans used for the purchase of precision agriculture or nutrient management equipment and technology; and include precision agriculture or nutrient management practices as practices recognized under EQIP, including Conservation Incentive Contracts. Allow for up to 90% of cost-share under the program for “state-determined high priority” precision agriculture or nutrient management practices. Add precision agriculture and nutrient management to the "advanced grazing management" section for supplemental payments under CSP.

Allow a producer receiving payments under EQIP to also receive a loan under the Conservation Loan and Loan Guarantee Program to cover additional costs for the same practices on the same land. Require FSA and NRCS to coordinate when making or guaranteeing loans. 

Nullify the final rule issued by the Council on Environmental Quality in 2022 titled “National Environmental Policy Act Implementing Regulations Revisions”.

Designate phosphate, potash, and "and other minerals necessary for the production of fertilizer and other agricultural products used to promote crop development" as critical minerals, and requires DOI to issue recommendations to Congress to support domestic production of such commodities. Make it the sense of Congress that glyphosate is safe and not carcinogen, and is "a necessary tool in ensuring a safe and secure food supply in the United States".  Permit the "continued sale and use of a pesticide whose registration is suspended or canceled...or vacated through a court order for a period of not less than 5 years after the date on which such suspension, cancellation or vacatur occurs."

Rescind the SEC’s proposed rule on climate-related disclosures.

Require an economic analysis on GIPSA rules.

See [[section-by-section summary https://republicans-agriculture.house.gov/uploadedfiles/sec-by-sec_barriers_to_production.pdf]].
Support: [[Press Release https://republicans-agriculture.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=7347]]
Analysis:
This bill aims to lower input costs for farmers by promoting precision agriculture and nutrient management practices. While the bill provides a 90% taxpayer-funded cost-share to encourage the adoption of these practices, it lacks clear standards or guidelines that would ensure significant reductions in input costs. Additionally, the legislation does not provide any additional funding, so the expanded cost-share could draw directly from existing resources and strain conservation program budgets for other proven soil health practices with well-documented input reduction benefits to farmers and ranchers.

The bill also addresses glyphosate regulation, prohibiting states from labeling glyphosate or glyphosate-containing products as carcinogens. This provision may be seen as protecting the agricultural industry from inconsistent state regulations, but it also undermines states' rights. It also openly endorses the safety and efficacy of glyphosate, which may not align with the free market values of many of the bill’s supporters.

Section 5 of the bill requires the EPA to permit the continued sale and use of any pesticide, including those deemed harmful, for at least five years after suspension, cancellation, or a court order. While this provision may provide stability to the industry, it could also expose farmers and their communities to potential health risks.

The bill authorizes the EPA to use phosphogypsum, a low-level radioactive waste material (generated from fertilizer production), in government road construction projects. This helps repurpose waste material but may also raise environmental and health concerns.

Additionally, the bill modifies corporate emissions reporting requirements for the Securities and Exchange Commission, potentially limiting emissions-related data availability and quality. Moreover, the legislation includes elements related to meat and poultry processing, allowing establishments to operate at rates exceeding the maximum limits currently outlined in regulations.

Name: Drought Relief through Innovative Projects (DRIP) Act of 2022
Summary:
This bill directs USDA to establish a $10 million annual competitive grant program to (1) remove nonnative plant species in riparian areas that contribute to drought conditions, (2) replace those nonnative plant species with native plant species, and (3) maintain and monitor riparian areas in which nonnative plant species have been removed and replaced.

Name: Recognizing and promoting the role of demonstration farm networks in expanding the adoption of conservation farming practices that improve the health of watersheds and agricultural lands.
Summary: This resolution recognizes and promotes the role of demonstration farm networks in expanding the adoption of conservation farming practices that improve the health of watersheds and agricultural lands.
Support: [[Press Release https://gallagher.house.gov/media/press-releases/gallagher-kind-recognize-wisconsin-demonstration-farms]]
Analysis:
Farmer-to-farmer networks are a known effective means of knowledge- and skills-sharing for the adoption of soil health practices, thus programs that support the expansion of such networks for the delivery of leading technical assistance should be valuable.

The resolution recognizes significant soil loss (over 1/3 of the Nation's topsoil), and the role of practices (mentioning reduced tillage, cover crops, managed grazing, and manure management) in building soil organic matter, increasing water quality and holding capacity, and thus resilience during drought, as well as reducing input costs and financial risks. 

Recognizes precedent, with the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative enabling the formation of the first demonstration farm network.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Ron Kind (D-WI-3)
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Conservation and Forestry; Transportation and Infrastructure - Subcommittee on Water Resources and Environment; Natural Resources

Name: Removing Emissions to Mend Our Vulnerable Earth (REMOVE) Act of 2022
Summary:
This bill would establish the "Committee on Large-Scale Carbon Management" in the Department of Energy and a Federal Carbon Removal Initiative.

This bill is the reintroduction of [[H.R.8671 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/8671/text]] - the CREATE Act of 2020.
Analysis:
The bill defines carbon dioxide removal as including soil carbon management, bioenergy with carbon capture and sequestration, and forest restoration, among other methods.

The proposed Committee must consider all available data on the carbon sequestration and storage potential of soils (including data collected externally to the Federal Government), as well as the cost effectiveness of soil carbon management as a carbon removal mechanism (in comparison to direct capture and technology based carbon removal solutions). 

If the Committee duly considers soil carbon management in its research, the associated recommendations could lead to support for producers to implement soil health practices.

New in this version of the bill: adds to the definition of carbon dioxide removal "any other approaches or methods identified by the Committee"; adds to the duties of the Committee "Monitoring the long-term carbon and environmental impacts of carbon dioxide removal." and "Evaluating socio-economic and community impacts resulting from the application of carbon dioxide removal technologies..."; directs the Committee to coordinate with other relevant agencies; establishes a multi-agency plan for the collection and management of data on carbon emissions and carbon dioxide removal that integrates existing data collection efforts acoss the Federal Government.
While these updates are new in the House version of the bill, the reintroduced Senate version (S.843) is identical to the version introduced in the 116th Congress, and retains the previous name (CREATE Act).
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Anthony Gonzalez (R-OH-16)
Committees: Science, Space, and Technology; Energy and Commerce

Name: Expressing the need for protecting and conserving at least 50 percent of the lands and oceans in the United States and encouraging diplomatic efforts to achieve this goal worldwide.
Summary: This resolution expresses the need for protecting and conserving at least 50 percent of the lands and oceans in the United States and encouraging diplomatic efforts to achieve this goal worldwide.
Analysis:
In order to achieve the goals outlined in this resolution, conservation on working agricultural lands must be included.

This resolution was introduced in support of the Half-Earth initiative.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Barbara Lee (D-CA-13), Rep. Raúl Grijalva (D-AZ-3)

Name: Flood Insurance for Farmers Act of 2022
Summary:
This bill would remove the prohibition on construction and repair of agricultural structures in high flood-risk areas (Special Flood Hazard Areas) as designated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). Currently, all new, expanded, or repaired structures must be raised above potential flood level. 

It also makes the chargeable premium rate for coverage of a structure given a variance the same as would otherwise apply if the structure had been dry floodproofed, or a comparable actuarial rate based upon the risk associated with structures within the applicable AL-E zone. 

This is a reintroduction of [[H.R.830 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/830/text]] - Flood Insurance for Farmers Act of 2019
Support:
California Rice Commission, USA Rice Federation, American Farm Bureau Federation, California Farm Bureau Federation, Sacramento County Farm Bureau, Yuba-Sutter Farm Bureau, Yolo County Farm Bureau, California Cattlemen’s Association, Dairy Institute of California, Sacramento County, San Joaquin County, Sutter County, Butte County, and Sutter Butte Flood Control Agency.

2019 [[Press Release https://garamendi.house.gov/media/press-releases/garamendi-and-lamalfa-reintroduce-flood-insurance-farmers-act]]
Analysis:
This bill is essentially asking to taxpayers to subsidize flood insurance in high risk "Special Flood Hazard Areas" that FEMA has determined are not actuarially sound. 

The rationale of the bill is that constructing or repairing agricultural structures above potential flood level is "cost prohibitive for farmers" and thus threatens continued agricultural land use. 

There could be an opportunity for flood insurance to be subsidized on "high risk" lands when flood-mitigating soil health practices are in place, by accounting for the risk reduction associated with continual improvements in soil health in actuarial assessments (rather than issuing subsidized policies with no risk mitigation strategy). Tying farmer incentives to reducing on-farm risk, especially in high risk regions, could be impactful both for supporting farmers in keeping their farms in place over the long term, and for reducing risk across the Flood Insurance Program portfolio.

Changes from last version of bill: The current version of the bill removes some detail that was in the previous bill that allowed for alternative maps and risk-based rates for National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) coverage in certain areas where levees fail to meet specified minimum standards. This version allows the chargeable premium rate for coverage of a structure given a variance to be the same as would otherwise apply if the structure had been dry floodproofed or "a comparable actuarial rate based upon the risk associated with structures within the applicable AL-E zone."
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Doug LaMalfa (R-CA-1), Rep. Mike Bost (R-IL-12)

Name: Food and Agribusiness Merger Moratorium and Antitrust Review Act of 2022
Summary:
This bill places a moratorium on certain acquisitions between large agricultural and retail-related businesses and establishes the Food and Agriculture Concentration and Market Power Review Commission. The commission shall report to Congress and the President on (1) the nature and consequences of market concentration in the U.S. food and agricultural economy, and (2) recommended legal and regulatory changes to address such market concentration. "The moratorium would be lifted once Congress acts on the recommendations from the commission by passing comprehensive legislation to address the problem of growing market concentration in the agriculture sector."

This is the reintroduction of [[S.1596 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/1596/text]] - The Food and Agribusiness Merger Moratorium and Antitrust Review Act of 2019.
Support:
The bill has been endorsed by Farm Action Fund, Food & Water Watch, R-CALF USA, and several other farm, food, rural, community, labor, consumer, and advocacy organizations. See list [[here https://www.booker.senate.gov/news/press/booker-introduces-bill-to-place-moratorium-on-ag-mergers]].

Booker [[Press Releas https://www.booker.senate.gov/news/press/booker-tester-merkley-warren-introduce-bill-to-impose-moratorium-on-large-agribusiness-mergers]]
Analysis:
Consolidation of meat packing and limited local processing access is a known obstacle to the financial viability of many regenerative family farms.

From press release: "In the past four decades, the top four beef packers have expanded their market share from 32 percent to 85 percent. This increased concentration, combined with anticompetitive practices and other abuses by these large multinational meatpacking companies, are driving small family farmers out of business and undermining the economies of rural communities."
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-OR), Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA)
