Name: Support To Rehydrate the Environment, Agriculture, and Municipalities Act (STREAM) Act
Summary:
This bill "would increase water supply and modernize water infrastructure throughout the West" by authorizing funding for water storage, recycling, desalination and supply projects, building on the funding provided by the bipartisan infrastructure law. 

It includes funding for ecosystem restoration, including an additional $250 million for the habitat restoration grant program in the bipartisan infrastructure law, and an additional $50 million for "natural water retention and release projects".

Establishes an Integrated Water Management Federal Leadership Committee, with membership from USDA, to coordinate federal efforts to implement water management projects. 

[[Section-by-section summary https://www.feinstein.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/a/c/ac93828e-2c11-49fe-99a7-984949829ca3/501B454487B27C7B5A1D88A9135B2E11.2022.05.18-stream-act-section-by-section.pdf]]
Support:
Has been endorsed by The Nature Conservancy, Association of California Water Agencies, California Farm Bureau, California Waterfowl, Ducks Unlimited, Family Farm Alliance, Grassland Water District, and National Water Resources Association, among others. See a full list [[here https://www.feinstein.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/c/9/c9ada155-66b0-4575-bb3b-d71d3729240a/13CF4C060B2A05E0B5ABD87A07E804E2.2022.05.18-stream-act-supporters.pdf]].

[[Press Release https://www.feinstein.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?ID=1783E95E-F02C-4CFC-9E81-AEFF7AAAC3AF]]
Analysis:
The inclusion of nature-based water supply solutions, alongside more "traditional" infrastructure projects, creates an opportunity to involve soil health focused farmers, ranchers, and foresters in meeting water conservation and supply goals.

Aligned with the soil health principle of mimicing natural systems, the definition of "natural water retention and release project" includes a project that "substantially mimics natural riverine, wetland, ecosystem, or hydrologic processes."
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Mark Kelly (D-AZ), Sen. Kyrsten Sinema (D-AZ)
Committees: Energy and Natural Resources - Subcommittee on Water and Power
Status: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources Subcommittee on Water and Power. Hearings held.

Name: To direct the Secretary of Agriculture to support and incentivize domestic activities to address fertilizer shortages and deficiencies, diversify fertilizer sources, and reduce dependency on foreign sources for fertilizer, and for other purposes.
Summary: This bill provides $100 million, until expended, through the CCC to increase the availability of "innovative fertilizer and fertilizer alternatives", materials or tools that reduce the need for fertilizer or support the more efficient use of fertilizer, research and development.
Analysis:
In supporting increased access to "alternative fertilizers", the bill mentions "biological products and technologies", which can be expected to reduce the use of synthetic fertilizer.

The bill does not mention building soil health as a key strategy for reducing the need for fertilizer. It does include "incentivizing greater precision in fertilizer use" but does not specify what these incentives would look like. 

The bill does not ask for a report to USDA assessing the impacts/outcomes of the $100 Million Dollar program or what strategies, if any should be further encouraged.
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Biotechnology, Horticulture, and Research

Name: To direct the Secretary of Agriculture to provide additional payments under the environmental quality incentives program for implementation of a nutrient management practice, and for other purposes.
Summary:
This bill would provide $750 million to USDA to cover up to 100% of the cost of implementing nutrient management practices under EQIP contracts in 2022 and 2023.

The bill defines "nutrient management practice" according to the NRCS conservaiton practice standard: management of the "rate, source, placement, and timing of plant nutrients and soil amendments while reducing environmental impacts."

The bill allows up to 5 percent of the funds to be used for related technical assistance.
Support: [[See Article https://www.farmweeknow.com/policy/national/house-ag-narrowly-advances-usda-meat-investigator-bill/article_d32aa858-d6c3-11ec-8a35-b36f71800146.html]]
Analysis:
Nutrient management is an important way to reduce over-application of chemical fertilizers. 

The bill does not specify any efficiency requirement for funding eligibility (ie. funding amounts are not tied to any % of reduction), and thus could spend 3/4 of a billion of taxpayer dollars with little impact unless this becomes specified.

The bill is aimed at meeting USDA's goal of reducing fertilizer use in the context of surging prices and conservation pressure. 

Biden at an Illinois farm May 11 announced his administration with USDA would seek to use EQIP and CSP to prioritize application approvals for nutrient management and technology-driven precision agriculture practices.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Jim Costa (D-CA-16)
Status: Approved by House Agriculture Committee. Placed on Union Calendar.

Name: American Food Supply Chain Resiliency Act
Summary:
This bill would establish “Supply Chain Regional Resource Centers” (no fewer than 6) through cooperative agreements with the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA). These Centers would support supply chain coordination in their region, fund technical assistance providers to offer guidance to food businesses and farms, and provide small grants to entities looking to expand or start their operations in a certain region.

The bill provies $6 million annually to carry out the programs.
Support: [[Press Release https://spanberger.house.gov/posts/spanberger-gonzalez-introduce-bipartisan-bill-to-combat-supply-chain-challenges-in-american-agriculture-lower-food-costs-for-consumers]]
Analysis:
While the "Supply Chain Regional Resource Centers" do not have a specific soil health language, navigating supply chain issues is a challenge many small and medium-sized, soil health and locally-focused farmers and ranchers face. Thus, these recources will be valuble to soil health focused farmers, and the commitment to support small- and medium-sized producers and businesses should support more soil health-centric farm viablilty.

The bill requires that at least one Center should focus specifically on supply chain issues faced by Indian tribes and Tribal organizations. 

This bill codifies USDA's recent announcement of its intention to create Regional Food Business Centers (RFBC) to build collaboration across sectors of local and regional food supply chains.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Ann Kuster (D-NH-2), Rep. Josh Gottheimer (D-NJ-5)
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Anthony Gonzalez (R-OH-16)
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Biotechnology, Horticulture, and Research

Name: Plant Biostimulant Act of 2022
Summary:
This bill provides a definition for plant biostimulants (under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act, or FIRFA), and directs EPA to exclude plant biostimulants from regulation under FIRFA.

'Plant biostimulant’ is defined as follows: a substance, micro-organism, or mixture thereof, that, when applied to seeds, plants, the rhizosphere, soil, or other growth media, act to support a plant’s natural processes independently of the biostimulant’s nutrient content, including by improving nutrient availability, uptake or use efficiency, tolerance to abiotic stress, and consequent growth, development, quality, or yield.

The bill also directs the Secretary of Agriculture to conduct and publish a study on plant biostimulants' benefits for soil health.
Support:
The bill has been endorsed by the Humic Products Trade Association (HPTA), Marrone Bio Innovations, BPIA, Novozymes Inc., Biotechnology Innovation Organization, and the American Seed Trade Association (ASTA). 

[[Panetta Press Release https://panetta.house.gov/media/press-releases/rep-panetta-introduces-bipartisan-bill-bolster-plant-biostimulant-research-and]]
Analysis:
The soil health study required under Sec. 3 of this bill includes a thorough list of elements related to improved soil health, including reducing runoff, increasing bioactivity, sequestering carbon, and others. 

"Currently, there isn’t a consistent and predictable path to market for plant biostimulants and this legislation would help remedy that problem with federal guidance from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and Department of Agriculture," says Rep. Panetta, the bill's sponsor.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Chellie Pingree (D-ME-1)
Cosponsors (R): Rep. James Baird (R-IN-4), Rep. Chris Jacobs (R-NY-27)
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Biotechnology, Horticulture, and Research

Name: Agriculture Innovation Act of 2022
Summary:
The Agriculture Innovation Act would direct the Secretary of Agriculture to identify, collect, link, and analyze data relating to the impacts of covered conservation and other production practices on enhancing crop yields, soil health, and ecosystem services, reducing risk, and improving farm, ranch, and other working land profitability.

It would also allow the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a secure, confidential cloud-based conservation and farm productivity data center to store operational, transactional, and administrative program databases and records that support business, statistical, and other analysis.

Enables USDA to use research, analysis, and evaluation products derived from enhanced data to provide technical assistance to farmers and improve farm program implementation. 

*This bill builds on the Agriculture Data Act of 2018 ([[S.2487 https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/senate-bill/2487/text]]), parts of which passed in the 2018 Farm Bill (authorizing USDA to identify existing datasets on conservation practices, and producing a summary report to the House Ag Committee).
Support:
The legislation has been endorsed by the National Corn Growers Association, Theodore Roosevelt Conservation Partnership, Natural Resources Defense Council, AGree Coalition, Ducks Unlimited, BPC Action, National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition, Pheasants Forever, American Farmland Trust, Environmental Defense Fund, American Sportfishing Association, Backcountry Hunters & Anglers, Izaak Walton League of America, the National Wildlife Federation, American Fly Fishing Trade Association, American Woodcock Association, Angler Action Foundation, Archery Trade Association, Danone North America, Mishra and Roznik, Arizona State University Morrison School of Agribusiness, National Deer Association, Quail Forever, Ruffed Grouse Society, Supporters of Agriculture Research, Unilever United States, and the Wildlife Management Institute.

[[Klobuchar Press Release https://www.klobuchar.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2022/5/klobuchar-thune-introduce-bipartisan-legislation-to-connect-farmers-with-most-effective-conservation-practices]]
Analysis:
The bill direct USDA to conduct research on the impacts of conservation practices on crop yields, soil health, ecosystem services, and profitability (using the analyzed data), and it also directs USDA to use the results of this research to improve the implementation of USDA programs (Sec 2).

The act would make a large amount of data publicly available; see Sec. 2 added Sec. 1248 (c) (10) "Promptly make available on the public-facing component of the secure data center established under paragraph (6) the research, analysis, evaluation products, and other information generated in carrying out this section"). 

The bill addresses data confidentiality and security (Sec. 2, (d) (2) REQUIREMENT TO MODERNIZE DATA SECURITY, STORAGE, AND ACCESS.), which is a concern for many farmers.

This bill could make a significant impact on research and development, especially for new quantification tools associated with agriculture, and specifically soil health.

While farmers would only benefit directly from the incentives offered to share their data, they would hopefully also benefit indirectly through the development of tools that would be facilitated by the increased availability of data (e.g. tools to quantify risk, or efficiency of practices etc...). However, the public availability of such a significant amount of data could potentially devalue the data of an individual farmer because the annonimized, aggrigated data would be widely avaialble. 

New in this version of the bill: 
→ Expands the scope of the legislation beyond “conservation practices” to include all production practices.
→ Expands the “purpose” of the bill to include support for the development of ecosystem markets. 
→ Authorizes the Secretary to provide incentives to producers to share data.
→ Authorizes the Secretary to use existing funds and authorities to carry out the legislation.
→ Adds the Department of Agriculture’s Chief Data Officer as a coordinating position for carrying out the activities outlined in the legislation.
→ Explicitly links the collection and identification of relevant USDA data sets to the evidence building plan required by the Evidence Act.
→ Replaces the term “data warehouse” with “data center” to better convey the intent.
→ Requires the Secretary to periodically consult with experts and stakeholders to consider necessary modifications to security and confidentiality protections.
Cosponsors (R): Sen. John Thune (R-SD)

Name: Strengthening the Agriculture and Food Supply Chain Act
Summary: This bill would create a task force at USDA that would be responsible for "evaluating the stability and reliability of the agriculture and food system as well as identifying specific recommendations to improve the security, safety and resilience of the supply chain". The task force would be required to submit a report detailing its work and recommendations for "improving the security, safety, and resilience of the agriculture and food system supply chain" to Congress no later than 270 days after the enactment of the bill.
Support:
The bill has been endorsed by National Farmers Union, National Corn Growers Association, U.S. Dairy Export Council, National Milk Producers Federation, Minnesota Soybean Growers Association, and Consumer Brands Association.

[[Press Release https://craig.house.gov/media/press-releases/representative-angie-craig-leads-introduction-bipartisan-legislation-strengthen]]
Analysis: The text of the Strengthening the Agriculture and Food Supply Chain Act was included in H.R.7606 - Lower Food and Fuel Costs Act - which passed in the House on June 16, 2022.

Name: Great Lakes Agricultural Stewardship Act
Summary:
This bill directs USDA, in consultation with the Great Lakes States, to establish a "Great Lakes basin initiative" for agricultural nonpoint source pollution prevention.

The initiative would provide grants to Great Lakes States to fund education and outreach to producers; technical assistance for producers to implement activities that reduce or prevent nonpoint pollution of water; and the development and implementation of voluntary State verification programs (with a funding priority for programs that incorporate USDA conservation planning and practice standards).
Support:
The bill has been supported by the Michigan Farm Bureau.

[[Press Release https://walberg.house.gov/media/press-releases/walberg-and-ryan-introduce-bipartisan-bill-protect-great-lakes-promote]]
Analysis:
The bill is aimed at bringing federal support to voluntary state assurance programs in Great Lakes states, modeled after the Michigan Agriculture Environmental Assurance Program (MAEAP), which verifies farms based on certain guidelines, and supports farmers in implementing conservation practices (including soil health practices) and reducing hazards, such as runoff and erosion.

We imagine many of the education and training initiatives would include soil health-centric practices, but the bill does not mention soil health.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Tim Ryan (D-OH-13)
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Conservation and Forestry

Name: Supporting the designation of December 5 of each year as "National Soil Health Day"
Summary: A House resolution that: (1) supports the designation of “National Soil Health Day”; and (2) calls upon this celebration and its related activities to improve the awareness of United States farmers and agribusiness toward the importance of the air and water quality environment for all of the citizens of the United States.

Name: Lower Food and Fuel Costs Act
Summary:
This bill "addresses provisions related to agriculture, food, and fuel, including by providing funds for nutrient management, precision agriculture, and biofuel infrastructure". By incorporating several separate bills, this bill:

Title I) Establishes within USDA the Office of the Special Investigator for Competition Matters, which must investigate and prosecute violations of the Packers and Stockyards Act of 1921 by packers and live poultry dealers. The Special Investigator would have subpoena and litigation power, and would coordinate and act in consultation with the DOJ and FTC.

Title II) Provides funding for USDA ($500 million for FY2022-3) to make payments to agricultural producers for up to 100% of the costs of crop nutrient use or adopting precision agriculture practices. 

Title III) Subtitle A establishes an "agriculture and food supply chain resilience and crisis response task force"; Subtitle B provides assistance to address fertilizer shortages and reduce dependency on foreign sources for fertilizer; Subtitle C directs USDA's Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) to enter into certain cooperative agreements for establishing supply chain regional resource centers to support small- and medium-sized producers of agricultural products and agricultural businesses. 

Title IV) Provides funding for USDA ($200 million for FY2022-3) to provide grants to eligible entities (e.g., fueling and distribution facilities) for biofuel infrastructure.

Title V) Applies the Reid vapor pressure (a measure of gasoline's volatility) requirements that are applicable to gasoline blended with 10% ethanol (E10) to gasoline blended with more than 10% ethanol. Thus, the waiver given to E10 gasoline, which allows an increase in the Reid Vapor Pressure volatility, is extended to gasoline blended with more than 10% ethanol. 

Title VI) Incorporates support for precision agriculture into various USDA programs, including the FSA Conservation Loan and Loan Guarantee Program, EQIP, and CSP.

Title VII) Allows USDA to make loans and grants for livestock and poultry processing.

Title VIII) "Lower Food and Fuel Costs Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2022" - provides an additional $200 million to carry out Title IV; and an additional $500 million to carry out Title II.
Support:
Supported by: Virginia Cattlemen’s Association, National Farmers Union, National Young Farmers Coalition

[[Press Release https://spanberger.house.gov/posts/just-in-u-s-house-passes-spanberger-led-package-to-lower-grocery-gas-costs-fight-inflation]] on Bill Passing House (June 16, 2022)
Analysis:
Overall there are a number of strong provisions in this bill that are aimed at increasing supply chain resiliency. However, like other current proposals that focus on nutrient management and precision agriculture as a primary means of achieving the goals, these practices are broad "best practices" and do not specify any input reduction levels or standards for increased efficiency needed to qualify for funding. Without this being specified, this bill could spend hundreds of millions of taxpayer dollars with little to no impact on efficiency.

Spanberger originally introduced this bill as the "Meat and Poultry Special Investigator Act of 2022". During June 2022, she expanded the bill to include several other, standalone bills addressing inflation and supply chain issues, renaming the bill as the "Lower Food and Fuel Costs Act". Several of the Titles in this bill are drawn from other bills, specifically:

Title I) H.R.7606/S.3870 - Meat and Poultry Special Investigator Act
Title II) related to H.R.7764
Title III) Subtitle A - H.R.7675 - Strengthening the Agriculture and Food Supply Chain Act; Subtitle B - H.R.7763 - To support and incentivize domestic activities to address fertilizer shortages and deficiencies, diversify fertilizer sources, and reduce dependency on foreign sources for fertilizer; and Subtitle C - H.R.7765 - American Food Supply Chain Resiliency Act) 
Title IV) Provides funding for USDA ($200 million for FY2022-3) to provide grants to eligible entities (e.g., fueling and distribution facilities) for biofuel infrastructure.
Title V) H.R.4410 - Year-Round Fuel Choice Act
Title VI) H.R.2518 - PRECISE Act
Title VII) H.R.4140 - Butcher Block Act
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Katie Porter (D-CA-45), Rep. Cynthia Axne (D-IA-3)
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Mariannette Miller-Meek (R-IA-2)
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Livestock and Foreign Agriculture
Status: Passed House; Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry.

Name: SECURE Food Act
Summary:
This bill would require the Director of National Intelligence to submit an intelligence report on the effects of increased production and consumption of alternative proteins on American national security. 

The report would address plant-based and cultivated proteins’ impacts on food security, water supplies, climate impacts, public health, the agricultural sector, and the American economy as a whole. 

The study would include an anlysis of how the production and consumption of alternative proteins made by foreign countries constitutes a "competitive threat to American economic interests".
Support:
The bill has been supported by the Truman National Security Project, Food Solutions Action, and The Good Food Institute.

[[Press Release https://krishnamoorthi.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressmen-krishnamoorthi-and-khanna-introduce-security-economy-climate-and]]
Analysis:
The suggested framing of this study makes a critical link between various food production systems and food, climate and water security. Such a study could help to increase understanding of these linkages among the intelligence community. However:

The variability of different management systems - soil health focused, regenerative row cropping vs. conventional, or management-intensive rotational grazing vs. contained feed-lot beef, etc. are not being specifically addressed and need to be clarified for this initiative to be a meaningful tool in drawing conclusions.

Thus, the study must not miss the opportunity to provide a full and accurate picture of the impacts of the range of protein production systems, including management-intensive rotational grazing systems. The study should take a Life Cycle Assessment approach to the food, climate and water security impacts of "alternative" plant based protein production systems to yield an accurate picture of the impacts of these systems. 

This information is critical for the intelligence community to support the development of a more resilient and secure food system.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Ro Khanna (D-CA-17), Rep. Julia Brownley (D-CA-26)
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Gus Bilirakis (R-FL-12), Rep. Robert Wittman (R-VA-1), Rep. David Schweikert (R-AZ-6)

Name: Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) Improvement Act of 2022
Support:
This bill is endorsed by Pheasants Forever, Quail Forever, Ducks Unlimited, and South Dakota Cattlemen's Association.

Thune [[Press Release https://www.thune.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?ID=1D2895E5-87BE-4EBA-A898-389EB67C1510]]
Analysis:
The 150% increase in the annual CRP payment, from $50,000 to $125,000, will make CRP a significantly more attractive option for producers.

Additionally, the bill makes CRP grazing a more attractive option by providing cost-share for the establishment of grazing infrastructure – including fencing and water distribution – on all CRP contracts if grazing is included in the approved conservation plan. Appropriate grazing can have significant benefits for soil health, particularly on grasslands. 

Recommend that the bill add language specifying "holistic planned grazing" or "rotational grazing" to ensure the encouragement of grazing meets the program's goals (reducing topsoil erosion, runoff, habitat loss, etc.). 

Builds on recent program updates made during 2021 - see "What's New With CRP?" June 2021 Fact Sheet
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-MN)
Cosponsors (R): Sen. Mike Rounds (R-SD)

Name: Rural Prosperity Act of 2022
Summary:
This bill would establish an Office of Rural Prosperity within the White House. 

The office would be led by a Chief Rural Advisor, who would be appointed by the President and would serve on the National Economic Council.

The office would be responsible for developing and updating (at least every 3 years) a comprehensive strategy for rural development across the Executive Branch.
Support:
The bill has been supported by Rural Organizing. 

Craig [[Press Release https://craig.house.gov/media/press-releases/representatives-craig-and-newhouse-lead-bipartisan-introduction-rural]]
Analysis:
Having a dedicated Chief Rural Advisor could have an impact on agricultural policies implemented by the President. This would be a position that the soil health community would want to be aware of, should such an Office be established, as a targeted means of engaging with the Executive branch on agricultural issues. 

The "rural prosperity action plan" which the Secretary of Agriculture and Under Secretary for Rural Development would be charged with developing, would include actions to:
- remove barriers to economic prosperity in rural areas
- empower State, local, and Tribal agencies that implement rural economic development, agricutlural, and environmental programs to tailor those programs to relevant regional circumstances
- increase employment opportunities in agriculture
- "promote the preservation of family farms as they are passed from generation to generation" 
- improve food safety
- address barriers related to access to federal lands for grazing
- improve coordination between Federal government and other stakeholders
- among other goals that would impact agriculture.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY)
Cosponsors (R): Sen. Joni Ernst (R-IA), Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-IA)

Name: Recycling and Composting Accountability Act
Summary: This bill would require the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to prepare and submit reports to Congress on the capability of the United States to implement a national residential composting strategy, and on federal agency recycling practices. The bill would also require EPA to collect, and make publicly available, data on recycling and composting rates across the country.
Support: [[Press Release https://www.carper.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2022/3/carper-capito-boozman-introduce-legislation-to-strengthen-recycling-and-composting-efforts]]
Analysis: Sec. 4 - Report on Composting Infrastructure Capabilities is the most relevant section of this bill for agriculture. A consistent source of compost nationwide for use as fertilizer would be invaluable to the success of regenerative farming. Compost infrastructure and strategies are underdeveloped in the US, leading to low quality and often unusable compost. The national strategy explored through the report in this section of the bill, including an evaluation of existing infrastructure and needs to expand composting programs, would potentially help to overcome these challenges.

Name: Voluntary Grazing Permit Retirement Act
Summary:
This bill would allow ranchers who hold grazing permits on federal lands to voluntarily retire their grazing permits in exchange for payment. The bill applies to federal lands in the 16 western states managed by USDA or the Department of the Interior.

Once the rancher has sold this right, the managing federal agency would be required to permanently extinguish the right, with the intention of permanently ending livestock grazing on the allotment covered by the permit or lease. 

The bill is aimed at simplifying current law and regulations, which either do not allow for the retirement of grazing permits or make the process difficult. 

Reintroduction of [[H.R.5737 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/5737/text]] - Voluntary Grazing Permit Retirement Act of 2020 (identical bill).
Support:
Conservation orgs strongly support this bill (including the Sierra Club, NRDC, and Wilderness Watch) although it has received strong opposition from ranchers, the Public Lands Council, and beef associations.

Notable Press: [[The Fence Post https://www.thefencepost.com/news/ncba-urges-congress-to-oppose-voluntary-grazing-permit-retirement-act/]]

[[Press Release https://adamsmith.house.gov/2022/3/reps-smith-and-huffman-introduce-the-voluntary-grazing-permit-retirement-act-to-promote-smart-land-use-practices]]
Analysis:
This bill is motivated by environmental concern, but is based on the assumption that grazing is antithetical to conservation goals. 

Ranchers are generally opposed to the act because it would reduce their ability to graze on federal lands. 

The environmental impact of the grazing is unclear as many ranchers who oppose the bill claim that grazing is necessary for the health of grasslands, improving the land and soil by cycling nutrients and helping to prevent wildfire risk. 

The degree to which grazing damages or improves the land is likely connected to the management techniques used which relate to soil health. Thus, the change could be beneficial in the context of overgrazing, but would lead to prohibiting holistically managed grazing activity (with the associated soil health benefits) on the allotments covered by the permit or lease. 

This bill could be made more soil health focused with an emphasis on re-issuing licences to ranching operations with "holistically managed grazing plans and practices" rather than attempting to permenantly retire these grazing permits.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Jared Huffman (D-CA-2)
Agencies: U.S. Dept. of Agriculture; U.S. Dept. of Interior

Name: Climate Resilience Workforce Act
Summary:
"To establish a climate resilience workforce, and for other purposes." This bill would establish an Office of Climate Resilience within the White House, as well as a Center for the Climate Resilience Workforce, to support workforce development programs, including through a Climate Resilience Job Creation grant program. 

The bill would also fund the development of "regional, state, local, and community-based climate resilience action plans." 

The bill focuses on five "climate resilience sectors", one of which is agriculture. Efforts to 'prepare for, adapt to, and address risks related to climate change' are identified across social, environmental, and economic systems, including:

(B) ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS (iii) LAND.—Loss of land cover and impact on agriculture, wildfires, coastal wetlands and vegetation, mitigating the impacts of deforestation and urbanization, and considering climate change risks in land use decisions; and (v) ECOSYSTEMS AND BIODIVERSITY.—Altered or deteriorated ecosystem functions, altered individual characteristics of organisms, timing of biological events and geographic ranges of terrestrial, freshwater and marine organisms, spread of invasive species, loss of biodiversity, endangerment and extinction of organisms, and changes in agricultural and fisheries production, supply of clean water, protection from extreme events, and culturally valuable resources.

(C) ECONOMIC SYSTEMS (ix) AGRICULTURE AND FOOD SYSTEMS.—Disruptions to food availability, access, and quality due to reduced agricultural productivity, changes in temperature and precipitation patterns resulting in floods, droughts, changes in crop and livestock viability, new pests, pathogens and weed problems, depletion of water supplies for irrigation, soil degradation, illness and death in farm workers and livestock due to heat, economic losses, instability of food supply, closure of smaller farms with limited safety nets to deal with disrupting factors, economic losses for farming and rural communities, and increased food prices and greater food insecurity.
Support:
Endorsing organizations include the Architecture Lobby, Data for Progress, Food & Water Watch, 350 Seattle, Sunrise Movement, Casa Latina, Asian Pacific Environmental Network, Gulf Coast Center for Law & Policy, Resilience Force, Friends of the Earth US, The Union of Concerned Scientists, Sierra Club, Indivisible, Seattle Aquarium, National Immigration Project (NIPNLG), National Immigration Law Center, Make the Road NY, People’s Action, SEIU, The Green New Deal Network, the National Immigrant Justice Center, OneAmerica, and MoveOn.

[[Press Release https://jayapal.house.gov/2022/01/25/jayapal-leads-lawmakers-in-introducing-the-climate-resilience-workforce-act/]]
Analysis:
This bill demonstrates an understanding of the impacts of extreme weather events on food production, the agriculture sector, and farm viability in the definition/framing of climate resilience sectors; particularly in Sec. 7(c)(2)(C)(ix) AGRICULTURE AND FOOD SYSTEMS, where it identifies how changes in weather patterns are contributing to flood, drought, and pest issues and soil degradation, leading to economic losses and closure of smaller farms with limited safety nets. 

There is a greater opportunity to focus workforce training in soil health management and regenerative agriculture as a key mechanism for enhancing the resilience of the agriculture system.

Name: National Climate Adaptation and Resilience Strategy Act
Summary:

Name: New York-New Jersey Watershed Protection Act
Summary:
This bill requires the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to establish the New York-New Jersey Watershed Restoration Program, a nonregulatory program, to coordinate restoration and protection activities among government entities and conservation partners throughout the watershed. The bill also establishes the New York-New Jersey Watershed Restoration Grant Program, a voluntary grant and technical assistance program, to provide competitive matching grants to certain entities to implement restoration and protection activities for the watershed.

The bill authorizes $50,000,000 annually through fiscal year 2027.
Support: The bill is endorsed by Scenic Hudson, Riverkeeper, NY/NJ Baykeeper, NYC Soil & Water Conservation District, National Wildlife Federation, Jersey City Parks Coalition, Environmental Defense Fund, National Parks Conservation Association, NJ Audubon Society, Hackensack Riverkeeper, Waterfront Alliance, Natural Areas Conservancy, and more (see full list [[here https://tonko.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=3441]]).
Analysis:
The bill directs the NY-NJ Watershed Restoration Program to adopt a strategy to maximize conservation outcomes, including (under Sec 4(d)(2) - purposes) to advance the use of natural climate solutions and natural infrastructure; to provide for feasibility and planning studies for green infrastructure projects that achieve habitat restoration and stormwater management goals; to support land conservation and management activities; to provide technical assistance to carry out resstoration activities; and more. 

There is opportunity for building soil health to be identified as critical infrastructure for habitat restoration, storm and flood management, and other goals; and for the Program to engage with producers and private landowners in achieving the goals of the legislation. 

Could provide a template for bipartisan, nonregulatory "restoration and protection" legislation for use in other regions.

Name: Study on Improving Lands (SOIL) Act
Summary:
This bill would require the Department of Agriculture, in coordination with the Department of Interior and the National Academies of Science, to (1) direct a study on the state of soil health on federal lands that determines impacts such as grazing, wildfire, recreation, and invasive species; and (2) create a database of the information collected during the study. The report is required to include recommendations for legislative or regulatory action to improve soil health, increase carbon sequestration, and improve community benefits of soil health programs on Federal lands.

Reintroduction of [[H.R.4133 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/4133/text]] - SOIL Act of 2019
Support:
This bill received support from Rocky Mountain Farmers Union.

2019 [[Press Release https://curtis.house.gov/press-releases/curtis-neguse-introduce-bipartisan-legislation-to-study-soil-health-on-public-lands/]]
Analysis:
The study will specifically determine: 1) soil organic matter and other measurements; (2) soil qualities that lead to the sequestering of carbon; and (3) soil qualities that support strong ecosystems and resilient environments.

Requires commencing on a study on the state of soil health on Federal lands that determines impacts such as grazing, wildfire, recreation, invasive species, and other relevant impacts on soil health on Federal lands.

Would create a baseline to guide "Congress in introducing impactful legislation to build soil health on public lands" and create a database with access for academic and priave sector research.

Bill does not specify how the study would be funded.

Name: Driftless Area Landscape Conservation Initiative Act (DALCI) Act
Summary:
This bill would re-establish the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Driftless Area Landscape Conservation Initiative (DALCI) (originally run from 2012-2017).

The DALCI Act would recommit the USDA to conservation efforts in the Driftless Area (the region between Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota and Wisconsin) with $5 million through the Environmental Quality Incentives Program for efforts managing working lands, woodlands, prairies and cold water streams in the region.
Support:
The bill is endorsed by the Natural Land Institute, Aldo Leopold Foundation, Izaak Walton League of Iowa, Izaak Walton League of Illinois, Izaak Walton League of Minnesota, Izaak Walton League of Wisconsin, Izaak Walton League of America, Environmental Policy Innovation Center, Environmental Law & Policy Center, Northeast Iowa Resource Conservation & Development, Nature Conservancy, Trout Unlimited, Prairie Enthusiasts, the Driftless Area Land Conservancy, and more.

[[Press Release https://bustos.house.gov/bustos-hinson-craig-kind-introduce-bipartisan-legislation-to-preserve-the-driftless-area-between-illinois-iowa-minnesota-wisconsin/]]
Analysis:
With the following objectives (listed in Sec. 2), and implemented through EQIP, DALCI offers a template that can be followed to implement other regional efforts to reduce soil loss across the country: 

1. Manage working lands for year-round ground cover to rebuild soil, sequester carbon, improve water quality, increase water holding capacity of soil, reduce soil erosion, and mitigate flooding and other climate impacts. 
2. Manage woodlands for increased biodiversity to improve the health of woods to provide habitat and sequester carbon.
3. Restore prairies and manage grasslands, oak savannas, and barrens to expand habitat and sequester carbon.
4. Restore cold water streams by reducing stream bank erosion and threats of flooding while improving trout habitat.

Name: Protect America’s Children from Toxic Pesticides Act of 2021 (PACTPA)
Summary:
This bill would ban three forms of pesticides from the farm system - organophosphate insecticides, neonicotinoid insecticides and paraquat herbicides.

The bill is largely the same as a version introduced in 2020 by then-Sen. Tom Udall. However, Booker’s legislation includes new language to protect farmworkers from retaliation if they speak out as whistleblowers and to expand the ability of citizens to pursue legal action if EPA doesn’t fully enforce the law.
Support:
The measure has gained support from more than 50 groups, including the American Bird Conservancy, Bird Conservation Network, Center for Biological Diversity, Center for Food Safety, Farmworker Justice, Natural Resources Defense Council, NOFA/Mass, United Farm Workers, and more (see full list [[here https://www.booker.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/endorsed_organizations_for_protect_americas_children_from_toxic_pesticides_act.pdf]]

 [[Press Release https://www.booker.senate.gov/news/press/booker-announces-legislation-aimed-at-banning-dangerous-pesticides-from-our-agriculture-system]]
Analysis:
While the bill focuses on addressing the adverse human health impacts of the identified pesticides, there is a direct corrilation between how and which pesticides are used, and the health of our our soils and lands.

There is an opportunity for this bill to recognize building soil health and biological function as a strategy for reducing overreliance on synthetic pesticides, and to address the economic considerations for supporting farmers in transitioning to more resilient soil health focused management systems.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY), Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA), Sen. Alex Padilla (D-CA), Sen. Edward Markey (D-MA)

Name: Veteran and Beginning Farmers Assistance Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill would reauthorize the Appropriate Technology Transfer for Rural Areas program (ATTRA) in the next Farm Bill. The ATTRA sustainable agriculture program provides educational resources, training, technical assistance, and farmer-to-farmer learning networks for producers seeking to expand and diversify their operations.

The bill would increase authorized annual funding for ATTRA by $3.5 million. 

Additionally the bill adds authorizing language that would guide the program towards supporting producers in pursuing soil health approaches to on-farm risk mitigation, by stating: Sec 2 (4)d) "increase on-farm resilience to extreme weather by enhancing soil health and adopting other conservation practices"
Support: [[Press Release https://kuster.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=4088]]
Analysis:
The ATTRA program is geared toward beginning farmers and ranchers, farmer veterans, and producers who are implementing sustainable and regenerative methods, and provides resources, training and technical assistance for these groups.

The program taps the expertise of more than 30 sustainable agriculture specialists across 10 states and is developed and managed by the National Center for Appropriate Technology (NCAT). The majority of funding for ATTRA is through a cooperative agreement with the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Rural Business-Cooperative Service.

Sec 2 (4)d) specifies "increase on-farm resilience to extreme weather by enhancing soil health and adopting other conservation practices"

Reauthorizing the program could help to advance both goals of regeneration and equity.
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Rodney Davis (R-IL-13)
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Commodity Exchanges, Energy, and Credit

Name: White House Conference on Food, Nutrition, Hunger, and Health Act
Summary:
This bill would convene a second national White House conference on food, nutrition, hunger, and health.

Directs the President to designate a senior executive branch official to serve as Presidential Designee, and to work with Co-chairs (the Secretary of Health and Human Services; the Secretary of Agriculture; and the Secretary of the Treasury) to plan, conduct and convene the Conference, which would take place not later than 18 months after the selection of a Policy Committee (not later than June 30, 2022). Among the responsibilities of the Policy Committee would be to provide a final report of findings and recommendations for administrative and legislative action to Congress and the President within 180 days after the Conference adjourns.

The Conference would be charged with identifying viable solutions for ending hunger in the United States by 2030, reducing by 1⁄2 the level of nutrition insecurity by 2025, and reducing by 1⁄2 the level of diet-related illnesses by 2030; as well as reviewing "the economic opportunities for independent farmers and ranchers to provide healthy food to their communities"; among other purposes. 

The bill authorizes $2.5 million annually for each of the fiscal years during which the Conference is planned and held.
Support:
The bill is supported by the Academy Of Nutrition and Dietetics, American Sustainable Business Council, Center for Food Safety, Earthjustice, Fair Food Network, Farm Aid, Foodshed Alliance, Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy, National Farm to School Network, National Farmers Union, National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition, National Young Farmers Coalition, Rural Coalition, Slow Food USA, and Tufts University, among others (view full list of endorsing organizations [[here https://www.booker.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/wh_list.pdf]]).

Booker [[Press Release https://www.booker.senate.gov/news/press/booker-braun-mcgovern-and-walorski-introduce-bipartisan-bicameral-bill-that-would-convene-a-white-house-conference-on-food-nutrition-hunger-and-health]]
Analysis:
The first such conference was held in 1969 under President Nixon, and culminated in the creation and expansion of programs such as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children (WIC), and the National School Breakfast and Lunch Program. 

The proposed second conference would "take a whole-of-government approach to ending hunger and combatting nutrition insecurity in America, featuring diverse voices and those with lived experience. The conference would also explore weaknesses within the current food system, highlighting the fragility created by hyper-consolidation that has led to fewer choices for consumers and economic insecurity for farmers, ranchers, and rural communities, many of which are now considered food deserts." (from Booker's press release). 

Sec. 2 contains a useful set of findings on current food security, hunger, health and nutrition issuses in the United States; including, for example, finding (6)(A), identifying "the fragility and importance of the food system as a national security issue and making clear that a diverse local and regional food system is essential to the resilience of the United States".

The Conference could be an opportunity to place the national spotlight on the connections between soil health and human health, food and nutritional security; and to increase support for producers to build soil health, ressulting in a more resilient food system and economic opportunities for farmers and ranchers, as well as reduced food insecurity, insufficient nutrition and disease.

Note the conference is planned for September 2022. Recommendations would likely interact with and inform the provisions of the 2023 Farm Bill. The effectiveness of recommendations made as a result of the Conference would depend on robust funding commitments being attached to them.

Name: White House Conference on Food, Nutrition, Hunger, and Health Act
Summary:
This bill would convene a second national White House conference on food, nutrition, hunger, and health.

Directs the President to designate a senior executive branch official to serve as Presidential Designee, and to work with Co-chairs (the Secretary of Health and Human Services; the Secretary of Agriculture; and the Secretary of the Treasury) to plan, conduct and convene the Conference, which would take place not later than 18 months after the selection of a Policy Committee (not later than June 30, 2022). Among the responsibilities of the Policy Committee would be to provide a final report of findings and recommendations for administrative and legislative action to Congress and the President within 180 days after the Conference adjourns.

The Conference would be charged with identifying viable solutions for ending hunger in the United States by 2030, reducing by 1⁄2 the level of nutrition insecurity by 2025, and reducing by 1⁄2 the level of diet-related illnesses by 2030; as well as reviewing "the economic opportunities for independent farmers and ranchers to provide healthy food to their communities"; among other purposes. 

The bill authorizes $2.5 million annually for each of the fiscal years during which the Conference is planned and held.
Support:
The bill is supported by the Academy Of Nutrition and Dietetics, American Sustainable Business Council, Center for Food Safety, Earthjustice, Fair Food Network, Farm Aid, Foodshed Alliance, Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy, National Farm to School Network, National Farmers Union, National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition, National Young Farmers Coalition, Rural Coalition, Slow Food USA, and Tufts University, among others (view full list of endorsing organizations [[here https://www.booker.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/wh_list.pdf]]).

Booker [[Press Release https://www.booker.senate.gov/news/press/booker-braun-mcgovern-and-walorski-introduce-bipartisan-bicameral-bill-that-would-convene-a-white-house-conference-on-food-nutrition-hunger-and-health]]
Analysis:
The first such conference was held in 1969 under President Nixon, and culminated in the creation and expansion of programs such as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children (WIC), and the National School Breakfast and Lunch Program. 

The proposed second conference would "take a whole-of-government approach to ending hunger and combatting nutrition insecurity in America, featuring diverse voices and those with lived experience. The conference would also explore weaknesses within the current food system, highlighting the fragility created by hyper-consolidation that has led to fewer choices for consumers and economic insecurity for farmers, ranchers, and rural communities, many of which are now considered food deserts." (from Booker's press release). 

Sec. 2 contains a useful set of findings on current food security, hunger, health and nutrition issuses in the United States; including, for example, finding (6)(A), identifying "the fragility and importance of the food system as a national security issue and making clear that a diverse local and regional food system is essential to the resilience of the United States".

The Conference could be an opportunity to place the national spotlight on the connections between soil health and human health, food and nutritional security; and to increase support for producers to build soil health, ressulting in a more resilient food system and economic opportunities for farmers and ranchers, as well as reduced food insecurity, insufficient nutrition and disease.

Note the conference is planned for September 2022. Recommendations would likely interact with and inform the provisions of the 2023 Farm Bill. The effectiveness of recommendations made as a result of the Conference would depend on robust funding commitments being attached to them.
Cosponsors (R): Sen. Mike Braun (R-IN)
Agencies: Dept. of Health and Human Services; Dept of Agriculture; Dept. of the Treasury

Name: School Food Recovery Act of 2021
Summary: This bill would establish a new program at USDA to provide grants to schools working on food waste reduction projects. Schools would be eligible if they participate in the National School Lunch Program or the School Breakfast Program. This funding would support capacity-building and implementation of food waste measurement and reduction programs in schools. Eligible grant activities would include food waste measurement and reporting, prevention, education, and reduction projects, including purchasing equipment and providing training. The federal grants would not exceed 75% of the total cost of the project.
Support:
The bill is supported by the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics, the FoodCorps, Harvard Law School Food Law and Policy Clinic, the Natural Resources Defense Council, and the World Wildlife Fund.

[[Press Release https://pingree.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=3852]]
Analysis: The reduction of food waste is a significant component of increasing the sustainability and resilience of the food system, and schools represent an important leverage point for action on this issue.

Name: Build Back Better Act
Summary:
The Build Back Better Act is the $1.75 trillion Democrat budget reconciliation bill. This bill provides for reconciliation pursuant to S. Con. Res. 14, a budget resolution which sets forth the congressional budget for the United States Government for FY2022 and sets forth the appropriate budgetary levels for fiscal years 2023 through 2031.

This budget framework, introduced by Senate Democrats, proposes $1.75 trillion in new spending to enact the "Build Back Better" agenda, including a total of $89.44 billion for agriculture.

House Democrats on 11/3 unveiled [[new legislative text https://rules.house.gov/sites/democrats.rules.house.gov/files/BILLS-117HR5376RH-RCP117-18.pdf]] for the package, which includes $28.29 billion for conservation programs (slightly higher than the original $28B). According to Politico: "Climate-related farm and forestry programs still make up the bulk of ag money in the bill, including programs that incentivize farmers, ranchers and forest landowners to adopt emissions-mitigating practices."

See House Agriculture Committee [[fact sheet https://agriculture.house.gov/uploadedfiles/house_agriculture_build_back_better_act_provisions_.pdf]] on the ag provisions in the bill.

NOTE: This bill was reintroduced and passed as the Inflation Reduction Act (see passed tab).
Support: See "[[Reconciliation Tracker https://www.crfb.org/blogs/fy-2022-reconciliation-tracker]]"
Analysis:
This bill allocates a total of $89.44 billion to agriculture, which includes the $28.29 billion for conservation, as well as $2 billion for ag research, $18 billion for rural investment, $27.15 billion for forestry programs, and $12 billion in debt relief for farmers.

The $28.29 billion for conservation programs nearly doubles current funding levels, paralleling asks from a broad coalition of farming, food, ag business and nonprofit organizations. Conservation programs currently receive about $6 billion per year for the current five-year cycle (or $30 billion). This investment would significantly expand access to the currently oversubscribed conservation programs such as CSP and EQIP. Democrats have touted the amount as "the largest investment in conservation since the Dust Bowl." That these provisions were not cut, when many others were, reflects a relatively new understanding by policymakers of the huge role ag and forestry will play in reaching our emissions reductions goals.

The same broad coalition is pushing for a doubling of funding for training and technical support to help producers transition to a more resilient agriculture. The current addition of $200 million for conservation technical assistance (CTA) falls well short of doubling technical assistance, netting in at under 1/3 of the current $734 million annual CTA budget.

The bill has been held up by ongoing Democrat negotiations over the total cost and contents, since its passage requires support from every Democratic Senator. Groups are pushing for the passage of the bill with the full provisions for conservation (see Land Core's blog memo). They are joined by Congressional leaders, such as Reps. Pingree and Spanberger, who sent a letter on 10/18 urging Democratic leadership to keep $28 billion for conservation in the bill. 

The Build Back Better Act passed in the House on November 19. Was stalled in the Senate. Reintroduced and passed as the Inflation Reduction Act (See Passed tab).
Status:
Passed in House. 

House - 11/19/2021 Motion to reconsider laid on the table.

Name: Watershed Results Act
Summary:
This bill would authorize the Secretary of the Interior, in coordination with the Department of Agriculture and the Environmental Protection Agency, to carry out 2-5 large-scale watershed pilot projects.

The bill provides annual appropriations of $15 million for each Federal agency, as well as $15 million to implement each watershed pilot along with $2 million for each watershed pilot to carry out advance watershed analytics.
Support:
The bill is supported by the Farmer's Conservation Alliance, Family Farm Alliance, the Iowa Soybean Association, the Soil and Water Outcomes Fund, and others.

[[Press Release https://www.wyden.senate.gov/news/press-releases/wyden-introduces-bill-to-improve-watershed-resilience-and-health-]]
Analysis:
Increasing watershed resiliency can provide important water management and quality outcomes for farmers and downstream communities.

The pilots are to achieve outcome-based goals, including: (A) a quantifiable reduction in nutrient or sediment runoff; (B) a quantifiable reduction in thermal load; (C) a quantifiable increase in dissolved oxygen; (D) a quantifiable increase in surface water or groundwater that functionally benefits fish and wildlife species; or (E) any other quantifiable benefit identified by the management team as being desirable in the applicable watershed.

Name: Fresh Produce Procurement Act of 2021
Summary: To direct the Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the Agricultural Marketing Service and in consultation with the Food and Nutrition Service, to enter into contracts to provide individuals dealing with food and nutrition insecurity family-friendly fresh produce, and for other purposes.
Support: [[Press Release https://delauro.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/delauro-coalition-advocates-announce-bill-increase-usda-fresh-produce]]
Analysis:
This bill aims to increase local procurement of fresh produce by stating the makeup of the produce includes "locally grown fruits and vegetables where geographically and seasonally possible, as determined by the Secretary", but otherwise grown in the United States. The bill limits suppliers to small businesses (as defined by the SBA) including growers, packers, distributors, or food-hubs; nonprofit organizataions; and cooperatives. 

Soil health advocates could ask for stipulations that the program prioritize purchasing produce from producers improving soil health, through outlined practices. 

There is no funding specified in the legislation for the program to be implemented.

Name: Small Farm to School Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill would create a pilot program under the National School Lunch Program to provide States and tribal organizations with a higher rate of reimbursement for sourcing school lunches from small farmers.

Authorizes $20 million for fiscal year 2021 and each succeeding fiscal year, to remain available until expended for this "Locally Produced Foods Pilot Program". The program would distribute grants to States and tribal organizations (with a matching requirement) to provide an additional 2.5 cents reimbursement to each school food authority located in such State for each qualified lunch served by such school food authority.

This is the reintroduction of [[H.R.7831 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/7831/text]] - the Small Farm to School Act of 2021
Support: [[Press Release https://delgado.house.gov/media/press-releases/rep-delgado-reintroduces-bipartisan-small-farm-school-act]]
Analysis:
Providing incentives to school food services could support markets for fresh, locally produced food. As the bill states, "Research suggests that providing financial incentives to school food service directors for purchasing of locally produced foods, can result in an overall positive economic effect for farmers and local economies."

The bill defines locally produced as food that is “(i) raised, produced, and distributed in a locality that is less than 400 miles from the point of sale of such food, or (ii) raised, produced, distributed, and sold within the same State, territory, or Tribal land." 

There is little detail provided on requirements for procurement beyond the "locally produced" definition (eg. no information about size of farm, management practices). Advocates could call for procurement requirements to prioritize farms using soil health practices, to support local markets for regenerative products.

The pilot program gives priority to States or Indian tribal organizations with a "demonstrated commitment to farm-to-school activities" (which include planting (i) Planting and maintenance of farms or gardens, (ii) Procurement from local agricultural producers, or (iii) Educational activities relating to agriculture, nutrition, or food).
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Chellie Pingree (D-ME-1), Rep. Jahana Hayes (D-CT-5), Rep. Al Lawson (D-FL-5), Rep. Kaiali'i Kahele (D-HI-2)

Name: 21st Century Civilian Conservation and Climate Corps Act
Summary:
This bill would authorize the President to establish the Civilian Conservation and Climate Corps "as a means of providing gainful employment to unemployed and underemployed youth through the performance of useful public work."

Rep. Kaptur originally introduced the 21st Century Civilian Conservation Corps Act in 2009 and has since reintroduced her bill in every subsequent session of Congress.
Analysis:
This bill focuses mostly on forest management (among the eligible projects is "(4) the prevention of forest fires, floods, and soil erosion;").

The bill focuses on projects on public land (while some of the other CCC proposals target private lands and agriculture), with the following exception: (e) Inclusion Of Other Lands.—The President may extend the activities of the Civilian Conservation and Climate Corps to lands owned by a political subdivision of a State and lands in private ownership, but only for the purpose of conducting such kinds of cooperation work as are otherwise authorized by law and consistent with the program’s purposes.

The bill appropriates such funds as are necessary to carry out the purposes of this Act through the end of the fifth complete fiscal year following its enactment.

This is one of multple conservation corps plans that have been proposed in various other bills. Funding for conservation corps activities are included in the Build Back Better proposal (Democrats' $3.5 trillion reconciliation bill).
Cosponsors (D): Del. Eleanor Holmes Norton (D-DC-At Large), Rep. Gwen Moore (D-WI-4), Rep. Janice Schakowsky (D-IL-9), Rep. Chrissy Houlahan (D-PA-6)

Name: Restore Environmental Vitality and Improve Volatile Economy by the Civilian Conservation Corps (REVIVE the CCC) Act of 2021
Summary:
To establish a Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) to create jobs to carry out conservation activities, by amending the National and Community Service Act of 1990.

This bill would authorize eligible host entities to design Corps projects, host Corps members and implement projects on public and private lands. Eligible entities include farmers, local conservation districts, State or local offices of the Cooperative Extension program (or equivalent Tribal office), a State agency with jurisdiction over agriculture, a land trust, an agriculture or related nonprofit organization, among others.
Support:
This bill has been supported by Chesapeake Bay Foundation, National Wildlife Federation, National Young Farmers Coalition, Pasa Sustainable Agriculture, and The Corps Network, among others.

Casey [[Press Release https://www.casey.senate.gov/news/releases/casey-introduces-legislation-to-renew-job-creation-revitalize-civilian-conservation-corps]] / Lamb [[Press Release https://lamb.house.gov/media/press-releases/lamb-wild-evans-and-kuster-introduce-legislation-revitalize-civilian]]
Analysis:
This bill would allow individual farmers, as eligible host entities, to receive funds to host Corps members to carry out conservation projects, increasing capacity and support for farmers implementing conservation practices. The eligibility of private lands to be considered as eligible worksites for Corps projects are to be determined in relation to the public conservation benefit of the proposed project.

Eligible activities for service positions with respect to agriculture include grazing management, grassland restoration, soil health management, silvopasture, land and water quality restoration, and a range of others with benefits for soil health (see list of eligible activities).

Sec. 166 (i)(2)(B)(i) allows funds received through this program to contribute towards the implementation of an agricultural conservation practice for which funding has been obtained through another USDA conservation program, provided that the sum total does not exceed the cost of implementation.

Sec. 166 authorizes the use of Conservation Technical Assistance (CTA) to be used on Corps projects on private land when relevant, and adjacent public land when relevant to the project. CTA provides critical training and support to help producers adopt conservation practices, and this provision could create an opportunity to expand access to assistance.

Sec. 3 authorizes an On-Farm Apprenticeship Program, providing funding for experienced farmers to participate and host a Corps member. By directing the host site to provide training, technical instruction and education related to Corps service positions, the on-farm projects would create a unique opportunity to train beginning farmers. The bill also gives priority to projects on farms managed by beginning farmers or ranchers, or socially disadvantaged farmers or ranchers.

No specific amount authorized for implementing this bill, other than "such sums as may be necessary".

While there are multiple conservation corps plans that have been proposed in other bills, this proposal would have a greater direct impact on soil health and on-farm conservation than many of the others. The White House originally included a $10 billion fund to establish a Civilian Climate Corps as part of the American Jobs Plan, and the Senate Agriculture Committee has been instructed to establish a CCC as part of the $135 billion allocated to the agriculture committee in Senate Democrats' $3.5 trillion reconciliation package (as much as $20-30 billion could be allocated to the CCC through the reconciliation bill). Soil health and farmer advocates can support the inclusion of language from this bill in the CCC plan as part of the Ag Committee's policy proposal for the reconciliation bill.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Susan Wild (D-PA-7), Rep. Dwight Evans (D-PA-3), Rep. Ann Kuster (D-NH-2)
Committees: Education and Labor; Ways and Means

Name: Urban Agriculture and Community Food Security Act
Summary:
This bill would establish two new urban agriculture programs: 1) The Urban Agriculture Conservation Easement Program, authorized at $20 million annually, would protect urban lands for food production and conservation and ensure affordable long-term access to lands for agricultural uses; and 2) The Urban Agriculture Microentrepreneur Assistance Program, authorized at $3 million annually, would provide small-dollar loans and grants to support the development and ongoing success of urban agriculture microenterprises.  

The legislation would also provide a $15 million annual boost to the Community Food Project Grant Program, which is designed to fight food insecurity in low-income communities.
Support:
The bill is supported by the Illinois Stewardship Alliance, Urban Growers Collective, Advocates for Urban Agriculture, and the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition (NSAC).

[[Press Release https://rush.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rush-introduces-legislation-establish-two-new-urban-agriculture]]
Analysis:
The Urban Agriculture Conservation Easement Program includes conservation goals by aiming to "protect the agricultural use and future viability, and related conservation values, of eligible land" in urban communities. 

In addition, the program provides technical assistance for "the conservation of natural resources", as well as cost share assistance to "protect the agricultural use, including grazing, and related conservation and food security values of eligible land" - especially for beginning farmers or ranchers, and socially disadvantaged farmers or ranchers.

According to Wes King of the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition (NSAC), the bill would help address two key barriers to realizing community food security and entrepreneurial potential of community-based urban agriculture - stable long-term access to land and scale-appropriate financial capital. 

This could be an opportunity for the soil health community to partner with urban agriculture, local food and food security movements. Advocates can call for increased access to education around soil health practices as part of the programs.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Gwen Moore (D-WI-4), Rep. Marcy Kaptur (D-OH-9)
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Conservation and Forestry

Name: Tribal Wildlife Corridors Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill would direct the Department of Interior to establish Tribal Wildlife Corridors, by providing funds to Indian Tribes to create wildlife migration pathways and implement conservation measures on tribal lands.

The bill would authorize $50 million for FY2022 and each year thereafter.
Support: Luján [[Press Release https://www.lujan.senate.gov/press-releases/lujan-introduces-legislation-to-protect-tribal-wildlife-corridors-and-support-wildlife-management-efforts/]]
Analysis:
In addition to funding provided through the grant program, DOI would also be required to provide Indian Tribes with technical assistance relating to the "establishment, management, and expansion of a Tribal Wildlife Corridor, including assistance with accessing wildlife data and working with voluntary private landowners to access Federal and State programs to improve wildlife habitat and connectivity on non-Federal land."

The bill could support habitat restoration on tribal lands, though there is little detail provided on the types of activities that would be eligible for funding under the grant program.
