Name: A concurrent resolution setting forth the congressional budget for the United States Government for fiscal year 2022 and setting forth the appropriate budgetary levels for fiscal years 2023 through 2031.
Summary:
This concurrent resolution sets forth the congressional budget for the United States Government for FY2022 and sets forth the appropriate budgetary levels for fiscal years 2023 through 2031.

This budget framework, introduced by Senate Democrats, proposes $3.5 trillion in new spending to enact the "Build Back Better" agenda.
Support:
Sanders [[Press Release https://www.sanders.senate.gov/press-releases/news-senate-budget-chairman-sanders-and-majority-leader-schumer-introduce-historic-budget-resolution/]]

[[Article https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/24/house-passes-budget-resolution-advances-infrastructure-bill.html]] regarding budget resolution passage
Analysis:
This $3.5 trillion budget resolution originally allocated $135 billion to agriculture, outlining top-line numbers and instructing committees (like the Agriculture Committee) to propose spending plans through the reconciliation process. This 8/9 memo to Senators (from Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer's office) instructed the Senate Agriculture Committee to focus on: Agriculture conservation, drought, and forestry programs to help reduce carbon emissions and prevent wildfires; rural development and rural co-op clean energy investments; agricultural climate research and research infrastructure; Civilian Climate Corps funding; child nutrition; and debt relief. The resolution also allows for additional new budget authority for wildfire suppression activities.

A broad coalition of farming, food, ag business and nonprofit organizations called on Congress to use these funds to double the investment in USDA conservation programs and double technical assistance funding to help producers build a soil health. Conservation programs currently receive about $6 billion per year for the current five-year cycle (or $30 billion), which still leaves many of the most needed programs - like EQIP and CSP - oversubscribed, and USDA woefully understaffed to help with technical assistance and training. Doubling the conservation budget would provide critical access to these programs as well as the needed training and support to help producers transition a more resilient agriculture.

The House Agriculture Committee held a two-part markup session (9/10 and 9/13) to review the specific legislation that will determine how this funding is structured. See the bill text and amendments related to these markup sessions here. The committee approved nearly $66 billion in funding for agricultural research, rural investment and forestry programs (see a breakdown of this funding here). In advance of the House Budget Committee's Sept. 25 markup of the $3.5 trillion package, the committee released draft text of the bill, and Democrats are circulating a $28 billion plan to expand existing farm blll conservation programs.

House and Senate Democrats are working to hammer out the package’s details this week and get it to the House for a possible vote by Sept. 27.

The agreement calls for the $3.5 trillion in long-term investments to be fully offset by a combination of new tax revenues, health care savings, and long-term economic growth."
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Patty Murray (D-WA), Sen. Ron Wyden (D-OR), Sen. Debbie Stabenow (D-MI), Sen. Mark Warner (D-VA), Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-OR), Sen. Timothy Kaine (D-VA), Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD), Sen. Ben Ray Luján (D-NM), Sen. Alex Padilla (D-CA)
Status: 8/24/2021 Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 601, S. Con. Res. 14 is considered passed House.

Name: Senate Agriculture Appropriations Act of 2022
Summary:
Making appropriations for Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies programs for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2022, and for other purposes.

The Senate FY2022 Agriculture-FDA spending bill provides $169.6 billion total and $25.86 billion in discretionary funding for farm and food programs. See [[bill report https://www.appropriations.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/Agriculture,%20Rural%20Development,%20Food%20and%20Drug%20Administration,%20and%20Related%20Agencies%20Report.pdf]].
Support: Senate Appropriations Committee [[Press Release https://www.appropriations.senate.gov/news/fy22-agriculture-appropriations-bill-advanced-by-subcommittee]]
Analysis:
Soil health specific provisions in the House bill would include increased funding for NRCS Conservations Operations ($900 million, with $759.813 million of this for Conservation Technical Assistance or CTA), funding for the Risk Management Agency to “study the actuarial soundness of possible new climate change related crop insurance products”, and increased funding for research (including $450 million for AFRI and $50 million for SARE). Meanwhile, the Senate bill provides $937.964 million for NRCS Conservation Operations ($784.813 million of this for CTA), $3.6 billion for agricultural research (including $445 million for AFRI and $45 million for SARE), among other provisions.

The House bill report recognizes "the need to enhance access to lending for mixed use land including crop and pastureland" and encourages USDA to "assess options for lending for regenerative farms that include crops and animals" under the Farm Service Agency (FSA), which is allocated a budget of $1.47 billion. The Senate bill allocates $1.178 billion for FSA.

The Senate bill provides $7.03 billion in disaster payments to producers for losses during 2020 and 2021, including $750 million for livestock losses.

The House bill report contains language directing NRCS to establish Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP) Bundles; and to increase support for partnerships that provide grazing lands conservation technical services, ongoing efforts of the Soil Health initiative linking soil health and cover crop management, and other initiatives. The Committee recognizes "the role of programs like the Environmental Quality Incentives Program and Conservation Innovation Grants in providing financial assistance to farms interested in improving soil health. NRCS is encouraged to continue supporting farmers that embrace regenerative agriculture practices, including continued investments in soil health demonstration projects." Similarly, the Senate bill report also provides $20 million for the Grazing Lands Conservation Initiative, $15 million for a Working Land Resilience Program, and "recognizes that improving soil health on agricultural lands is key to achieving both meaningful conservation and economic benefits for producers", among other provisions.

The House act also allocates $84.4 million to the Soil Surveys Program, stating: "The Committee recognizes the need for a regular soil carbon survey to improve the effectiveness of environmental incentive programs and elucidate the relationships between soil carbon content and agricultural yields, water and fertilizer-use efficiency, climate resilience, and other soil health metrics. To the extent possible using existing resources, the Committee encourages the Soil Surveys Program to measure, monitor, and model soil carbon sequestration on agricultural lands."

These are highlights. See appropriations charts for FY2022 Senate and House Ag Appropriations from NSAC.
Status: The Senate Appropriations Committee advanced S.2599 during a mark-up held on 8/4. Placed on the Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 113.

Name: Future of Agricultural Resiliency and Modernization (FARM) Act
Summary:
This bill would establish two new grant programs at USDA to help farmers implement "climate-friendly farming methods and technologies": FARM Fund, funded with $2.5 billion, to provide grants to "help farmers carry out projects that further agricultural resiliency and modernization". Pyrolysis Program, funded with $25 million, to support at least 10 pilot programs to convert tree nut by-products into biocarbon products that can be reused.

View [[One Page Summary https://harder.house.gov/sites/harder.house.gov/files/FARM%20Act%20One%20Pager%20-%20Updated.pdf]] 

Reintroduction of [[H.R.7482 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/7482/text]] - FARM Act of 2020
Support:
The bill is supported by the National Milk Producers Federation, League of Conservation Voters, Almond Alliance of California, and others.

[[Press Release https://harder.house.gov/media/press-releases/harder-introduces-landmark-legislation-help-farmers-lead-climate-change-0]]
Analysis:
It is worth noting that the FARM Fund, although it could support many conservation practices, has very few limitations on how the funding could be spent, with the identified buckets sufficiently broad to allow for the funding of a wide array of activities that could be unrelated to soil health and conservation (see the full list of eligible activities).

Further, a wide range of entities are listed as eligible for funding under the FARM Fund, including Federal agencies, States, local governments, transit agencies, or "any other entity, as determined by the Secretary". This could result in extending a new pot of funding to entities that are currently ineligible for conservation funding under USDA. The list of entities is sufficiently broad that it is unclear how much of the funding would reach farmers.

The funding could be directed towards existing, well-developed programs, such as the Conservation Innovation Grants (CIG) program, which already have broad conservation mandates.

While limited details are provided with respect to the Pyrolysis Program, it appears to be geared towards creating opportunities for nut producers to monetize current byproducts.

Name: Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) Flexibility Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill would allow for emergency haying of Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) acres during the primary nesting season in response to drought and other weather-related disaster events. 

'Emergency' is defined as D2 (severe drought) on US Drought Monitor, 40% forage loss in the county, or when "the Secretary, in coordination with the State technical committee, determines that the program can assist in the response to a natural disaster event without permanent damage to the established cover."

Emergency haying is not currently not allowed in the CRP until after the primary nesting season, which ends August 1 in South Dakota, Minnesota, and North Dakota. The CRP Flexibility Act would address this by allowing emergency haying on CRP acres before August 1 when certain conditions are met and in consultation with the state technical committee.

This is a bicameral bill, accompanied by H.R.4710 in the House.
Support: Thune [[Press Release https://www.thune.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2021/7/thune-smith-johnson-craig-introduce-bipartisan-bicameral-legislation-to-provide-needed-flexibility-for-emergency-crp-haying]]
Analysis:
This bill is designed to provide forage (in the form of hay) for livestock during emergency situations. CRP impact could be increased by allowing holistically-managed planned grazing on CRP land (with ranchers submitting plans prior to receiving grazing permits) to prevent land from going fallow. 

A related idea for increasing CRP impact would be to develop a grazing program on enrolled CRP land that establishes a supply chain between cow-calf operations grazing on public and private land in the western U.S., and CRP grazing permittees, which will have the effect of diverting animals from feedlots to pasture, which will increase domestic production of grass-fed beef, a market for which there is significant demand in this country that we are not currently meeting domestically.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Tina Smith (D-MN), Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-MN)
Cosponsors (R): Sen. Mike Rounds (R-SD), Sen. John Hoeven (R-ND), Sen. Kevin Cramer (R-ND)

Name: Agriculture Environmental Stewardship Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill would provide a 30 percent tax credit to farmers and rural electric cooperatives to help offset the upfront costs associated with building biodigester systems

Allows energy tax credits through 2023 for investments in (1) qualified biogas property, or (2) qualified manure resource recovery property. Qualified biogas property comprises a system that (1) uses anaerobic digesters or other specified processes to convert biomass into a gas which is at least 52% methane, and (2) captures the gas for use as a fuel. The term includes property that cleans and conditions the gas for use as a fuel. Qualified manure resource recovery property comprises a system that uses specified processes to recover the nutrients nitrogen and phosphorus from a non-treated digestate or animal manure by reducing or separating at least 50% of the nutrients, excluding any reductions during the incineration, storage, composting, or field application of the non-treated digestate or animal manure. The term also includes certain processing equipment.
Support:
The bill has been supported by the Ohio Farm Bureau, Food and Agriculture Climate Alliance (FACA), the National Milk Producers Federation, and the American Biogas Council.
 
Brown [[Press Release https://www.brown.senate.gov/newsroom/press/release/increase-biogas-production-rural-america]]
Analysis: The bill would help to fund the construction of more on-farm biodigester systems, which can help farmers reduce input costs and the use of synthetic fertilizers.

Name: Restore Environmental Vitality and Improve Volatile Economy by the Civilian Conservation Corps (REVIVE the CCC) Act of 2021
Summary:
To establish a Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) to create jobs to carry out conservation activities, by amending the National and Community Service Act of 1990.

This bill would authorize eligible host entities to design Corps projects, host Corps members and implement projects on public and private lands. Eligible entities include farmers, local conservation districts, State or local offices of the Cooperative Extension program (or equivalent Tribal office), a State agency with jurisdiction over agriculture, a land trust, an agriculture or related nonprofit organization, among others.

See [[bill summary https://www.casey.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/summary_revive_the_ccc_act_of_2021.pdf]].
Support:
This bill has been supported by Chesapeake Bay Foundation, National Wildlife Federation, National Young Farmers Coalition, Pasa Sustainable Agriculture, and The Corps Network, among others.

Casey [[Press Release https://www.casey.senate.gov/news/releases/casey-introduces-legislation-to-renew-job-creation-revitalize-civilian-conservation-corps]] / Lamb [[Press Release https://lamb.house.gov/media/press-releases/lamb-wild-evans-and-kuster-introduce-legislation-revitalize-civilian]]
Analysis:
This bill would allow individual farmers, as eligible host entities, to receive funds to host Corps members to carry out conservation projects, increasing capacity and support for farmers implementing conservation practices. The eligibility of private lands to be considered as eligible worksites for Corps projects are to be determined in relation to the public conservation benefit of the proposed project.

Eligible activities for service positions with respect to agriculture include grazing management, grassland restoration, soil health management, silvopasture, land and water quality restoration, and a range of others with benefits for soil health (see list of eligible activities).

Sec. 166 (i)(2)(B)(i) allows funds received through this program to contribute towards the implementation of an agricultural conservation practice for which funding has been obtained through another USDA conservation program, provided that the sum total does not exceed the cost of implementation.

Sec. 166 authorizes the use of Conservation Technical Assistance (CTA) to be used on Corps projects on private land when relevant, and adjacent public land when relevant to the project. CTA provides critical training and support to help producers adopt conservation practices, and this provision could create an opportunity to expand access to assistance.

Sec. 3 authorizes an On-Farm Apprenticeship Program, providing funding for experienced farmers to participate and host a Corps member. By directing the host site to provide training, technical instruction and education related to Corps service positions, the on-farm projects would create a unique opportunity to train beginning farmers. The bill also gives priority to projects on farms managed by beginning farmers or ranchers, or socially disadvantaged farmers or ranchers.

No specific amount authorized for implementing this bill, other than "such sums as may be necessary".

While there are multiple conservation corps plans that have been proposed in other bills, this proposal would have a greater direct impact on soil health and on-farm conservation than many of the others. The White House originally included a $10 billion fund to establish a Civilian Climate Corps as part of the American Jobs Plan, and the Senate Agriculture Committee has been instructed to establish a CCC as part of the $135 billion allocated to the agriculture committee in Senate Democrats' $3.5 trillion reconciliation package (as much as $20-30 billion could be allocated to the CCC through the reconciliation bill). Soil health and farmer advocates can support the inclusion of language from this bill in the CCC plan as part of the Ag Committee's policy proposal for the reconciliation bill.

Name: Cultivating Organic Matter through the Promotion Of Sustainable Techniques (COMPOST) Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill would amend the Food Security Act of 1985 to direct USDA to designate composting as a conservation practice and a conservation activity, to add composting as an eligible practice under the Conservation Stewardship Program and Environmental Quality Incentives Program, and to develop a composting practice standard. The bill would also establish a program to award grants and loan guarantees for projects that expand access to food waste composting.

Reintroduction of [[H.R.6023 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/6023/text]] - COMPOST Act of 2020
Support:
This bill is supported by the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition (NSAC), US Composting Council, Institute for Local Self-Reliance, US Green Building Council, Harvard Food Law and Policy Center, Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC), and others.

Brownley [[Press Release https://juliabrownley.house.gov/brownley-kuster-pingree-booker-introduce-bills-to-incentivize-sustainable-practices-in-food-consumption/]]
Analysis:
By designating composting as a conservation practice, this bill would enable farmers who produce and utilize compost to receive financial support and technical assistance through the Farm Bill's conservation programs, such as the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP) and the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP). This, in turn, would increase the use of compost and improve soil health outcomes on farms, resulting in increased production and quality. 

This bill would increase the demand for compost, which would not only be a source of potential revenue for urban producers of compost from city food waste, but would also encourage municipal waste diversion from urban centers, create new jobs, reduce emissions from landfills, and bridge the urban-rural divide.

Although it seems clear that the NRCS could/should just make a determination to add composting as a conservation practice without congressional intervention, this bill is likely responding to the fact that they have not yet and is attempting to require them to do so.

There is an existing NRCS practice that covers the building of compost facilities, but does not address the actual application of compost for soil health, nutrient management, resilience, water quality, etc. Some of the language from the bill may be useful to take directly to NRCS to advocate for broader compost use policies. 

New in this version of the act: The bill would create new USDA grant and loan guarantee programs and authorize $2 billion over 10 years for composting infrastructure projects, including both large-scale composting facilities as well as farm, home, or community-based projects.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Tina Smith (D-MN)
Agencies: U.S. Dept. of Agriculture; Environmental Protection Agency

It establishes a new directive for Science and Engineering Solutions and provides additional funding for the National Science Foundation.

While not the main focus of the bill, for stakeholders with international partners, this bill includes an example of how the US can support soil health-focused agricultural development abroad.

U.S. Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo called the legislative package “the biggest investment in 50 years” to boost America’s competitiveness, manufacturing capacity and research and development. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer called the counterpart Senate bill one of the most significant pieces of legislation passed in a long time and said it would have a huge impact on the American economy and jobs.

"House lawmakers passed the bill along party lines, and it now heads to the Senate to be reconciled with that chamber's bipartisan version, which was approved in June 2021. Name: Recovering America's Wildlife Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill provides funding for (1) the conservation or restoration of wildlife and plant species of greatest conservation need; (2) the wildlife conservation strategies of states, territories, or the District of Columbia; and (3) wildlife conservation education and recreation projects.

The Department of the Interior must use a portion of the funding for a grant program for "innovative recovery efforts for species of greatest conservation need, species listed as endangered or threatened species, or the habitats of such species."

In addition, the bill requires certain revenues generated from fees and penalties for violations of environmental requirements to be used as a source for the funding.

This is the reintroduction of [[H.R.3742 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/3742/text]] - Recovering America's Wildlife Act of 2019 (A version of this legislation was included as a bipartisan amendment to [[H.R.2 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/2/text]], the Moving Forward Act).

Heinrich [[Press Release https://www.heinrich.senate.gov/press-releases/heinrich-blunt-introduce-bipartisan-recovering-americas-wildlife-act]]

Name: Farm System Reform Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill seeks to reduce the expansion of large concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFO). The Farm System Reform Act of 2021 would:

1) Place an immediate moratorium on new and expanding large CAFOs, and phase out by 2040 the largest CAFOs as defined by the Environmental Protection Agency; 2) Hold corporate integrators responsible for pollution and other harm caused by CAFOs; 3) Provide a voluntary buyout for farmers who want to transition out of operating a CAFO; 4) Strengthen the Packers and Stockyards Act to protect family farmers and ranchers, including: a) Prohibit the use of unfair tournament or ranking systems for paying contract growers; b) Protect livestock and poultry farmers from retaliation; c) Create market transparency and protect farmers and ranchers from predatory purchasing practices; 5) Restore mandatory country-of-origin labeling requirements for beef and pork and expand to dairy products; and 6) Prohibit the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) from labeling foreign imported meat products as “Product of USA”"

Reintroduction of [[S.3221 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/3221/text]] - Farm System Reform Act of 2019
Support:
This bill has been endorsed by organizations including the American Agriculture Movement, Family Farm Action, the American Grassfed Association, Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy, Fair Farms, Women Food and Agriculture Network, Family Dairy Farms LLC, American Public Health Association, Food & Water Action, Center for Food Safety, Public Justice Waterkeeper Alliance, Land Stewardship Project, Rural Coalition, and Natural Resources Defense Council, among others. See full list [[here https://www.booker.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/farm_system_reform_act1.pdf]].

Notable Press:  [[The Hill https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/474685-booker-proposes-moratorium-on-expanding-large-factory-farms]], [[Food and Water Watch https://www.foodandwaterwatch.org/2021/07/14/farm-system-reform-act-reintroduced-in-congress-would-ban-new-factory-farming/]], [[Beef Magazine https://www.beefmagazine.com/legislative/legislation-introduced-eliminate-modern-animal-agriculture]], [[The Fern https://thefern.org/ag_insider/booker-introduces-bill-that-would-reshape-livestock-farming/]], and [[Vox https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/2019/12/20/21028200/factory-farms-abuse-workers-animals-and-the-environment-cory-booker-has-a-plan-to-stop-them]]

Booker [[Press Release https://www.booker.senate.gov/news/press/booker-reintroduces-bill-to-reform-farm-system-with-expanded-support-from-farm-labor-environment-public-health-faith-based-and-animal-welfare-groups]] / Khanna [[Press R https://khanna.house.gov/media/press-releases/release-khanna-booker-reintroduce-farm-system-reform-act]]elease
Analysis:
If the bill passes, planned grazing (regenerative management or Adaptive Multi-Paddock Grazing) could be greatly enhanced, with immediate benefits for soil health.

Rather than punishing farmers for past practices, supporting soil health programs can help reduce and reverse adverse impact of farms without requiring them to shut down, but instead transition, their operations as food producers and job creators.

The publicity materials accompanying the introduction of the bill emphasize the negative environmental impacts of CAFOs, particularly with respect to water pollution and runoff. 

Soil health advocates can suggest the addition of language connecting soil health outcomes to water quality. 

Sec. 103(d)(2) broaches the idea of soil health by conditioning eligibility for the Debt Forgiveness program upon, "the use of the easement area for a spray field or land application of manure at rates exceeding crop agronomic requirements for nitrogen and phosphorus." 

The Integrator responsibilities and liabilities outlined in Sec. 104(a)(1) could be amended to include a provision that holds them responsible for soil degradation, which leads to adverse environmental impacts.

Name: House Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2022
Summary:
Making appropriations for Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies programs for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2022, and for other purposes.

The House FY2022 Agriculture-FDA spending bill provides $196.7 billion total and $26.55 billion (an increase of 12% above FY2021) in discretionary funding for farm and food programs. See committee activity [[summary https://appropriations.house.gov/legislation/agriculture-subcommittee-legislative-activity]] and [[bill report https://docs.house.gov/meetings/AP/AP00/20210630/112874/HMKP-117-AP00-20210630-SD005.pdf]].
Support: House Appropriations Committee [[Press Release https://appropriations.house.gov/news/press-releases/appropriations-committee-approves-fiscal-year-2022-agriculture-rural-development]]
Analysis:
Soil health specific provisions in the House bill would include increased funding for NRCS Conservations Operations ($900 million, with $759.813 million of this for Conservation Technical Assistance or CTA), funding for the Risk Management Agency to “study the actuarial soundness of possible new climate change related crop insurance products”, and increased funding for research (including $450 million for AFRI and $50 million for SARE). Meanwhile, the Senate bill provides $937.964 million for NRCS Conservation Operations ($784.813 million of this for CTA), $3.6 billion for agricultural research (including $445 million for AFRI and $45 million for SARE), among other provisions.

The House bill report recognizes "the need to enhance access to lending for mixed use land including crop and pastureland" and encourages USDA to "assess options for lending for regenerative farms that include crops and animals" under the Farm Service Agency (FSA), which is allocated a budget of $1.47 billion. The Senate bill allocates $1.178 billion for FSA.

The Senate bill provides $7.03 billion in disaster payments to producers for losses during 2020 and 2021, including $750 million for livestock losses.

The House bill report contains language directing NRCS to establish Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP) Bundles; and to increase support for partnerships that provide grazing lands conservation technical services, ongoing efforts of the Soil Health initiative linking soil health and cover crop management, and other initiatives. The Committee recognizes "the role of programs like the Environmental Quality Incentives Program and Conservation Innovation Grants in providing financial assistance to farms interested in improving soil health. NRCS is encouraged to continue supporting farmers that embrace regenerative agriculture practices, including continued investments in soil health demonstration projects." Similarly, the Senate bill report also provides $20 million for the Grazing Lands Conservation Initiative, $15 million for a Working Land Resilience Program, and "recognizes that improving soil health on agricultural lands is key to achieving both meaningful conservation and economic benefits for producers", among other provisions.

The House act also allocates $84.4 million to the Soil Surveys Program, stating: "The Committee recognizes the need for a regular soil carbon survey to improve the effectiveness of environmental incentive programs and elucidate the relationships between soil carbon content and agricultural yields, water and fertilizer-use efficiency, climate resilience, and other soil health metrics. To the extent possible using existing resources, the Committee encourages the Soil Surveys Program to measure, monitor, and model soil carbon sequestration on agricultural lands."

These are highlights. See appropriations charts for FY2022 Senate and House Ag Appropriations from NSAC.
Status: On 7/29, the House passed H.R.4502 - the seven-bill minibus appropriations act, which included H.R.4356 as the Agriculture-FDA bill. 8/3 - received in the Senate.

Name: National Climate Service Corps and Careers Network Act of 2021
Summary: This bill amends the National and Community Service Act of 1990 to establish the National Climate Service Corps to supplement the existing Corps programs within Americorps, and establishes a Climate Careers Network to help connect Corps alumni and Americans to other job opportunities that promote climate adaptation, mitigation, and resiliency.
Support:
The bill has been supported by The Corps Network, Great Basin Institute, Friends of Nevada Wilderness, Nevada Wildlife Federation, Conservation Lands Foundation, Nevada Conservation League, the Nevada Chapter of Backcountry Hunters and Anglers, America’s Service Commissions, and the Service Year Alliance. 

Chu [[Press Release https://chu.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-judy-chu-introduces-legislation-create-national-climate-service]]
Analysis:
Sec. 3(a) outlines activities to be carried out by the National Climate Service Corps as including "assisting with prevention, recovery, or restoration of wildland, rangeland, and wildland-urban interface areas from the effects of wildfire and associated impacts due to the effects of climate change", recovering from disasters to rebuild in a manner that provides improved resilience or adaptation for future climate impacts, supporting climate adaptation, mitigation, and resiliency, and other activities.

The bill authorizes $10 billion over five years ($2 billion each year) to implement the National Climate Service Corps, and $200 million over five years ($50 million each year) to implement the Climate Careers Network. Name: Butcher Block Act of 2021
Summary: This bill would establish a loan program at USDA Rural Development for new and expanding meat processors and finance producer investment to drive competition within the meat packing industry. Additionally, it would allocate grants to entities to increase hiring and processing capacity. The bill authorizes $20 million annually to carry out the program.
Support:
The bill has been endorsed by the American Farm Bureau Federation, United States Cattlemen's Association, and National Cattlemen's Beef Association. 

Introduction [[press release https://dustyjohnson.house.gov/media/press-releases/johnson-spanberger-introduce-butcher-block-act-cattle-producers]] 2021 / bill passes House [[press release https://dustyjohnson.house.gov/media/press-releases/johnsons-butcher-block-act-and-year-round-e15-passes-house]]
Analysis:
The bill is aimed at increasing competition in the cattle market by improving access to meat processing grants for small processors.

According to a 2021 Rabobank report, an additional daily packing capacity of 5,000 to 6,000 head of fed cattle could restore the historical balance of fed cattle supplies and packing capacity.

In a video discussing the bill, cosponsor Rep Spanberger addresses the fact that cattle producers' share of retail value for beef has decreased from more than 51% in 2015 to less than 37% in 2021, while meat prices are up 13% over the last year.

Following the introduction of the legislation, in July 2021, USDA announced its intent to provide $500 million in grants to expand meat and poultry processing capacity. Following this announcement, a press release from Rep Johnson's office stated: "As USDA continues to finalize details of the program, Johnson will continue to push USDA to design a program that is scalable and can quickly add processing capacity while incentivizing producer investment."

The text of the Butcher Block Act was included in H.R.7606 - Lower Food and Fuel Costs Act - which passed in the House on June 16, 2022.

Name: Agriculture Environmental Stewardship Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill would provide a 30 percent tax credit to farmers and rural electric cooperatives to help offset the upfront costs associated with building biodigester systems

Allows energy tax credits through 2023 for investments in (1) qualified biogas property, or (2) qualified manure resource recovery property. Qualified biogas property comprises a system that (1) uses anaerobic digesters or other specified processes to convert biomass into a gas which is at least 52% methane, and (2) captures the gas for use as a fuel. The term includes property that cleans and conditions the gas for use as a fuel. Qualified manure resource recovery property comprises a system that uses specified processes to recover the nutrients nitrogen and phosphorus from a non-treated digestate or animal manure by reducing or separating at least 50% of the nutrients, excluding any reductions during the incineration, storage, composting, or field application of the non-treated digestate or animal manure. The term also includes certain processing equipment.
Support:
The bill has been supported by the Ohio Farm Bureau, Food and Agriculture Climate Alliance (FACA), the National Milk Producers Federation, and the American Biogas Council.

Name: Wildfire Emergency Act
Summary: This bill would direct the Secretary of Agriculture to select and implement "landscape-scale" forest restoration projects, to assist communities in increasing their resilience to wildfire. The three main provisions of the bill are funding forest restoration projects designed to reduce wildfire risk, supporting infrastructure to allow for greater energy flexibility and resiliency; and supporting research, training and disadvantaged communities in forestry and fire management.
Support:
The Act is supported by the California Farm Bureau, Nature Conservancy, Sierra Club, Defenders of Wildlife, Wilderness Society, American Forests, Rural Voices for Conservation Coalition, Forest Stewards Guild, Watershed Research and Training Center, Sustainable Northwest, Western Environmental Law Center, Blue Forest Conservation, Quantified Ventures, Sempra Energy, Edison International, PG&E Corporation, and more (see list [[here https://panetta.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-panetta-senator-feinstein-introduce-bill-reduce-wildfire-risk]]).

Feinstein [[Press Release https://www.feinstein.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?ID=D42BB61B-4F08-4E66-BD95-55E5EF32A463]]
Analysis: The bill authorizes $250 million to fund a new U.S. Forest Service program to conduct large-scale forest restoration projects (i.e. at least 100,000 acres each), providing the ability to analyze and implement restoration activities on a large scale. These forest restoration projects, designed to reduce the potential for wildfires, include "removing dead and dying trees, using controlled burns to reduce fuel for larger fires, clearing out invasive and non-native species and creating habitat better suited for wildlife and native species". Restoration projects can help build resilience, and restore soil function and prevent erosion following wildfires.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Alex Padilla (D-CA), Sen. Ron Wyden (D-OR)

Analysis:
The Joint Chiefs Landscape Restoration Partnership is an initiative of the Chief of the US Forest Service and the Chief of the Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) that funds projects that "mitigate wildfire risk, improve water quality, and restore healthy forests ecosystems on public and private lands". The Joint Chiefs Partnership was launched seven years ago by USDA, but the program has never been officially authorized or fully funded. By formally establishing the program at USDA, doubling its funding to help meet demand, and introducing additional outreach and accountability measures, the successful passage of this Act could help improve forest, grassland and watershed restoration projects. 

The initiative aims to support voluntary restoration projects across ownership boundaries, "so that treatments can occur across a landscape, rather than stopping at public or private land."

As per Sec. 2(b)(2)(A), the funding allocated to NRCS is for assisting producers and landowners in implementing eligible activities on private or Tribal land. Eligible activities are those that reduce the risk of wildfire, protect water quality and supply, or improve wildlife habitat for at-risk species. There is opportunity to stipulate giving priority to projects that focus on improving soil health, as an effective means of achieving the stated goals.
Cosponsors (R): Sen. John Hoeven (R-ND)

Name: Cover Crop Flexibility Act of 2021
Summary:
To amend the Federal Crop Insurance Act to encourage the planting of cover crops following prevented planting, and for other purposes. 

The bill would permanently remove the prohibition on harvesting or grazing cover crops on prevented planting acres (acreage that cannot be planted because of flood, drought, or other disaster and is thus eligible for indemnification) prior to November 1. 

The bill would change crop insurance to encourage cover cropping. Sec. 2(a)(2) allows the USDA to include the costs of cover crop seed as a factor in calculating the prevented planting indemnity. 

Sec. 2(b) directs USDA to engage in research to determine how and to what extent cover cropping reduces the risks of prevented planting. It also allows the USDA to adjust insurance factors pursuant to this research and potentially lower premiums for farmers using cover crops.

(Reintroduction of [[S.3479 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/3479/text]] - Cover Crop Flexibility Act of 2020)
Support:
This bill has strong industry/producer and NGO support, including from the National Milk Producers Federation, National Cattlemen’s Beef Association, U.S. Cattleman's Association, National Association of Wheat Growers, National Corn Growers Association, American Soybean Association, National Council of Farmer Cooperativess, American Farm Bureau Federation, National Farmers Union, National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition, Better Seed, American Seed Trade Association, AGree Economic and Environmental Risk Coalition, Environmental Defense Fund, American Farmland Trust, and the National Wildlife Federation, among others (see [[full list here https://www.thune.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2021/4/thune-stabenow-reintroduce-cover-crop-legislation]]).

[[Press Release https://www.thune.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2021/4/thune-stabenow-reintroduce-cover-crop-legislation]]
Analysis:
This is an excellent and long overdue bill, which would save both taxpayers and farmers from the current disincentives to cover crop prevented planting acres.

This would bill give farmers increased flexibility to use their land under prevented planting circumstances, giving them the freedom to improve their soil for years into the future.

This bill supports the economic interests of both farmers and ranchers, allowing them to increase profitability while improving soil health. 

Even if this bill does not pass as a standalone, there is strong potential for its language to be incorporated into the 2023 Farm Bill, or to be added as an amendment to another bill related to disaster mitigation, resilience or other issues where flood, drought, or other disasters that involve prevented planting acres are addressed.

Sec. 2(a)(2) is promising in that it should allow farmers to more smoothly and easily make the transition toward cover cropping, including encouraging farmers who are hesitant to make this shift.

The research directed under Sec. 2(b) should provide valuable data and, as it links economic incentives to soil health, could be an area that could garner bipartisan support.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Debbie Stabenow (D-MI), Sen. Bob Casey Jr. (D-PA), Sen. Tina Smith (D-MN), Sen. Gary Peters (D-MI)
Cosponsors (R): Sen. Mike Rounds (R-SD)

Name: Safeguarding America's Future and Environment (SAFE) Act
Summary:
"To establish an integrated national approach to respond to ongoing and expected effects of extreme weather and climate change by protecting, managing, and conserving the fish, wildlife, and plants of the United States, and to maximize Government efficiency and reduce costs, in cooperation with State, local, and Tribal Governments and other entities, and for other purposes."  

This practice-based bill proposes the establishment of a group composed of heads of federal and state agencies with jurisdiction over fish, wildlife, and plant resources. This group would be required to create a climate adaptation strategy. 

Soil is mentioned in the following definition: "(4) ECOLOGICAL PROCESSES.—The term “ecological processes” means biological, chemical, or physical interaction between the biotic and abiotic components of an ecosystem, including—(A) decomposition; (B) disease epizootiology; (C) disturbance regimes, such as fire and flooding; (D) gene flow; (E) hydrological cycling; (F) larval dispersal and settlement; (G) nutrient cycling; (H) pollination; (I) predator-prey relationships; and (J) soil formation."
Support:
The act has been endorsed by several national organizations including Defenders of Wildlife, Alaska Wilderness Action, The Wilderness Society, World Wildlife Fund, National Parks Conservation Association, The Wildlife Society, Conservation Northwest, Earthjustice, Endangered Species Coalition, National Wildlife Federation, Sierra Club, Trust for Public Lands, Wildlands Network, Winter Wildlands Alliance, World Wildlife Fund, and Los Padres ForestWatch.

[[Press Release https://www.whitehouse.senate.gov/news/release/whitehouse-cartwright-bill-would-establish-national-strategy-to-protect-natural-resources-from-climate-change]]
Analysis:
This bill has an opportunity to make greater use of existing infrastructure, as well as to include crop insurance, the creation of market-based incentives for farmers, or the promotion of biodiversity on farms in the approach. 

Soil health is mentioned only in an ancillary way in section 3(4)(J).  

Section 6(b)(2) does discuss including the private sector in a federal advisory committee. This could potentially be an opportunity to incorporate soil health and to get regenerative farmers involved. The bill also addresses carbon sequestration and storage as important goals, which could be further opportunities to bring soil health and soil organic matter in. 

Although this bill does attempt to bring all stakeholders to the table, it has much more of a chance of resonating with Democrats, especially since it focuses specifically on climate change. 

• This bill is currently a standalone bill, although it needs a Republican cosponsor in order to become a bipartisan effort. However, Congressman Cartwright's office has indicated willingness to incorporate this bill into a larger bill or package of bills. 

This bill is identical to the previous version introduced in the 116th Congress.

Analysis:
This bill is supported by many of the biggest players in the agriculture and food business, as well as senior members of the Senate (with several more cosponsors in the 2021 version).

The bill's goal is to create a program that would help the agriculture sector gain access to revenue from greenhouse gas offset credit markets for producers looking to implement practices that capture carbon, reduce emissions, improve soil health, and make operations more sustainable. This goal would be pursued through establishing a USDA Greenhouse Gas Technical Assistance Provider and Third-Party Verifier Certification Program for carbon credits, through which USDA would be able to centralize information and provide "transparency, legitimacy, and informal endorsement" of third-party verifiers and technical service providers that help private landowners generate carbon credits through a variety of agriculture and forestry related practices.

New sections in this version of the act include: Sec. 2(d)(2) adds eligible activities including livestock emissions reductions through manure management practices, avoidance of the conversion of wetlands and grasslands in addition to forests, the restoration of wetlands and grasslands, and "current practices associated with private land conservation programs administered by the Secretary" (though these are not outlined); Sec. 2(e) includes a new "Fair Treatment of Farmers" section, which would require USDA to ensure technical assistance providers and credit verifiers provide farmers with realistic cost and revenue estimates, and help farmers, ranchers and foresters to “receive fair distribution" of the revenue derived from the sale of carbon credits (reflecting negotiations and concerns over the original version of the bill); Sec. 2(g)(2) stipulates the composition of the advisory council be not less than 51% farmers, ranchers, or private forest owners, including socially disadvantaged or historically underserved farmers and ranchers. Sec. 2(k) authorizes up to $9.1 million for USDA to operate the program.

Name: Agriculture Resilience Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill aims to reduce the impact of climate change on the agricultural sector, and to reduce agriculture emissions by 50 percent by 2030 and achieve net zero emissions by 2040.

The bill would quadruple funding and investment for agricultural research, with an emphasis on science-driven areas like climate change and adaptation, soil health, and farmland preservation and viability. 

The bill authorizes USDA to provide performance-based crop insurance discounts for farmers utilizing risk-reduction farming practices, and provides funds, information, and data for farmers and ranchers. 

Sec. 101(b)(2) establishes soil health benchmarks as goals for USDA and directs USDA to create an action plan that will reach these goals, including expanded adoption of soil health practices (crop rotations, cover cropping, among other practices) in order to restore soil health and sequester carbon, and to increase cover crop acreage in the United States. 

Title II directs USDA to pursue research to develop science-based methods to advance these goals, and education programs based on that information that would help farmers and ranchers who want to incorporate practices that support soil health. This research intends to accelerate the ability of agriculture and the food system to achieve net zero carbon emissions and ultimately become carbon negative.

Pursuant to these goals, Title V advocates for the establishment of pastured-based livestock management on 100 percent of grazing land by 2040.

Reintroduction of [[H.R.5861 https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/5861/text]] - Agriculture Resilience Act of 2020
Support:
This bill has received support from organizations and individuals including Former Vice President Al Gore, the American Farmland Trust, the American Grassfed Association, Beyond Pesticides, the California Climate and Agriculture Network, Carolina Farm Stewardship Association, Coastal Enterprises Inc., Harvard Food Law and Policy Clinic, [[The Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy https://www.iatp.org/blog/202002/agriculture-resilience-act-offers-climate-change-solutions-farmers]], Izaak Walton League of America, the National Resources Defense Council, the [[National Young Farmers Coalition https://www.youngfarmers.org/2020/02/agresilienceact]], the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition, [[Seed Alliance https://seedalliance.org/2020/osa-endorses-the-agriculture-resilience-act/]], and the [[Union of Concerned Scientists https://blog.ucsusa.org/marcia-delonge/6-ways-the-agricultural-resilience-act-equips-farmers-to-fight-the-climate-crisis-with-science]], among others (see [[full list here https://pingree.house.gov/netzeroagriculture/ara-statements-of-support.htm]]).

[[Press Coverage https://pingree.house.gov/netzeroagriculture/recent-news-coverage-of-the-ara.htm]], including Civil Eats and Politico Agriculture

Pingree [[Press Release https://pingree.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=3688]]
Analysis:
This comprehensive bill recognizes that transition to regenerative agricultural practices comes with increased costs and risks, and thus intends to provide farmers with access to regional assistance in order to implement those changes (making regenerative agriculture both more accessible and more profitable for farmers to adopt). The bill includes seven titles: (setting a) I) National Goal; II) Research; III) Soil Health; IV Farmland Preservation and Farm Vitality; V Pasture-Based Livestock; Title VI On-Farm Renewable Energy; Title VII Food Loss and Waste; 

USDA Climate Hubs would be required to solicit stakeholder input. This is an area that could be ripe for bipartisan support; moreover, the data collection and research contemplated could be key to building a workable outcomes-verified soil health testing program. 

Title III - Soil Health incentivizes and promotes soil health practices in a variety of ways. For instance, Sec. 301 declares NRCS conservation practices and conservation enhancements as good farming practices for crop insurance indemnity payment purposes; it also authorizes Risk Management Agency (RMA) to offer risk-reduction based crop insurance for producers who use risk-reduction farming practices (cover cropping, crop rotation, etc.). Sec. 302 makes carbon sequestration part of the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) and Sec. 303 adds soil health enhancement as a criteria for entry into the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP). Secs. 304 creates new USDA grants to states and tribal governments for soil health improvements, and Sec. 305 find ways to fund what is detailed in 302/303. Sec. 305 provides an interesting opportunity for socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers to get increased funding as part of EQIP or CSP in exchange for the use of climate friendly and soil health friendly practices at the outset of their careers. Sec. 306 looks into the feasibility of creating a federal income tax credit to incentivize carbon capture. See the bill for full details. Other Sections - Sec. 711 specifies composting as a recognized conservation practice.

New in this version of the Act: The bill would boost the Conservation Stewardship Program by encouraging transitions from annual to perennial crop production, which could increase the amount of carbon sequestered and help solid development. The bill would also create a new Processing Resilience Grant Program for small meat and poultry processors, and places a priority on underserved producers to advance equity.

Pingree reportedly sees several opportunities to move the bill forward in the current session, whether through the upcoming infrastructure bill, a farm bill or another measure.

Name: Healthy Soils Healthy Climate Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill seeks to encourage farming practices that improve soil health and crop resilience, and sequester carbon, by creating permanent payments within the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) for soil health practices and carbon sequestration monitoring.

(Reintroduction of [[S.4580 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/4580/text]] - Healthy Soils Healthy Climate Act of 2020)
Support: The bill received statements of support from E2 and Natural Resources Defense Council.[[Press Rel https://www.wyden.senate.gov/news/press-releases/wyden-reintroduces-legislation-to-improve-soil-health-crop-resilience-and-address-the-climate-crisis]]ease
Analysis:
Would create a permanent soil health program through the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) at the USDA-NRCS. The program would provide $100 million to producers who adopt practices designed to improve soil health through increasing carbon levels in soil, prioritizing funding for underserved farmers. This support would build on the Soil Health Demonstration Trials introduced in the 2018 Farm Bill.

Would establish protocols for measuring soil organic carbon levels before and after these practices begin in order to determine which farming practices store the most carbon. This is critical because there is a significant need for more science and data to determine which conservation methods are most effective at storing carbon in the soil to improve soil health.

Would establish a Soil Health and Carbon Science Research Program at Agriculture Research Stations that would provide grants to land-grant colleges and universities to conduct research relating to soil health and carbon science at Agriculture Research Stations of the USDA.

New in this version of the Act: Sec. 2(k)(3) gives funding priority to underserved producers, including small producers, producers in rural areas, and socially disadvantaged farmers. Otherwise, this version of the bill is the same as the original.

Name: Conservation for Agricultural Leased Land (CALL) Act
Summary: This bill would require USDA to conduct a study to better understand the unique barriers that farmers who lease their lands face in accessing conservation programs or implementing conservation practices. The information gained from this study, is intended to enable USDA and Congress to make improvements to existing federal programs to ensure that farmers who lease land are able to participate fully in these programs and derive the benefits of improved conservation practices.
Support:
The bill is supported by American Farmland Trust, Environmental Defense Fund, and the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition. 

[[Press Release https://juliabrownley.house.gov/brownley-introduces-legislation-to-support-americas-farmers-in-addressing-the-impacts-of-climate-change/]]
Analysis:
Today about 40% of U.S. working lands (53% of croplands and 28% of rangelands) are operated by tenant farmers/ranchers, who currently have little or no direct economic incentive to improve the health of our soils as the benefits of regenerative agriculture are longer term and felt little over the average, one-year term of a land lease. This bill seeks to better understand the range of factors limiting landowners and tenants from adopting conservation practices on the land that they own or manage, and from participating in Federal, State, and local conservation programs.

The Select Committee on the Climate Crisis’s Congressional Action Plan recommended this action to improve federal conservation programs.

Name: Climate Agricultural Conservation Practices Act
Summary: This bill would require the Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) to review the national conservation practice standards, taking into consideration climate benefits, such as reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, increases in carbon sequestration, or mitigation against or adaptation to increased weather volatility, when developing conservation practice standards.
Support:
The bill is supported by American Farmland Trust, Environmental Defense Fund, and the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition. 

[[Press Release https://juliabrownley.house.gov/brownley-introduces-legislation-to-support-americas-farmers-in-addressing-the-impacts-of-climate-change/]]
Analysis:
While it is acknowledged that many of the currently approved conservation practices, such as cover cropping or no-till farming, also have climate benefits (such as reducing GHG emissions, sequestering carbon, or mitigating or adapting to the impacts of extreme weather), NRCS does not directly consider climate benefits when developing their list of approved standards. By making the linkage between such conservation practices and climate benefits, this bill could help to ensure that the full range of benefits of adopting conservation practices is addressed in NRCS programs, resulting in more comprehensive and responsive support for farmers' and ranchers' specific conservation goals and management plans.

This improvement to NRCS conservation programs was also a recommendation made by the Select Committee on the Climate Crisis’s Congressional Action Plan.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Anthony Brown (D-MD-4), Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI-13)

Name: Recovering America's Wildlife Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill provides funding for (1) the conservation or restoration of wildlife and plant species of greatest conservation need; (2) the wildlife conservation strategies of states, territories, or the District of Columbia; and (3) wildlife conservation education and recreation projects.

The Department of the Interior must use a portion of the funding for a grant program for "innovative recovery efforts for species of greatest conservation need, species listed as endangered or threatened species, or the habitats of such species."

In addition, the bill requires certain revenues generated from fees and penalties for violations of environmental requirements to be used as a source for the funding.

This is the reintroduction of [[H.R.3742 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/3742/text]] - Recovering America's Wildlife Act of 2019 (A version of this legislation was included as a bipartisan amendment to [[H.R.2 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/2/text]], the Moving Forward Act).
Support:
The bill is endorsed by over 1,500 organizations including the National Wildlife Federation, the Congressional Sportsmen’s Foundation, Theodore Roosevelt Conservation Partnership, Native American Fish and Wildlife Society, The Nature Conservancy, the Nevada Department of Wildlife and President of the Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies, and more.

Dingell [[Press Release https://debbiedingell.house.gov/news/email/show.aspx?ID=KZIYWGWAF6PLGL4CCROGFX2AXE]] / Heinrich [[Press Release https://www.heinrich.senate.gov/press-releases/heinrich-blunt-introduce-bipartisan-recovering-americas-wildlife-act]]

[[See NWF Information Page https://www.nwf.org/Our-Work/Wildlife-Conservation/Policy/Recovering-Americas-Wildlife-Act#:~:text=The%20House%20bill%20would%20provide,recover%20wildlife%20species%20at%20risk.&text=At%20least%2015%20percent%20of,listed%20as%20threatened%20or%20endangered.]]
Analysis:
This bill would redirect over $1.3 billion in existing revenues to the Wildlife Conservation Restoration Program for efforts led by States, territories, and Tribal nations to protect and restore wildlife habitat and prevent vulnerable wildlife from becoming endangered.

The bill would provide Tribal nations with $97.5 million annually to fund proactive wildlife conservation efforts on roughly 140 million acres of land.
Committees: Natural Resources - Subcommittee on Water, Oceans, and Wildlife & Subcommittee on Indigenous Peoples of the United States
Status: Passed House and received in the Senate.

Name: Farm to School Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill would renew the Farm to School Program, originally authorized in 2010, under which the USDA provides grants to schools to implement "farm to school activities" aimed at delivering fresh, local foods to schools.

The bill would expand participation in the program to preschools, after-school programs, and summer food service sites, and increases annual mandatory funding from $5 to $15 million.
Support:
The bill is supported by the National Farm to School Network, and the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition.

Leahy [[Press Release https://www.leahy.senate.gov/press/leahy-tillis-brown-collins-introduce-bill-to-renew-popular-farm-to-school-program]]
Analysis:
The grants provided by the program can provide nutrition as well as education outcomes for students, while encouraging procurement of local foods. Eligible activities include: (I) planting and maintenance of farms or gardens; (II) procurement from local agricultural producers; or (III) educational activities relating to agriculture, nutrition, or food.”

There is little detail provided on requirements for procurement beyond "local" (eg. no information about size of farm, management practices). Advocates could call for procurement requirements to prioritize farms using soil health practices, to support local markets for regenerative products.

Since 2013, USDA has received more than 1,900 applications requesting over $141 million, however, only 437 awards were granted from the $30 million available ($5 million per year). The Farm to School Act increases annual mandatory funding for Farm to School to $15 million to meet the current need and increases the maximum individual grant award to $250,000.

Name: Resiliency for Ranching and Natural Conservation Health (RANCH) Act
Summary:
The bill doubles the maximum term of grazing permits and leases to 20 years.

The bill would increase spending on "rangeland improvement projects" by $10 million.

The bill would increase spending  to "enhance, expand, or improve access opportunities" by $5 million.

This bill instructs the Secretary of Agriculture, or the Secretary overseeing public lands, to authorize temporary utilization of vacant allotments during extreme events and disasters. These temporary relocations are not to exceed three consecutive grazing seasons.

Allows for the use of a categorical exclusion of NEPA review for renewal of certain grazing permits/leases.

Allows for the use of a categorical exclusion of NEPA review for certain actions during extreme events/disasters for up to two years.
Support: [[Press Release https://www.energy.senate.gov/2021/4/barrasso-introduces-legislation-to-promote-resilient-rangelands-effective-grazing-management]]
Analysis:
Doubles the length of maximum grazing permit from 10 to 20 years, with no substantive additional resource considerations required.

$10 million per year to would be directed to enhance, expand or improve access opportunities for rangeland betterment and improvements "including: seeding and reseeding, fence construction, the use of a temporary structure (such as a corral), an invasive plant or weed control measure or treatment, water development, and any other activity that advances healthy rangeland improvement, habitat, and resiliency". This includes land under existing graizing permits and leases without any required participation from the rancher.

$5 million per year would be directed "to enhance, expand or improve access opportunities" to public lands (through cooperative agreements or special use agreements with private land owners.

It creates access to "vacant allotments" for ranchers with leases or grazing permits for temporary use when their own allotments are unavailable due to resource conditions from unforeseen natural events or disasters, including extreme weather events, drought, wildfire or infestations. This could increase flexibility and promote resource management on public lands. These temporary relocations are not to exceed three consecutive grazing seasons.

Circumvents NEPA review for many lease renewals and for "temporary" (up to 2 years) use during natural disaster relocation for grazing operations.
Committees: Energy and Natural Resources - Subcommittee on Public Lands, Forests, and Mining
Status: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources Subcommittee on Public Lands, Forests, and Mining. Hearings held.

Name: Growing Climate Solutions Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill would create a certification program at USDA to reduce technical entry barriers to farmer and forest landowner participation in voluntary environmental credit markets.

Through the program, USDA would help connect landowners to private sector actors who could assist the landowners in implementing the protocols and monetizing the climate value of their sustainable practices.

[[Senate Hearing https://www.agriculture.senate.gov/hearings/legislative-hearing-to-review-s-3894-the-growing-climate-solutions-act-of-2020]] on GCSA of 2020
Analysis:
This bill is supported by many of the biggest players in the agriculture and food business, as well as senior members of the Senate (with several more cosponsors in the 2021 version).

The bill's goal is to create a program that would help the agriculture sector gain access to revenue from greenhouse gas offset credit markets for producers looking to implement practices that capture carbon, reduce emissions, improve soil health, and make operations more sustainable. This goal would be pursued through establishing a USDA Greenhouse Gas Technical Assistance Provider and Third-Party Verifier Certification Program for carbon credits, through which USDA would be able to centralize information and provide "transparency, legitimacy, and informal endorsement" of third-party verifiers and technical service providers that help private landowners generate carbon credits through a variety of agriculture and forestry related practices.

New sections in this version of the act include: Sec. 2(d)(2) adds eligible activities including livestock emissions reductions through manure management practices, avoidance of the conversion of wetlands and grasslands in addition to forests, the restoration of wetlands and grasslands, and "current practices associated with private land conservation programs administered by the Secretary" (though these are not outlined); Sec. 2(e) includes a new "Fair Treatment of Farmers" section, which would require USDA to ensure technical assistance providers and credit verifiers provide farmers with realistic cost and revenue estimates, and help farmers, ranchers and foresters to “receive fair distribution" of the revenue derived from the sale of carbon credits (reflecting negotiations and concerns over the original version of the bill); Sec. 2(g)(2) stipulates the composition of the advisory council be not less than 51% farmers, ranchers, or private forest owners, including socially disadvantaged or historically underserved farmers and ranchers. Sec. 2(k) authorizes up to $9.1 million for USDA to operate the program.

Name: Civilian Climate Corps for Jobs and Justice Act
Summary: This bill would establish a Civilian Climate Corps (CCC) administered by the Corporation for National and Community Service within AmeriCorps, with the goal of creating 1.5 million jobs over five years to respond to climate change including through implementing conservation projects. The Act authorizes over $100 billion over five years in funding.
Support:
This bill is endorsed by Evergreen Action, Sunrise Movement, Data for Progress, Food & Water Watch, Organic Consumers Association, Family Farm Action, Center for Biological Diversity, Indigenous Environmental Network, and others (see full list [[here https://www.markey.senate.gov/news/press-releases/senator-markey-and-rep-ocasio-cortez-introduce-civilian-climate-corps-for-jobs-and-justice-to-rebuild-america]]).

Markey [[Press Release https://www.markey.senate.gov/news/press-releases/senator-markey-and-rep-ocasio-cortez-introduce-civilian-climate-corps-for-jobs-and-justice-to-rebuild-america]]
Analysis:
Sec. 199T includes as eligible service projects: developing and implementing conservation projects including, importantly, by (7)(K) "assisting farmers and ranchers in a transition to more regenerative farming and ranching systems", and mitigating the effects of climate change, including (4)(G) "advising and supporting farmers and ranchers in the implementation of management practices that account for climate change", which would provide support for technical assistance to farmers and ranchers in transitioning to soil health practices.

Eligible projects also include activities that contribute to building soil health, such as restoring habitat, stabilizing shorelines using green infrastructure, expanding local and regional food systems, developing farm to institution distribution models, planting forests and native grasslands.

Note: There are multiple similar 'conservation corps' expansion ideas that have been proposed in other bills such as the 21st Century Conservation Corps Act (S.487 / H.R.1162), the Climate Stewardship Act (S.1072 / H.R.2820), the Civilian Climate Corps Act (S.1057 / H.R.2241), the Outdoor Restoration Partnership Act (S.1248 / H.R.2682), and the RENEW Conservation Corps Act (S.1370). This particular Act codifies President Biden's call for a national service program in his Executive Order on Tackling the Climate Crisis at Home and Abroad. The White House included a $10 billion fund to establish a Civilian Climate Corps as part of the American Jobs Plan.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Alex Padilla (D-CA), Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-OR), Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY), Sen. Cory Booker (D-NJ), Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD), Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-CT), Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA)

Name: America Creating Opportunities for Manufacturing Pre-Eminence in Technology and Economic Strength (COMPETES) Act of 2022
Summary:
"To provide for a coordinated Federal research initiative to ensure continued United States leadership in engineering biology."

This omnibus bill has a number of provisions, including $52 billion to make semiconductor chips, $45 billion to improve supply chains for critical items, and $160 billion for scientific research and innovation. See [[SHRM https://www.shrm.org/resourcesandtools/hr-topics/talent-acquisition/pages/house-passes-sweeping-america-competes-act.aspx]]: "The bill—made up of several previous proposals and hundreds of new amendments—authorizes billions of dollars to boost domestic research and development of semiconductors, as well as critical supply chains and science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education and training."

Sec. 30607. ADDRESSING INTERNATIONAL CLIMATE CHANGE MITIGATION, ADAPTATION, AND SECURITY includes international development assistance for developing countries including initiatives to employ (b)(3)(B) "agricultural production practices that reduce poverty while improving soil health, protecting water quality, and increasing food security and nutrition"; and direct US policy to include providing resources to developing countries to (15) "promote sustainable agricultural practices that mitigate carbon emissions, conserve soil, and improve food and water security of communities".
Support: The bill has received support from AFL-CIO, Association of Public and Land-grant Universities (APLU), Association of American Universities, Intel, National Association of Manufacturers, White House Office of Managment and Budget, Security Industry Association, and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
Analysis:
This bill is largely aimed at increasing American competitiveness, including to counter China. The bill includes $52 billion to support domestic manufacturing and research of semiconductors, the chips that are used in electronic devices. The bill also authorizes $45 billion to strengthen the supply chain. It establishes a new directive for Science and Engineering Solutions and provides additional funding for the National Science Foundation.

While not the main focus of the bill, for stakeholders with international partners, this bill includes an example of how the US can support soil health-focused agricultural development abroad.

U.S. Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo called the legislative package “the biggest investment in 50 years” to boost America’s competitiveness, manufacturing capacity and research and development. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer called the counterpart Senate bill one of the most significant pieces of legislation passed in a long time and said it would have a huge impact on the American economy and jobs.

"House lawmakers passed the bill along party lines, and it now heads to the Senate to be reconciled with that chamber's bipartisan version, which was approved in June 2021. But reaching an agreement on the two versions is expected to be difficult because Republicans have since turned against the measure, largely due to its inclusion of dozens of other provisions related to climate change, immigration, labor organizing and trade." (SHRM)

Name: Outdoor Restoration Partnership Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill would establish a fund to increase local efforts to restore forests and watersheds, reduce wildfire risk, clean up public lands, enhance wildlife habitat, remove invasive species, and expand outdoor access. The bill proposes to create or sustain two million jobs, including in agriculture.

The bill would make funding available directly to state and local governments, tribes, special districts, and non-profits to support restoration, resilience, and mitigation projects across public, private, and tribal lands; and would fund federal agencies to partner with states and tribes on targeted projects to restore wildlife habitat and reduce wildfire risk across the country.
Support:
This bill is supported by National Wildlife Federation, National Association of State Foresters, The Nature Conservancy, National Wild Turkey Federation, American Forests, National Audubon Society, Family Farm Alliance, Theodore Roosevelt Conservation Partnership, Western Landowners Alliance, Western Resource Advocates, Trout Unlimited, and Conservation Legacy.[[

Bennet [[Press Release https://www.bennet.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?id=367C1E10-CAAD-4F4D-95FE-CC35642F250E]]
Analysis:
The bill would establish the Outdoor Restoration Fund in the Treasury, and provide $60 billion to this Fund. Of this, $20 billion would be available to the Restoration and Resilience Grant Program to provide grants to eligible entities (state agency, unit of local government, tribal government, regional organization, special district, or nonprofit organization) to implement projects that improve forest, watershed, and rangeland health and mitigate wildfire. The remaining $40 billion would fund the Restoration and Resilience Partnership, a program administered by the Secretary of Agriculture to restore forest, grassland, and rangeland ecosystems and create jobs by reducing the backlog of restoration and resilience projects on federal and non-federal land, in partnership with state, local, and tribal governments.

There is opportunity for soil health to be explicitly addressed in this bill, for example by giving priority to projects that build soil health as a central component of achieving the stated goals (improving forest, watershed, and rangeland health and mitigating wildfire), in addition to the stated job creation goals.

President Joe Biden included a commitment to invest in restoration and resilience in his American Jobs Plan, highlighting Bennet’s legislation as a model.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Ron Wyden (D-OR), Sen. Ben Ray Luján (D-NM)

Name: National Green Bank Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill establishes a U.S. "Green Bank" to finance climate change mitigation and adaptation projects at the state and local level by capitalizing regional, state, and municipal green banks.

The bill requires the Department of the Treasury issue green bonds to provide the bank with an initial capitalization of $10 billion and additional capitalization, upon the bank’s request, of no more than $50 billion in aggregate at any one time.

The bill also establishes a revolving Green Bank Establishment Fund in the Treasury Department to help set up green banks in states that don’t already have one.
Support: Murphy [[Press Release https://www.murphy.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/murphy-blumenthal-introduce-legislation-to-create-a-national-green-bank-thousands-of-clean-energy-jobs]]
Analysis:
While the proposal appears geared towards clean energy projects, it could also provide a potential source of funding for regenerative agriculture practices - the bill defines "climate change mitigation or adaptation project" as "any project that reduces the emissions of greenhouse gases by sources or enhance their removal from the atmosphere by sinks, or reduce the vulnerability of social and biological systems to relatively sudden change and thus offset the effects of global warming, including through —(A) afforestation, reforestation, and land conservation; (B) regenerative agriculture".

The national bank would help establish and fund "green banks" across the country, which would then be able to make financing in the form of direct financing support or credit enhancement for eligible projects. The first green bank in the country was the Connecticut Green Bank, which has mobilized almost $2 billion of investment since its founding in 2011.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-CT)
