Name: Sponsoring USDA Sustainability Targets in Agriculture to Incentivize Natural Solutions (SUSTAINS) Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill encourages private sector funding of USDA conservation initiatives. The bill authorizes specific accounts at USDA that allow for private sector donations and incentivizes private funding by awarding sponsorship of targeted conservation initiatives, including expanded land use practices to sequester carbon, improve wildlife habitat, protect sources of drinking water, and address other natural resource priorities. 

Key provisions include the ability for USDA to match private sector investments and for the contributor to work with USDA to decide which natural resource concerns they want to address.

[[Brief Summary https://republicans-agriculture.house.gov/uploadedfiles/04.14.2021_sustainsactthompsonsummary.pdf?utm_campaign=2760-396]]
Support: Check back for Press Release
Analysis:
This bill provides an opportunity to increase funding for existing USDA conservation programs, including the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) and the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP), to meet high demand for the programs and ultimately support farmers and ranchers in implementing soil health practices.

Functions by authorizing USDA accounts that accept private sector donations and incentivizing private funding by awarding sponsorship of targeted conservation initiatives by funders.

Uses existing infrastructure

Rethinking of the way conservation practices are funded

Rep. Thompson has called the five-bill package "an alternative to the Growing Climate Solutions Act", and said that GOP members will be working to gain bipartisan support for the bills.

Name: Producing Responsible Energy and Conservation Incentives and Solutions for the Environment (PRECISE) Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill amends the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) to include the adoption of precision agriculture practices as a practice recognized under EQIP. 

Amends EQIP to allow a producer receiving payments to also receive a loan under the Conservation Loan and Loan Guarantee Program to cover additional costs for the same practices on the same land.

Incentivizes the purchase of precision agriculture equipment, systems, and technology; amending EQIP to allow for up to 90% of cost-share under the program agriculture practices. 

Includes precision agriculture to the additional payments authority in the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP).

Incentivizes private sector financing of precision agriculture equipment through the Conservation Loan Guarantee Program and the Business and Industry Loan Guarantee Program; and funding 100% of precision agriculture projects through joint participation of conservation cost-share programs and the Conservation Loan Program.

[[Brief Summary https://republicans-agriculture.house.gov/uploadedfiles/04.14.2021_preciseacthinsonsummary.pdf?utm_campaign=2760-396]]

This bill aims to define "Precision Agriculture" as a recognized conservation practice under EQIP and CSP and allow for 90% cost share for the purchase of precision agriculture equipment, systems, and technology under EQIP,  payments under CSP, and loan guarantees.

Incentivizes private sector financing of precision agriculture equipment through existing programs.

Funds 100% of precision agriculture projects through joint participation of conservation cost-share programs and the Conservation Loan Program.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Cynthia Axne (D-IA-3)
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Randy Feenstra (R-IA-4), Rep. Mariannette Miller-Meeks (R-IA-2), Rep. Michelle Fischbach (R-MN-7), Rep. Eric Crawford (R-AR-1), Rep. Elise Stefanik (R-NY-21), Rep. Don Bacon (R-NE-2), Rep. Troy Balderson (R-OH-12)
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Commodity Exchanges, Energy, and Credit
Status: Approved by the House Agriculture Committee. Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 258.

Name: Biochar Innovations and Opportunities for Conservation, Health, and Advancements in Research (BIOCHAR) Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill directs the Secretaries of Agriculture and Energy to establish a program to enter into partnerships to carry out demonstration projects, and directs the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a research and development grant program to support the development and use of biochar in land management activities.

Eligible entities for participation in the programs are State, local and Tribal governments; land-grant colleges and universities; and private, non-private, or cooperative entities.
Support: [[See Press Coverage https://www.currentargus.com/story/news/local/2021/04/27/yvette-herrells-biochar-bill-clean-up-forests-reduce-emissions/7326758002/?fbclid=IwAR2JW22xA3_TjxAmupub4SBwewHM1HW9ScoRAQoDsMCUA1WcA1_6Zfrk8ro]]
Analysis:
Biochar, a charcoal-like substance made by burning excess organic material from agricultural and forestry wastes (biomass) through pyrolysis, can be applied to soils to improve soil health, improve soil fertility, and sequester carbon. 

This bill is designed to support biochar production - which is currently cost-intensive - in order to make it more economically viable for use by agricultural producers and forest landowners. 

35% of granted funds can be used to construct new or expand existing biochar facilities.

The Secretary of Agriculture or Energy would have very broad leeway in identifying qualifying demonstration projects. As per Sec. 4, the Secretaries may enter into partnerships and provide funding to carry out demonstration projects that: (F) carry out any other activities the Secretaries determine appropriate; or (G) any combination of the purposes specified in subparagraphs (A) through (F).

Given the emissions associated wth new biochar creation, and the stated framing of this bill as using biochar for carbon sequestration, it is notable that there is no net CO2 sequestration requirement for funded projects.

It is also worth noting that there is no requirement that the biomass used to produce the biochar be already dead/dying or culled from post fire areas. The only requierment is under Sec. 2(a)(5), which requires demonstration projects to derive at least 50 percent of the feedstock required to produce biochar from forest thinning and management; note, the other 50% can be derived from any source. 

Per Sec. 2(a)(3), proposals for demonstration projects would be given priority based on carbon sequestration potential, but also potential for job creation, market viability of the projects, and local need. This is a broad and vague priority group. 

The bill does not allocate any funding to the establishment of the stated programs.
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Bruce Westerman (R-AR-4), Rep. Dan Newhouse (R-WA-4), Rep. Paul Gosar (R-AZ-4), Rep. Doug LaMalfa (R-CA-1), Rep. Mariannette Miller-Meeks (R-IA-2)
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Conservation and Forestry; Science, Space and Technology
Agencies: U.S. Departments of Agriculture and Energy

Name: Conservation and Innovative Climate Partnership Act of 2021
Summary: This bill provides $13 million per year in funding (for 4-year grants, with a maximum amount of $400,000), as part of a new competitive grant program to be established by the Secretary of Agriculture. Funds will go to land-grant colleges and universities to support agricultural producers in adopting conservation and innovative climate practices.
Support:
The bill has been supported by Purdue University, Indiana Corn Growers Association, Indiana Soybean Alliance, Indiana Farm Bureau, Agribusiness Council of Indiana, Citizens for Responsible Energy Solutions, Corteva, Environmental Defense Fund, Washington State University, The Nature Conservancy, and Washington Potato Council.[[

Young [[Press Release https://www.young.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/young-smith-bill-will-boost-hoosier-farmers-yield-while-helping-climate]] / Newhouse [[Press Release https://newhouse.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/newhouse-introduces-bill-support-farmers-conservation]]
Analysis:
Sec. (2)(5) defines 'innovative climate practice' as a practice that results in reduced emissions, carbon sequestration, soil health improvement, or reduced exposure to climate-related risk.

Eligible activities under the grant funding include providing technical assistance to agricultural producers in implementing a conservation practice or an innovative climate practice, conducting workshops and public awareness campaigns that provide direction to producers around how to access technical assistance, and for soil testing.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Tina Smith (D-MN), Sen. Brian Schatz (D-HI)
Cosponsors (R): Sen. Mike Braun (R-IN)

Name: Forestry Improvements to Restore the Environment (FIRE) Act of 2021
Summary:
Requires the U.S. Forest Service (USFS) to complete a survey of National Forest System land impacted by wildfire within 60 days after the fire has been contained. 

Requires the USFS to give priority first to lands where timber is under contract.

Requires that within 60 days of containment of a wildfire on National Forest System Land, that the USFS convert any timber sale to a salvage sale, without the need for NEPA environmental assessment.

Creates a new Categorial Exclusion of unlimited size for activities where the primary purpose is roadside salvage allowing for the removal of hazard trees within 200 feet of a roadway. Extraordinary circumstances procedures shall not apply to this new Categorical Exclusion.

Establishes judicial review procedures limiting objections to a period of 30 days. Requires that timber sales be allowed to proceed during litigation.
Support: [[Press Release https://dustyjohnson.house.gov/media/press-releases/house-agriculture-committee-rolls-out-conservative-climate-solutions]]
Analysis:
Provides tools to expedite post fire timber harvesting.

Enables rural communities to get salvage timber to market, increasing financial benefits to local communities and funding for future restoration activities

Rolls back the review period, and limits the redress of land owners, protecting logging companies
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Doug LaMalfa (R-CA-1), Rep. Bruce Westerman (R-AR-4), Rep. Eric Crawford (R-AR-1), Rep. Liz Cheney (R-WY-At Large)
Committees: Agriculture - Subcommittee on Conservation and Forestry; Natural Resources

Name: Climate Stewardship Act of 2021
Summary:
To provide incentives for agricultural producers to carry out climate stewardship practices, to provide for increased reforestation across the United States, to establish the Coastal and Estuary Resilience Grant Program, and for other purposes.

This bill would exponentially scale up federal funding in existing voluntary USDA programs for a newly defined subset of "climate stewardship practices", including USDA working lands conservation programs, and agricultural research programs including soil health demonstration trials, technical assistance, and grant funding. The bill would support voluntary climate stewardship practices on over 100 million acres of farmland. 

[[Section by Section Summary https://www.booker.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/with_fdrs_new_deal_as_blueprint_sen_booker_and_rep.spanbergerreintroduceclimatechangebillfocusedoninvestinginfarmconservationprogramsreforestationandwetlandsrestoration3.pdf]]
Support:
This bill is supported by the American Grassfed Association, Family Farm Action, the National Family Farm Coalition, the Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy, Natural Resources Defense Council, and the Intertribal Timber Council, among others (see full list [[here https://www.booker.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/with_fdrs_new_deal_as_blueprint_sen_booker_and_rep.spanbergerreintroduceclimatechangebillfocusedoninvestinginfarmconservationprogramsreforestationandwetlandsrestoration4.pdf]]).

Booker [[Press Release https://www.booker.senate.gov/news/press/with-fdrs-new-deal-as-blueprint-sen-booker-and-rep-spanberger-re-introduce-climate-change-bill-focused-on-investing-in-farm-conservation-programs-reforestation-and-wetlands-restoration]] / Spanberger [[Press Release https://spanberger.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=3712]]
Analysis:
This bill emphasizes a key role for soil health practices across USDA programs, and includes massive increases in funding to incentivize the adoption of conservation practices among producers, through the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP), Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) (up to $7B per year in mandatory funding by 2024), and the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP) (up to $7B per year in mandatory funding by 2024). This new funding is dedicated to 37 "climate stewardship practices" (see full list of practices on page 5 of the bill section by section summary).

Doubles funding for agricultural research programs, including more funding for soil health demonstration trials.

Triples funding for the Conservation Technical Assistance Program to provide farmers with expert technical assistance on climate stewardship practices.

The bill also includes large increases in funding to the Rural Energy for America Program (REAP) for farmers and businesses to expand renewable energy production, directs and funds massive reforestation, the Regional Conservation Partnership Program, the establishment of a civilian conservation corps to train and employ youth on reforestation and restoration projects, and a host of other less specifically soil health, but rather green jobs and environmental initiatives, with billions in total funding provisions to federal programs.

This new version of the Act (reintroduced form the 116th Congress) Establishes a new "Soil Health Equipment Grant Program" Establishes a program to incentivize landowners to undertake forest management practices that increase carbon sequestration and storage Adds new climate stewardship practices including compost applications, mulching to improve soil health Stipulates priority funding for underserved and minority farmers

Voluntary practices are broadly supported and tend to be well received.

Sponsor Sen. Cory Booker (D-NJ) is said to be positioning portions of the bill for inclusion into President Biden's upcoming infrastructure and climate packages. The American Jobs Plan includes a $10 billion fund to establish a Civilian Climate Corps, a similar idea of which is included in the CSA.
Committees: Agriculture; Natural Resources - Subcommittee on National Parks, Forests, and Public Lands & Subcommittee on Water, Oceans, and Wildlife & Subcommittee on Indigenous Peoples of the United States; Science, Space, and Technology - Subcommittee on Environment
Status: Referred to Subcommittee on Indigenous Peoples of the United States

Name: Naturally Offsetting Emissions by Managing and Implementing Tillage Strategies (NO EMITS) Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill creates a Soil Health Transition Program, expands activities of and increases funding for the On-Farm Conservation Innovation Trials, establishes a grant program for States and Indian Tribes addressing soil health on agricultural lands, and establishes a special technical assistance initiative for climate change. This bill provides incentives for producers to adopt soil health cropping systems in order to increase farm productivity and optimize agriculture's ability to sequester carbon and reduce net emissions.

[[Brief Summary https://republicans-agriculture.house.gov/uploadedfiles/04.14.2021_noemitsactdavissummary.pdf?utm_campaign=2760-396]]
Support: Check back for Press Release
Analysis:
Establishes a Soil Health Transition Incentive Program that provides payments and technical assistance to producers who are transitioning their farms to soil health cropping systems.

Provides longer term contracts (5-7 years) to help mitigate risk during transition to soil health cropping systems.

Allows the producer to choose individualized technical assistance through USDA, TSPs, commercial entities, non-profits, or state or local governments.

Doubles funding for the On-Farm Conservation Innovation Trials from $25 million to $50 million per year; and adds livestock production as a covered activity for the trials. 

Establishes a State Assistance for Soil Health Programs and provides $100 million per year out of Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP) funding for matching grants to States or tribes for state soil health programs.

Carves out 1 percent of the overall conservation title funding to provide technical assistance to producers to mitigate and adapt to the changing climate
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Don Bacon (R-NE-2), Rep. Eric A. Crawford "Rick" (R-AR-1)

Name: America's Clean Future Fund Act
Summary:
This bill would establish a new program to pay farmers and ranchers for implementing practices that sequester carbon and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Sec. 6(a) directs the Secretary of Agriculture to provide payments to farmers, ranchers, private forest landowners, and other agricultural landowners in the United States that reduce or sequester greenhouse gas emissions through the adoption of qualifying farming, ranching, and forestry practices. The assistance seeks to help finance the transition to improved practices that will allow producers' participation in private sector greenhouse gas credit markets.

The bill would implement several other measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and fund the transtion to a clean energy economy, including the establishment of an independent federal agency (Climate Change Finance Corporation, or C2FC) to finance and support investment and job creation in clean energy projects, climate resilience, and research, development, and deployment; and a carbon fee by 2023.
Support:
The bill is supported by EDF, C2ES, Citizens’ Climate Lobby (CCL).

Newman [[Press Release https://newman.house.gov/media/press-releases/us-representative-marie-newman-introduces-first-bill-americas-clean-future]]
Analysis:
Sec. 6(c) establishes a program to provide payments to eligible producers that will assist with the transition to reducing greenhouse gas emissions through the adoption of qualifying practices, which include improved soil, water, and land management systems through diverse crop rotations, cover crops, conservation tillage, conservation plantings, the integration of livestock, conservation easements that include soil health improvement, and other practices. 

Sec. 6(c) also outlines several key considerations in determining the rate and duration of a payment, including additionality, early adopters, permanence, and current soil conditions.

This new version of the Act (reintroduced from 116th Congress) expands on the provisions for monitoring and verification: Sec 6(d) establishes an outcomes-based measurement system and directs the Secretary of Agriculture to set standards accordingly and within 18 months (based on information obtained from agro-ecosystem models, remote sensing data and analysis, soil health demonstration trials, and field-level measurement). The establishment of a national standard is essential for facilitating the participation of farmers and ranchers in the various incentives and payment schemes. There is, however, opportunity for protocols to be outlined more specifically in this section.

Sec. 2(A) directs the proposed C2FC to provide grant and loan funding to entities conducting approved practices and projects relating to climate change mitigation, risk reduction and resilience measures, including increasing the resilience of the agriculture sector. This provision could support innovative projects related to soil health.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Nikema William (D-GA-5), Rep. Jahana Hayes (D-CT-5), Rep. Juan Vargas (D-CA-51), Rep. Salud Carbajal (D-CA-24), Rep. Albio Sires (D-NJ-8), Rep. Ritchie Torres (D-NY-15), Rep. Mike Quigley (D-IL-5), Rep. Jared Huffman (D-CA-2), Rep. Pete Aguilar (D-CA-31)
Committees: Energy and Commerce; Ways and Means; Agriculture; Education and Labor; Transportation and Infrastructure; Financial Services; Science, Space, and Technology; Natural Resources

Name: Farmers Fighting Climate Change Act
Summary: This bill directs NRCS to establish region-specific climate change mitigation bundles within CSP to support and promote agricultural practices that reduce greenhouse gas emissions and increase carbon sequestration. See [[Fact Sheet https://underwood.house.gov/sites/underwood.house.gov/files/Farmers%20Fighting%20Climate%20Change%20Act%202021.pdf]].
Support:
The bill has been endorsed by the Illinois Farm Bureau, Illinois Corn Growers Association, Illinois Soybean Association, Illinois Stewardship Alliance, National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition, Natural Resources Defense Council, Union of Concerned Scientists, League of Conservation Voters, Shedd Aquarium, Defenders of Wildlife, Environmental Working Group, Dairy Business Association, and Edge Dairy Farmer Cooperative.

[[Press Release https://underwood.house.gov/media/press-releases/underwood-gallagher-introduce-bipartisan-climate-change-legislation-support]]
Analysis: The bill sets up "Comprehensive" groupings of CSP conservation activities that support practices that sequester carbon and reduce emissions (like no- till and cover cropping and compost aplication for example). These are known as "bundles", that result in more competitive CSP contracts receiving a higher level of financial assistance to encourage a holistic approach that maximizes conservation benefits."
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Barbara Lee (D-CA-13), Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-OR-3), Rep. Ed Case (D-HI-1)
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Mike Gallagher (R-WI-8)

Name: Climate Justice Grants Act
Summary: This bill would create a 10-year "Climate Justice Grants Program" at EPA, that provides $1 billion per year in climate justice grants (of up to $2 million each) to Tribal governments, local governments, or nonprofit, community-based organizations for projects that address the concerns of environmental justice communities, including to build natural infrastructure.
Support: [[Press Release https://barragan.house.gov/2021/04/12/barragan-introduces-climate-justice-grants-act/]]
Analysis: As per Sec. 2(d), the funds can be used to develop partnerships, provide outreach services, or implement projects to address "climate justice concerns", under which a range of activities is listed. Thus the funding would likely have limited direct impact on soil health or land management. However, land management related projects would technically be allowable for grants, since one of the eligible project types is natural infrastructure, which is defined in the bill as infrastructure that uses, restores, or emulates natural ecological processes and "involves the use of plants, soils, and other natural features, including through the creation, restoration, or preservation of vegetated areas using materials appropriate to the region to manage stormwater and runoff, to attenuate flooding and storm surges, and for other related purposes."
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Doris Matsui (D-CA-6)
Committees: Energy and Commerce - Subcommittee on Energy; Natural Resources

Name: Advancing Conservation and Education Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill allows the states of Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington, or Wyoming to relinquish state land grant parcels wholly or primarily within eligible areas and select, in exchange, public land within the state.

Reintroduction of [[H.R.244 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/244/text]] from 116th Congress
Analysis: This bill aims to simplify the process for states to put state trust lands into conservation, which could improve land management efficiency: "Since statehood land grant land owned by the western States are typically scattered across the public land, creation of Federal conservation areas often include State land grant parcels with substantially different management mandates, making land and resource management more difficult, expensive, and controversial for both Federal land managers and the western States"
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Tom O'Halleran (D-AZ-1)
Committees: Natural Resources - Subcommittee on National Parks, Forests, and Public Lands
Status: Ordered to be Reported by Unanimous Consent.

Name: Civilian Climate Corps Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill establishes a Civilian Climate Corps by utilizing existing national service programs and coordinating with federal and non-federal entities. 

The Civilian Climate Corps would facilitate projects to help disadvantaged communities build resilience to climate change, including efforts to conserve and restore public lands, assist natural disaster-prone communities, utilize natural climate solutions, replace vulnerable infrastructure, protect biodiversity, and enhance ecological resilience.
Support:
The Civilian Climate Corps Act is endorsed by the Corps Network, Voices for National Service, Service Year Alliance, National Wildlife Federation, and the National Audubon Society.

[[Press Release https://www.coons.senate.gov/news/press-releases/new-legislation-for-civilian-climate-corps-introduced-88-years-after-new-deal-era-ccc]]
Analysis:
Sec 5(3)(E) identifies service projects as including the promotion of regenerative agricultural practices. Provides additional support and appropriations for increasing carbon sequestration in the agricultural sector.

Note: There are multiple similar 'conservation corps' expansion ideas that have been proposed in other bills such as the 21st Century Conservation Corps Act (S.487 / H.R.1162), the Climate Stewardship Act (S.1072 / H.R.2820), the Civilian Climate Corps for Jobs and Justice Act (S.1244 / H.R.2670), the Outdoor Restoration Partnership Act (S.1248 / H.R.2682), and the RENEW Conservation Corps Act (S.1370). This particular Act codifies President Biden's call for a national service program in his Executive Order on Tackling the Climate Crisis at Home and Abroad. The White House included a $10 billion fund to establish a Civilian Climate Corps as part of the American Jobs Plan.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Abigail Spanberger (D-VA-7), Rep. Lloyd Doggett (D-TX-35)
Committees: Natural Resources - Subcommittee on Indigenous Peoples of the United States & Subcommittee on National Parks, Forests, and Public Lands; Agriculture - Subcommittee on Conservation and Forestry; Education and Labor
Agencies: U.S. Departments of Agriculture and the Interior

Name: Water for Conservation and Farming Act
Summary:
To provide for drought preparedness and improved water supply reliability in Western regions experiencing high levels of drought. This bill would improve water access for agriculture and conservation by funding projects that improve dam safety, create more resilient watersheds and benefit agricultural and urban water users.

Sec. 201(a)(1) directs the Secretary of the Interior to establish a program to provide financial assistance to eligible agricultural producers in Reclamation States, in the form of direct payments or credits, as applicable, to compensate the eligible agricultural producers for the creation and maintenance of waterbird and shorebird habitats.

Sec. 204(b) establishes a competitive grant program under which the Secretary shall award grants to eligible applicants for the design, implementation, and monitoring of conservation outcomes of habitat restoration projects that improve watershed health in a Reclamation State, including by providing ecosystem benefits, restoration of native species, protection against invasive species, and restoration of aspects of the natural ecosystem. 

(Reintroduction of [[S.4189 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/4189/text]] - Water for Conservation and Farming Act of 2020)
Support:
The bill has received support from Trout Unlimited, The Freshwater Trust, Family Farm Alliance, Agency Ranch, Sustainable Norhwest, and Morrow and Gilliam Soil & Water Conservation Districts. 

[[Press Release https://www.wyden.senate.gov/news/press-releases/wyden-and-merkley-introduce-bill-to-improve-water-access-for-agriculture-and-conservation-as-west-continues-to-face-drought-]]
Analysis:
This bill provides supplemental appropriations to support conservation projects that conserve water, increase water use efficiency, and improve the condition of natural water recharge infrastructure. The improvement of soil health is a key mechanism for meeting these stated goals and mitigating drought on agricultural lands. There is an opportunity for soil health to be made more explicit in this bill.

Sec. 204(b) could provide financial incentives and compensation to producers adopting soil health management practices, which contribute to the stated goals. 

•This bill is in front of the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, which is more active than the Ag Committee (that in recent years does little outside of the -every 5 year- Farm Bill cycle), so this bill may be able to more quickly through committee.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-OR)
Committees: Energy and Natural Resources - Subcommittee on Water and Power
Status: Hearings held by the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources Subcommittee on Water and Power.

Name: Climate Emergency Act of 2021
Summary:
To require the President to declare a national climate emergency under the National Emergencies Act, and for other purposes.

Sec. 3(b)(1) directs the Federal Government to respond to the national emergency declared by investing in large scale mitigation and resiliency projects, including projects that (D) protect and restore wetlands, forests, public lands, and other natural climate solutions; and (E) create opportunities for farmers and rural communities, including by bolstering regenerative agriculture, and invest in local and regional food systems that support farmers, agricultural workers, healthy soil, and climate resilience; among other priorities
Support:
Blumenauer [[Press Release https://blumenauer.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/blumenauer-ocasio-cortez-and-sanders-introduce-legislation-mandate]]

This is a bicameral bill, with ][[S.938 https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/senate-bill/938/text]] sponsored by Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT) in the Senate.
Analysis: This bill explicitly mentions and has broad ranging implications for soil health. The bill would enable emergency federal funding to be allocated towards soil health projects, recognizing the value of soil health practices in addressing a broad range of climate change impacts and building resilience to extreme shocks.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-OR), Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA), Sen. Edward Markey (D-MA), Sen. Cory Booker (D-NJ)

Name: Carbon Removal, Efficient Technologies, Technology Expertise (CREATE) Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill would establish the "Committee on Large-Scale Carbon Management" in the Department of Energy and a Federal Carbon Removal Initiative.

This bill is the reintroduction of [[S.4341 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/4341/text]] - the CREATE Act of 2020.
Analysis:
The bill defines carbon dioxide removal as including soil carbon management, bioenergy with carbon capture and sequestration, and forest restoration, among other methods.

The proposed Committee must consider all available data on the carbon sequestration and storage potential of soils (including data collected externally to the Federal Government), as well as the cost effectiveness of soil carbon management as a carbon removal mechanism (in comparison to direct capture and technology based carbon removal solutions). 

If the Committee duly considers soil carbon management in its research, the associated recommendations could lead to support for producers to implement soil health practices.

New in this version of the bill: adds to the definition of carbon dioxide removal "any other approaches or methods identified by the Committee"; adds to the duties of the Committee "Monitoring the long-term carbon and environmental impacts of carbon dioxide removal." and "Evaluating socio-economic and community impacts resulting from the application of carbon dioxide removal technologies..."; directs the Committee to coordinate with other relevant agencies; establishes a multi-agency plan for the collection and management of data on carbon emissions and carbon dioxide removal that integrates existing data collection efforts acoss the Federal Government.
While these updates are new in the House version of the bill, the reintroduced Senate version (S.843) is identical to the version introduced in the 116th Congress, and retains the previous name (CREATE Act).

Name: America's Clean Future Fund Act
Summary:
This bill would establish a new program to pay farmers and ranchers for implementing practices that sequester carbon and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Sec. 6(a) directs the Secretary of Agriculture to provide payments to farmers, ranchers, private forest landowners, and other agricultural landowners in the United States that reduce or sequester greenhouse gas emissions through the adoption of qualifying farming, ranching, and forestry practices. The assistance seeks to help finance the transition to improved practices that will allow producers' participation in private sector greenhouse gas credit markets.

The bill would implement several other measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and fund the transtion to a clean energy economy, including the establishment of an independent federal agency (Climate Change Finance Corporation, or C2FC) to finance and support investment and job creation in clean energy projects, climate resilience, and research, development, and deployment; and a carbon fee by 2023.

(Reintroduction of [[S.4484 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/4484/text]] - America's Clean Future Fund Act, from 116th Congress)
Support:
The bill is supported by EDF, C2ES, Citizens’ Climate Lobby (CCL).

Durbin [[Press Release https://www.durbin.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/durbin-introduces-bill-to-invest-in-a-clean-climate-future-and-spur-job-creation]] / Newman [[Press Release https://newman.house.gov/media/press-releases/us-representative-marie-newman-introduces-first-bill-americas-clean-future]]
Analysis:
Sec. 6(c) establishes a program to provide payments to eligible producers that will assist with the transition to reducing greenhouse gas emissions through the adoption of qualifying practices, which include improved soil, water, and land management systems through diverse crop rotations, cover crops, conservation tillage, conservation plantings, the integration of livestock, conservation easements that include soil health improvement, and other practices. 

Sec. 6(c) also outlines several key considerations in determining the rate and duration of a payment, including additionality, early adopters, permanence, and current soil conditions.

This new version of the Act (reintroduced from 116th Congress) expands on the provisions for monitoring and verification: Sec 6(d) establishes an outcomes-based measurement system and directs the Secretary of Agriculture to set standards accordingly and within 18 months (based on information obtained from agro-ecosystem models, remote sensing data and analysis, soil health demonstration trials, and field-level measurement). The establishment of a national standard is essential for facilitating the participation of farmers and ranchers in the various incentives and payment schemes. There is, however, opportunity for protocols to be outlined more specifically in this section.

Sec. 2(A) directs the proposed C2FC to provide grant and loan funding to entities conducting approved practices and projects relating to climate change mitigation, risk reduction and resilience measures, including increasing the resilience of the agriculture sector. This provision could support innovative projects related to soil health.

Name: Farm to School Act of 2021
Summary:
This bill would renew the Farm to School Program, originally authorized in 2010, under which the USDA provides grants to schools to implement "farm to school activities" aimed at delivering fresh, local foods to schools.

The bill would expand participation in the program to preschools, after-school programs, and summer food service sites, and increases annual mandatory funding from $5 to $15 million.
Support:
The bill is supported by the National Farm to School Network, and the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition.

Plaskett [[Press Release https://plaskett.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=3758]]
Analysis:
The grants provided by the program can provide nutrition as well as education outcomes for students, while encouraging procurement of local foods. Eligible activities include: (I) planting and maintenance of farms or gardens; (II) procurement from local agricultural producers; or (III) educational activities relating to agriculture, nutrition, or food.”

There is little detail provided on requirements for procurement beyond "local" (eg. no information about size of farm, management practices). Advocates could call for procurement requirements to prioritize farms using soil health practices, to support local markets for regenerative products.

Since 2013, USDA has received more than 1,900 applications requesting over $141 million, however, only 437 awards were granted from the $30 million available ($5 million per year). The Farm to School Act increases annual mandatory funding for Farm to School to $15 million to meet the current need and increases the maximum individual grant award to $250,000.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Alma Adams (D-NC-12), Rep. Ed Case (D-HI-1), Rep. Shontel Brown (D-OH-11)
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Jeff Fortenberry (R-NE-1)

Name: FLOODS Act
Summary:
To establish a national integrated flood information system within the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and for other purposes.

Sec. 3(b)(1)(A) collects and integrates information on the key indicators of floods and flood impacts, including streamflow, reservoir release and diversion, precipitation, soil moisture, snow water equivalent, land cover, and evaporative demand.

Sec. 5(c)(1)(B) directs service coordinattion hydrologists to liaise with users of products and services of the National Weather Service, such as the public, academia, media outlets, users in the hydropower, transportation, recreation, and agricultural communities, and forestry, land, fisheries, and water management interests, to evaluate the adequacy and usefulness of the products and services of the National Weather Service.

Summary:
This bill adds the explicit goals of addressing carbon sequestration and reduction of emissions to research done through the Agriculture Advanced Research and Development Authority (AgARDA) program, amending the National Agricultural Research, Extension, and Teaching Policy Act of 1977 to enhance the role of agriculture in innovative sustainability solutions.

Name: 21st Century Conservation Corps Act
Summary:
Establishes the 21st Century Civilian Conservation Corps and provides supplemental appropriations for workforce training and jobs to support conservation programs and reforestation to restore public lands; address deferred maintenance and expand recreation access on our public lands; provide direct relief for outfitters and guides; improve access to clean drinking water; and bolster wildfire prevention and preparedness.

To carry out a Civilian Conservation Corps program, provide supplemental appropriations for certain conservation activities, to provide for increased reforestation across the United States, to provide incentives for agricultural producers to carry out climate stewardship practices, and for other purposes.

(Reintroduction of [[S.3684 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/3684/text]] - 21st Century Conservation Corps for Our Health and Our Jobs Act)
Support:
The bill has received support from organizations including the Sierra Club, Accesss Fund, Rural Voices for Conservattion Coalition, The Freshwater Trust, The Wilderness Society, The Trust for Public Land, The Corps Network, Outdoor Industry Association, America Outdoors Association, American Forests, and others. See support [[here https://neguse.house.gov/imo/media/doc/Support_CCC_2021.pdf]].

Wyden [[Press Release https://www.wyden.senate.gov/news/press-releases/wyden-neguse-unveil-plan-to-establish-21st-century-conservation-corps-invest-in-wildfire-resiliency]] / Neguse [[Press Release https://neguse.house.gov/media/press-releases/rep-neguse-and-senator-wyden-unveil-plan-to-establish-21st-century-conservation-corps-invest-in-wildfire-resiliency]]
Analysis:
Would provide increased funding for a number of programs that support natural resource management and conservation, including an additional $5.5 billion in funding to USDA-NRCS' Regional Conservation Partnership Program (RCPP), to increase on-farm, watershed, and regional conservation work that puts people to work creating water resiliency infrastructure; 

This legislation makes climate stewardship practices eligible for new supplemental funding under the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP) without changing existing CSP programs and funding. It would support voluntary climate stewardship practices on over 100 million acres of farmland by providing tens of billions of dollars of supplemental funding for USDA working lands conservation programs, with new funding dedicated to stewardship practices such as rotational grazing, improved fertilizer efficiency, and planting tens of millions of new acres of cover crops.

Recognizes the key role of soil health practices across USDA programs, and increases various sources of support for farmers and ranchers looking to adopt conservation practices. 

Note: There are multiple similar 'conservation corps' expansion ideas that have been proposed in other bills such as the Civilian Climate Corps Act of 2021 (S.1057 / H.R.2241), the Climate Stewardship Act (S.1072 / H.R.2820), the Civilian Climate Corps for Jobs and Justice Act (S.1244 / H.R.2670), the Outdoor Restoration Partnership Act (S.1248 / H.R.2682), and the RENEW Conservation Corps Act (S.1370). This Act aligns with President Biden's call for a national service program in his Executive Order on Tackling the Climate Crisis at Home and Abroad. The White House included a $10 billion fund to establish a Civilian Climate Corps as part of the American Jobs Plan.

Name: Feed Emergency Enhancement During Disasters with Cover Crops (FEEDD) Act
Summary:
This bill would amend the Federal Crop Insurance Act to modify prevented planting coverage. Specifically, the bill would: 

Direct the Secretary of Agriculture to allow for haying, grazing or chopping of a cover crop on prevented plant acres before November 1 in the event of a feed shortage due to excessive moisture, flood or drought.

Direct the Secretary to establish regional haying and grazing dates for each crop year (providing flexibility in comparison to the current date, November 1, which is set on a nationwide basis).

Maintain crop insurance program integrity and have no impact on a producers’ Actual Production History (APH).
Support:
The Act is endorsed by the North Dakota Corn Growers Association, North Dakota Farmers Union, North Dakota Grain Growers Association, North Dakota Stockmen’s Association, Ag Retailers Association, American Bankers Association, American Farm Bureau Federation, American Sheep Industry Association, American Soybean Association, Ducks Unlimited, Edge Dairy Farmer Cooperative, Farm Credit Council, Independent Community Bankers of America, Midwest Dairy Coalition, National Association of Conservation Districts, National Cattlemen’s Beef Association, National Council of Farmer Cooperatives, National Farmers Union, National Milk Producers Federation, National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition, The Nature Conservancy, U.S. Durum Growers Association, and U.S. Cattlemen’s Association. See industry statements of support [[here https://www.hoeven.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/Feed%20Emergency%20Enhancement%20During%20Disasters%20with%20Cover%20Crops.pdf]].

Hoeven [[Press Release https://www.hoeven.senate.gov/news/news-releases/hoeven-and-baldwin-introduce-bipartisan-legislation-to-alleviate-feed-shortages]] / Johnson [[Press Release https://dustyjohnson.house.gov/media/in-the-news/feedd-act-alleviate-livestock-feed-shortages]]
Analysis:
Provides farmers and ranchers additional flexibility to alleviate feed shortages in years with widespread excessive moisture, flooding or drought. This flexibility could increase confidence and certainty for farmers considering planting cover crops.

Recognizes the effectiveness of cover crops in building soil health and addressing disasters, including drought and flood.

Common sense policy change

Name: Strengthening Local Processing Act of 2021
Summary:

Authorize competitive grants to small and very small establishments, state inspected facilities, custom exempt facilities, or new small-scale slaughter facilities for activities related to COVID-19 response and recovery. 

Authorize a new $10 million grant program for colleges and universities to establish or expand meat processing training program, and a new $10 million grant program for small and very small establishments or nongovernmental organizations to offset the cost of training new meat processors.
Support:
The bill has been supported by the National Farmers Union, United States Cattlemen's Association, Center for Rural Affairs, American Association of Meat Processors, National Bison Association, Niche Meat Processors Assistance Network, and the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition.

[[Press Release https://pingree.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=3620]]
Analysis: The bill would increase processing options for local livestock and poultry producers, increase the slaughter and processing capacity across the United States in order to respond to the supply chain disruption caused by Covid-19 and other crises, and help meet consumer demand for locally-raised meat.

Cosponsors (R): Sen. Susan Collins (R-ME), Sen. Mike Rounds (R-SD), Sen. Kevin Cramer (R-ND)

Name: 21st Century Conservation Corps Act
Summary:
Establishes the 21st Century Civilian Conservation Corps and provides supplemental appropriations for workforce training and jobs to support conservation programs and reforestation to restore public lands; address deferred maintenance and expand recreation access on our public lands; provide direct relief for outfitters and guides; improve access to clean drinking water; and bolster wildfire prevention and preparedness.

To carry out a Civilian Conservation Corps program, provide supplemental appropriations for certain conservation activities, to provide for increased reforestation across the United States, to provide incentives for agricultural producers to carry out climate stewardship practices, and for other purposes.
Support:
The bill has received support from organizations including the Sierra Club, Accesss Fund, Rural Voices for Conservattion Coalition, The Freshwater Trust, The Wilderness Society, The Trust for Public Land, The Corps Network, Outdoor Industry Association, America Outdoors Association, American Forests, and others. See support [[here https://neguse.house.gov/imo/media/doc/Support_CCC_2021.pdf]].

Wyden [[Press Release https://www.wyden.senate.gov/news/press-releases/wyden-neguse-unveil-plan-to-establish-21st-century-conservation-corps-invest-in-wildfire-resiliency]] / Neguse [[Press Release https://neguse.house.gov/media/press-releases/rep-neguse-and-senator-wyden-unveil-plan-to-establish-21st-century-conservation-corps-invest-in-wildfire-resiliency]]
Analysis:
Would provide increased funding for a number of programs that support natural resource management and conservation, including an additional $5.5 billion in funding to USDA-NRCS' Regional Conservation Partnership Program (RCPP), to increase on-farm, watershed, and regional conservation work that puts people to work creating water resiliency infrastructure; 

This legislation makes climate stewardship practices eligible for new supplemental funding under the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP) without changing existing CSP programs and funding. It would support voluntary climate stewardship practices on over 100 million acres of farmland by providing tens of billions of dollars of supplemental funding for USDA working lands conservation programs, with new funding dedicated to stewardship practices such as rotational grazing, improved fertilizer efficiency, and planting tens of millions of new acres of cover crops.

Recognizes the key role of soil health practices across USDA programs, and increases various sources of support for farmers and ranchers looking to adopt conservation practices. 

Note: There are multiple similar 'conservation corps' expansion ideas that have been proposed in other bills such as the Civilian Climate Corps Act of 2021 (S.1057 / H.R.2241), the Climate Stewardship Act (S.1072 / H.R.2820), the Civilian Climate Corps for Jobs and Justice Act (S.1244 / H.R.2670), the Outdoor Restoration Partnership Act (S.1248 / H.R.2682), and the RENEW Conservation Corps Act (S.1370). This Act aligns with President Biden's call for a national service program in his Executive Order on Tackling the Climate Crisis at Home and Abroad. The White House included a $10 billion fund to establish a Civilian Climate Corps as part of the American Jobs Plan.

Name: PUGET SOS Act
Summary:
This bill amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to provide support for the restoration and protection of the water quality of Puget Sound, an estuary in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Washington. 

Specifically, the bill establishes (1) a Puget Sound Recovery National Program Office within the Environmental Protection Agency; and (2) the Puget Sound Federal Leadership Task Force, which replaces the existing Puget Sound Federal Task Force.

Finally, the bill establishes a State Advisory Committee.

The Act specifically provides funding for a Task Force to fight the acidification of the Puget Sound on a number of fronts including agricultural runoff management and soil erosion.

(Reintroduction of [[H.R.2247 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/2247/text]] - PUGET SOS Act from 116th Congress)
Support:
This bill is supported by the Puget Sound Partnership, the Northwest Indian Fisheries Commission, The Nature Conservancy and Washington Environmental Council.

[[Press Release https://kilmer.house.gov/news/press-releases/kilmer-strickland-introduce-legislation-to-bolster-puget-sound-restoration-and-recovery-efforts]]
Analysis:
This bill is not directly about soil health. However, Sec. 124(d)(2)(C)(xi) does mention the link between soil health and water quality. This language shows the importance of water infiltration in soil and how erosion from farm land can carry significant pollution into water sources. 

Although this bill is centrally focused on the Puget Sound and water quality (rather than soil health), it serves as an example of the important link between the two. The language linking the two in this bill could serve as a model to use in other soil health/water quality legislation.

Although the previous version of the bill passed the House unanimously as a standalone bill, parts of the bill were included in S.1811 - the Water Resources Development Act of 2020.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Marilyn Strickland (D-WA-10), Rep. Adam Smith (D-WA-9), Rep. Rick Larsen (D-WA-2), Rep. Suzan DelBene (D-WA-1)
Committees: Transportation and Infrastructure - Subcommittee on Water Resources and Environment
Status: Passed House; Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Environment and Public Works.

Name: Justice for Black Farmers Act of 2021
Summary:
The Justice for Black Farmers Act will reform the U.S. Department of Agriculture, including by creating an independent civil rights oversight board, provide debt relief and create a land grant program and a Farm Conservation Corps to encourage a new generation of Black farmers. 

Sec. 201(3) defines training, as supported through the Act, as providing "basic skills to operate a farm or ranch profitably with a primary focus on regenerating the soil, ecosystem, and local community".

The Act substantially increases funding for USDA technical assistance and for programs such as the Conservation Stewardship Program (CSP), which compensates farmers and ranchers for practices that build soil health such as crop rotation, cover cropping, reduced and no till, and rotational grazing; and gives priority for these programs, as well as increased access to capital, to all socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers. 

Reintroduction of [[S.4929 https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/4929/text]] - Justice for Black Farmers Act of 2020
Support:
The Act has received endorsement from 170+ groups, including the National Farmers Union, National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition (NSAC), Center for Biological Diversity, Community Farm Alliance, Family Farm Action Alliance, Grassroots International, Intertribal Agriculture Council, National Black Farmers Association, National Young Farmers Coalition, Union of Concerned Scientists, and others. See [[full list  https://www.booker.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/2%20JUSTICE%20FOR%20BLACK%20FARMERS%20ACT%20endorsements%202.8.21.pdf]]here.[[

Booker [[Press Release https://www.booker.senate.gov/news/press/booker-warren-gillibrand-smith-warnock-and-leahy-announce-comprehensive-bill-to-address-the-history-of-discrimination-in-federal-agricultural-policy#:~:text=The%20Justice%20for%20Black%20Farmers%20Act%20will%20enact%20policies%20to,to%20help%20family%20farmers%20across]] / Adams Press Release
Analysis:
Although this bill centrally addresses civil rights and "social justice," it does directly address soil health by allocating new funding for soil health practices under programs like the Conservation Stewardship Program, and explicitly puts soil health at the core of training and support for new and disadvantaged farmers.

Ties social justice to soil health.

Name: National Climate Bank Act
Summary:
This bill would establish an independent, national climate bank funded with $50 billion initially, and an additional $10 billion every year for five years, into projects that reduce carbon emissions. 

Sec. 5245F. Project Types includes as key areas (5) Climate resiliency measures, (7) Reforestation of degraded land, and (8) Agricultural projects, among others.
Support:
Markey [[Press Release https://www.markey.senate.gov/news/press-releases/senators-markey-van-hollen-and-rep-dingell-re-introduce-legislation-to-create-a-clean-energy-and-sustainability-accelerator]]

Senate [[hearing held 4/27/2021 https://www.epw.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2021/4/legislative-hearing-on-s-283-national-climate-bank-act]]
Analysis:
While the establishment of this bank would be geared primarily towards the energy sector, it is also a potential source of funding for regenerative agriculture practices.

Beyond the instances that most directly impact soil health (eligibility of agricultural, reforestation, and climate resiliency projects), there is additional general language that presents the opportunity to pursue soil health goals more specifically. For example, under Sec. 5245G, the Cash for Carbon Program could be used to help farmers transition to soil health practices. Likewise, Sec. 5245H (a)(2) enabling the Bank to invest directly in projects that reduce emissions across the United States could be used to fund soil health projects. Should this bill become law, these sections present opportunities to actively pursue the inclusion of soil health goals.
Cosponsors (D): Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD), Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-CT), Sen. Brian Schatz (D-HI), Sen. Martin Heinrich (D-NM), Sen. Debbie Stabenow (D-NM), Sen. Cory Booker (D-NJ), Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA)

Name: Expressing the need for the Federal Government to establish a national biodiversity strategy for protecting biodiversity for current and future generations
Summary: This resolution calls for a national commitment to addressing biodiversity loss by establishing a strategy (ideally to be developed through an interagency process) announced by the president in an Executive Order; sets a national goal of conserving at least 30 percent of US lands and waters by 2030 and supporting the same goals globally.
Support:
This resolution has been supported by 60+ groups working on wildlife protection and conservation, including the Center for Biological Diversity, Environmental Defense Fund, National Audubon Society, Natural Resources Defense Council, among others (see [[full list https://neguse.house.gov/imo/media/doc/Support%20letter%20for%20Rep.%20Neguse%20National%20Biodiversity%20Strategy%20resolution_Dec2020_final.pdf]]). The resolution has also been supported by a group of leading scientists in the field (read [[support letter https://neguse.house.gov/imo/media/doc/Signed_House_NBS_scientist_sign-on.pdf]]).

 [[Press Release https://neguse.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-joe-neguse-reintroduces-resolution-calling-for-national-biodiversity-strategy]]
Analysis:
Recognizes the decline of biodiversity causing soil loss as pressenting a direct threat to the security, health, and well-being of the people of the United States.

Building soil health is a key pathway towards restoring biodiversity.

The resolution endorses pathways forward for the effective conservation, restoration, and durable protection of at least 30 percent of an ecologically representative area of the Nation's lands, freshwaters, and oceans by 2030 by working collaboratively with governments, land owners, fishers, indigenous people, communities, and others; this creates opportunity for farmers and ranchers to be key partners in the achievement of such a strategy.

Sec. 2(F) notes that the resolution should include direction on advancing conservation in collaboration with the State and Tribal governments and on private lands through incentives, funding, technical support, and partnerships; this could create support for the development of market-based incentives and technical support for producers looking to adopt soil health practices.

The resolution discusses incorporating indigenous knowledge and practices, which promote soil health, to support conservation and biodiversity.

The goal of conserving 30 percent of US lands and waters by 2030 was also included in the President's Executive Order on Climate Change, signed 01/27/2021.

Name: Healthy Soil, Resilient Farmers Act of 2020 (116th Congress)
Summary: This bill would amend the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act with respect to the conservation loan and loan guarantee program, to establish a “Soil Health Transition Loan Program” at USDA and distribute these loans to help crop and livestock producers improve their soil health and increase their soil carbon levels.
Support:
This bill is supported by the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition and the Organic Trade Association

[[Press Release https://spanberger.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=3218]]
Analysis:
Loans would be authorized and distributed by expanding existing authorities at the USDA under the Farm Service Agency’s Conservation Loan Program. Farmers receiving these loans would be allowed a three-year deferment on the loan’s interest and payments on loan principle.

The bill would support farmers looking to start or strengthen existing conservation efforts on their farms, providing additional flexibility for farmers looking to adopt best practices in cover-cropping, crop rotation, advanced grazing management, organic production, and additional techniques.

Name: Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2021
Summary:

"Natural Resources Conservation Service - Conservation Operations - For necessary expenses for carrying out the provisions of the Act of April 27, 1935 (16 U.S.C. 590a–f), including preparation of conservation plans and establishment of measures to conserve soil and water (including farm irrigation and land drainage and such special measures for soil and water management as may be necessary to prevent floods and the siltation of reservoirs and to control agricultural related pollutants); operation of conservation plant materials centers; classification and mapping of soil; dissemination of information..."

Divison A, Title II - Farm Production and Conservation Programs includes funding for NRCS

The Act includes includes agricultural practices and soil carbon management as methods of carbon dioxide removal
Analysis:
The most pertinent section for soil health is in the section providing funding for NRCS. This section directly addresses the importance of soil health. Name: Farmer Driven Conservation Outcomes Act of 2020 (116th Congress)
Summary:
This bill would amend the Soil and Water Resources Conservation Act of 1977 to direct the USDA to establish a process through which to measure, evaluate and report on conservation program outcomes. 

The bill would provide USDA with the tools and authority to quantify the environmental benefits of conservation activities, and directs USDA to report to Congress and the public on the measurement and evaluation process, in order to demonstrate their impact and further improve program performance regarding on-farm productivity, soil health, and water quality. 

The Act does not provide new funding to the USDA to develop and implement the program, instead directing "not more than one percent of the total annual funding from the funds of the Commodity Credit Corporation made available for new annual enrollments for the conservation programs established under subtitles D and H of title XII of the Food Security Act of 1985."
Support:
It is supported by the American Farmland Trust, Chesapeake Bay Foundation, National Farmers Union, National Milk Producers Federation, National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition, National Wildlife Federation, National Young Farmers Coalition, R Street, and Taxpayers for Common Sense.

[[Press Release https://www.casey.senate.gov/newsroom/releases/casey-capito-introduce-bill-to-support-farmers-efforts-to-mitigate-climate-change-improve-water-quality-]]
Analysis:
This data would provide a valuable 'proof of concept' for innovative land management techniques and conservation practices that could be used to secure further incentives for producers to adopt those practices in subsequent legislation.

Sec. 9(b)(6) provides a means for USDA to compensate farmers and other producers for cooperating with the data collection efforts implemented by this Act. This provision, however, is vague and leaves much discretion to USDA in determining eligibility for and access to any compensation. 

Those advocating for outcomes-verified soil heath testing might seek more funding for this program and an expanded incentive structure for farmers cooperating with data collection.

Common sense policy change
Cosponsors (R): Sen. Shelley Moore Capito (R-WV)

Name: AFFIRM Act of 2020 (116th Congress)
Summary:
This bill would reduce the amount of money the Federal Government spends on crop insurance by limiting elligibility for federal crop insurance subsidies to individuals or legal entities with adjusted gross income of less than $250,000 per year. 

The bill would also end all federal subsidies for crop insurance policies that incorporate a harvest price valuation, and impose a limit on the rate of return for crop insurance providers.
Support:
This bill is supported by organizations including R Street Institute, Americans for Prosperity, Campaign for Liberty, Council for Citizens Against Government Waste, FreedomWorks, Heritage Action for America, National Taxpayers Union, and Taxpayers for Common Sense.

Noteable Press: [[R Street https://www.rstreet.org/2020/02/20/free-market-and-conservative-groups-support-the-affirm-act/]]

[[Press Release https://www.shaheen.senate.gov/news/press/shaheen-toomey-introduce-bipartisan-crop-insurance-reform-bill-that-would-deliver-nearly-35-billion-in-savings-to-taxpayers]]
Analysis:
In its current form, this bill would shift significantly more risk onto farmers and reduce the support they receive for crop insurance. 

The cost-saving intent of this bill could instead be advanced by supporting soil health practice as part of broader crop-risk-reduction strategies through Federally-supported crop insurance. Soil health practice reduces the risk of catastrophic damage from flooding and drought, and provides a way to reduce the cost of crop insurance without limiting the protection farmers receive.

Supporting farmers while reducing costs and risk can be a bipartisan approach to government spending.
Cosponsors (R): Sen. Pat Toomey (R-PA)

Name: Natural Infrastructure and Resilience Act (116th Congress)
Summary:
This bill would amend title 23, USC, to make certain natural infrastructure projects eligible for surface transportation block grant funding. 

This bill would alter the Surface Transportation Block Grant program ($850,000,000 per year) to allow it to support projects that use natural infrastructure such as soils, vegetation, and ecological processes to improve the "resilience" of other transportation infrastructure.
Support:
The bill has received the endorsements of the NJ Audubon Society, The Nature Conservancy, and the League of Conservation Voters

[[Press Release https://malinowski.house.gov/media/press-releases/representative-malinowski-introduces-bipartisan-natural-infrastructure-and]]
Analysis:
The bill specifically defines "resilience" to include properties that either mitigate the effects of natural disasters or reduce their occurrence, which would allow soil health projects that reduce the risk and severity of flooding to receive grant funding.  

Federal programs that recognize and support the importance of non-monetary concepts like resilience offer an opportunity to demonstrate the widespread benefits of soil health.
Cosponsors (D): Rep. Albio Sires (D-NJ-8), Rep. Scott H. Peters (D-CA-52)
Cosponsors (R): Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-FL-1), Rep. Francis Rooney (R-FL-19)

Name: Food Recovery Act of 2020 (116th Congress)
Summary:
This bill aims to decrease the incidence of food waste and achieve other purposes. 

Sec. 103 of this bill would add agricultural composting practices to the list of practices eligible for support under USDA's Conservation Stewardship Program, Environmental Quality Incentives Program, and Delivery of Technical Assistance programs.
Support:
The Food Recovery Act of 2017 was also considered in the Senate and was sponsored by Senator Blumenthal.

This bill is supported by Recology, Hungry Harvest, the American Biogas Council, Harvard Law School Food Law and Policy Clinic, Good Food Advocate, Cumberland County Food Security Council, and the Natural Resources Council of Maine.

[[Press Release https://pingree.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=158]]
Analysis:
The practices supported by the bill include not only practices that produce compost from agricultural waste, but also the use of that compost to improve soil health. 

While the current form of the bill does not provide support for other methods of improving soil health, it could provide resources for farmers to more easily secure compost and to incorporate it into their soil conservation practices. 

Soil health advocates can push for the language of this bill to be expanded to include support for broader practices that incorporate compost as one part of an overall soil health improvement strategy.

The resolution does also discuss the importance of traditional and indigenous ways of agriculture which promote soil health. These traditional and indigenous practices probably involve cover cropping, no-till, and other agricultural techniques that promote soil health.

Name: Urban Agriculture Healthy Food and Entrepreneur Act (116th Congress)
Summary:
This bill provides financial incentives for urban entrepreneurs and farmers to build production within their communities with the goal of alleviating food deserts and food swamps. 

This bill: 1) Instructs the Secretary of Agriculture to establish the Urban Agriculture Conservation Easement Program for the conservation of eligible land, improved community food security, and improved access to crop land for beginning farmers or ranchers, socially disadvantaged farmers or ranchers, and majority-controlled producer-based business ventures through easements or other interests in land; 2) Instructs the Secretary of Agriculture to establish an Urban Agriculture Microentrepreneur Assistance Program to provide loans and grants to support microentrepreneurs in the development and ongoing success of urban agriculture microenterprises; 3) Extends the authority of the Community Food Project Grant Program by $15 million annually; and 4) Increases funding for the Farm to Schools Program by $10 million.

Name: Water Supply Infrastructure Rehabilitation and Utilization Act (116th Congress)
Summary:
This bill seeks to amend the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009 and to provide additional water supply infrastructure funds under that act to allow local operators of federally owned facilities to maintain and improve aging water infrastructure. 

The bill, according to press releases, seeks to improve drought resilience and to maintain and update water infrastructure that farms and cities are built on. 

The bill also seeks to adjust the flood control rule curve (an accepted practice in allocating the reservoir space of a multipurpose dam with the conflicting characteristic to both flood control and conservation purposes). The pilot program criteria considers both runoff and soil moisture levels for establishing funding.
Support:
The bill has support from organizations including the National Water Resources Association and the Washington State Water Users Association.

[[Press Release https://newhouse.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/newhouse-introduces-bill-maintain-repair-water-supply-infrastructure]]

This section could thus be improved by making clear the link between soil moisture and soil health, and its importance to water conservation.

Name: Hardrock Leasing and Reclamation Act of 2019 (116th Congress)
Summary:
This bill primarily seeks to govern mining on public lands by modifying current requirements, subjecting mining to the same scrutiny as other uses of public lands, such as grazing, hunting, and energy development. 

The bill replaces the 1872 Mining Law with a modern leasing system that increases oversight of mining companies. Currently, public lands and resources are vulnerable to mining and a lack of cleanup (polluting waters) by these mining companies. 

These are procedures to be added to the public lands mining permitting processes that take reclamation into account: "(b) Operation And Reclamation Standards.—The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture shall jointly promulgate regulations that establish operation and reclamation standards for mineral activities permitted under this Act. The Secretaries may determine whether outcome-based performance standards or technology-based design standards are most appropriate. The regulations shall address the following:

(1) Segregation, protection, and replacement of topsoil or other suitable growth medium, and the prevention, where possible, of soil contamination."
Support:
The bill has support from the [[National Wildlife Federation https://www.nwf.org/Latest-News/Press-Releases/2019/10-23-19-Hardrock-Mining-Reform]].

[[Press Release https://grijalva.house.gov/press-releases/natural-resources-committee-passes-mining-reform-mining-pension-bills/]]
Analysis:
This bill has very little direct soil health implications, however, one of the stated goals of the bill is to protect natural resources such as soil. Sec. 307(b) explains that "The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture shall jointly promulgate regulations that establish operation and reclamation standards for mineral activities permitted under this Act. The Secretaries may determine whether outcome-based performance standards or technology-based design standards are most appropriate."

In the same section, 307(b)(1) further explains that the regulations shall address the "Segregation, protection, and replacement of topsoil or other suitable growth medium, and the prevention, where possible, of soil contamination." 307(b)(3) states that the regulations should also address the control of sediments to prevent erosion and manage drainage. Thus, this is an area where language about soil health measurement could be useful in that it could reinforce the primary goal of protecting and conserving natural resources by preventing mining companies from stripping the soil and leaving it without nutrients. 

These regulations can address and consider soil health practices and one could easily imagine further language in this section tying these standards to explicit soil health measurement programs in order to promote the conservation of resources soil on public lands.

Name: Biochar Research Network Act of 2023
Summary:
This bill would establish a national biochar research network at USDA.

The research network would include up to 20 centers "to test the impact of biochar across various soil types, application methods and climates to learn more about its capacity to benefit farmers and the environment."

The specific goals of the network would be to "understand the uses of biochar in crop production and climate mitigation; assessing its potential for soil carbon sequestration; and delivering cost-effective and practical information to farmers on sustainable biochar production and application."

Authorizes appropriations of $50 million annually.
Support:
The press release contains a support statement from David Laird, Professor Emeritus of Soil Science at Iowa State University.

Grassley [[Press Release https://www.grassley.senate.gov/news/news-releases/grassley-reintroduces-bill-to-study-use-of-biochar-on-farms-and-forests]] 

In May 2022, Grassley and colleagues wrote a [[letter https://millermeeks.house.gov/sites/evo-subsites/millermeeks.house.gov/files/evo-media-document/5.26.2022%20MMM%20IA%20Delegation%20Letter%20to%20EPA%20and%20USDA.pdf]] to USDA and EPA expressing their support for biochar.
Analysis:
Biochar is created through the thermal or chemical conversion of biomass. For example, when a forest fire burns up trees and plants it leaves behind biochar. It spans across all kinds of black carbon, and can be made from many different types of organic material – including agricultural waste.

The proposal includes assessments of the most promising uses of biochar, including to "increase profitability, scalability, and portability", "to improve ecosystem and soil health", and "strengthen resilience to extreme weather events". 

Requires the centers to "share research results to inform farmers, horticulturalists, ranchers, foresters, urban biochar users, extension agents and specialists, and technical assistance providers on the most advantageous ways to use biochar to increase profitability, raise productivity, lower costs, improve soil and plant health, and enhance resilience to extreme weather events while contributing to carbon sequestration and greenhouse gas reductions."
